PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: We, the undersigned, wish to protest against the Federal Government's proposed 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on books, newspapers and magazines.
This proposed tax is a tax on knowledge and an impediment to the free flow of information. We respectfully request that these items be exempted from the sales tax provisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Sir William McMahon and Mr Hicks.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: SINCLAIR; BROWN; HODGES; MCMAHON; MILLAR; O'KEEFE; PEACOCK
PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers, particularly educational publications and books of a religious nature, is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, a clear infringement of our democratic freedom, and that no such tax is levied in any other country with which Australia is usually compared.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Sinclair,Mr Robert Brown,Mr Hodges,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Millar,Mr O'Keefe and Mr Peacock.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BUNGEY; CAMPBELL; DRUMMOND; MCLEAN; ROCHER; SHACK; VINER
PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5 per cent on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the Budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bungey,Mr Campbell,Mr Drummond,Mr McLean,Mr Rocher,Mr Shack and Mr Viner.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Librarians and library users throughout the nation call for the exemption of books, periodicals and newspapers from the imposition of sales taxes.

The tax exempt status of libraries and schools will not protect them from general cost increases which sales tax and its collection will cause. Indeed, exemption claims on millions of items per year will themselves add to the cost burden of both libraries and suppliers.
This tax is socially injurious and unworkable, and a burden on education, science and culture.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will exempt books and periodicals including newspapers from the proposed sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kerin and Mr Young.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate downgrading or closure of Eildon Post Office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate downgrading or closure of Broadford Vic. 3658 Post Office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by-
downgrading a large number of official post offices
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period
reducing the number of street posting boxes
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lloyd,Mr Milton and Mr Nixon.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CAMERON; FALCONER; LLOYD; MACKENZIE; SCHOLES; VINER
PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with home building, clothing, footwear, books and newspapers, wrapping for food.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax as requested by the Senate to avoid such taxes on necessities of life becoming a further burden on home builders, families and children or inhibiting the free flow of information through books and newspapers or reducing employment opportunities for people in the industries concerned and beyond.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Falconer,Mr Lloyd,Mr MacKenzie,Mr Scholes and Mr Viner.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned by the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with home building, clothing, footwear, books, newspapers and food wrappings, as these sales taxes impose a further burden on home builders, families and children; inhibit the free flow of information through books and newspapers; and reduce employment opportunities in the industries concerned.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should-
Exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax legislation, as requested by the Senate.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned by the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with educational books, clothing, footwear, newspapers, buildings and food wrappings, as these sales taxes impose a further burden on home builders, families and children; inhibit the free flow of information through books and newspapers; and reduce employment opportunities.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should-
Exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax legislation, as requested by the Senate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation and Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We, the people who have signed this petition ask all parties, Labor, Liberal, Democrats and others, to stop the latest increase in taxes and the forever increases in taxes which hit all people of the country of Australia in all goods and consumer goods and we call for a referendum on taxes and interest rates.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cunningham and Mr Howe.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern at the way in which children are now being used in the production of pornography call upon the government to introduce immediate legislation:
1. To prevent the sexual exploitation of children by way of photography for commercial purposes;
2. To penalise parents/guardians who knowingly allow their children to be used in the production of such pornographic or obscene material depicting children;
3. To make specifically illegal the importation, publication, distribution and sale of such pornographic child-abuse material in any form whatsoever such as magazines, novels, papers or films;

4. To take immediate police action to confiscate and destroy all child pornography in Australia and urgent appropriate legal action against all those involved or profiting from this sordid exploitation of children.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will protect all children and immediately prohibit pornographic child-abuse materials, publications or films.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howard and Mr O'Keefe.

PETITION.TITLE: La Boite Theatre, Brisbane
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The decision by the Australia Council to discontinue the General Grant of $20,000 (which is in the nature of recurrent funding) to La Boite Theatre, Brisbane, will jeopardise the continued viability of the theatre, and in particular, the Main House Theatre; Adult Theatre Workshops; Youth Theatre activities and the existence of the professional core of the theatre.
2. The decision has been taken without sufficient consultation and without giving sufficient notice to La Boite Administration.
3. The absence of the Federal Government funding will mean the loss to Brisbane of genuine community-oriented and community-based projects and of the regular presentation of Australian plays.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to cause the Theatre Board's General Grant of $20,000 to La Boite Theatre to be reinstated without delay.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys and Mr Jull.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys and Mr Morris.

PETITION.TITLE: National Roads Construction Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners believe that:
The decision to subject the National Roads Construction program to the tendering system will:
(a) threaten the jobs of 790 workers employed in 17 main road depots in New South Wales.
(b) impair the day labour system and undermine the capacity of Departments of Main Roads to train staff and test road construction concepts
(c) have a disruptive effect on the employment opportunities available in small communities
(d) reduce the flexibility of the Department of Main Roads to handle emergencies caused by flood or fires.
(e) ultimately increase the cost of road construction at Taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government withdraw this disruptive proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys and Mr West.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programmes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Federal Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the recent report of the World Council of Churches team which visited Australia, June 15 to July 3, 1981, emphasises the central importance of land rights to the Aboriginal people.
And noting that all attemps by white Australians to manage Aboriginal affairs for them have failed.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Federal Government will accept its responsibility and use its powers under the Constitution to override racist State legislation, particularly to provide Land Rights with freehold title, and

That in addition the Government fulfil its stated policy of self-determination and self-management for Aboriginal people, by funding all housing, health, education, legal, employment strategy and welfare matters concerning Aboriginal people directly through Aboriginal Community-based Community-controlled organisations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not protecting family home buyers from the severe effects of increased and increasing rates by interest on home mortgage loans.

Your Petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action through tax relief and other measures to avert any further effects of increases in interest rates on home mortgage loans which cause detrimental financial, social and psychological pressures on families, and in many cases, positive hardship.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as 'Australian Soldiers' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Air Force could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who voluntereed in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service; the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the N.H.S and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decrease in Federal Government funding for health, transfer of Commonwealth responsibility to the States, application of the 'user' pay principle to health services and encouragement of private business and profits in the health sphere will inevitably lead to a downgrading of health services and increasing health risks among people who cannot afford health insurance or private payment of doctors and hospitals.

That the cuts in Federal Government spending resulting from the recommendations of the Cabinet Sub-Committee of Review of Government Functions (Razor Gang) will lead to an increase in unemployment and a general deterioration in community services and living standards:
Therefore your petitioners urge that:
1. The Government continue Commonwealth funding of health services at an improved, and certainly not a lesser, level than that operating prior to 1 September 1981.
2. That recommendations of the Cabinet Sub-Committee of Review of Government Functions (Razor Gang) be not proceeded with.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully calls for:
The immediate and unconditional withdrawal of any proposals to deny Unemployment Benefits to unemployed people under 18 years old.
That the level of benefits for all unemployed people, and including people receiving sickness benefits and pensions, be raised to at least 120 per cent of the poverty line.

That future employment policies be devoted to job creation and the restoration of full employment rather than the evasion of this responsibility by hiding the unemployed in short term training and education schemes.
Public acknowledgement of the fact that unemployment is the result of insufficient jobs and not the fault of any minority group, the education system or the unemployed themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retail Trading Hours in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we wish to express our strongest opposition to any deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
That if trading hours are deregulated in the Australian Capital Territory, the present restrictions on trading hours in other parts of Australia may be lifted.

Past performances have proven that longer trading hours do not lead to increased sales. However, they do increase costs, because shops have to be staffed for longer periods. To cover these increased costs, retailers are forced to increase prices and reduce staff levels. This means that longer trading hours increase both prices and unemployment.
1. There is no real consumer demand for longer trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
2. The deregulation of trading hours would force small retail companies out of business.
3. Extended trading hours would gravely disrupt weekend recreation and family life of shop assistants.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should: Ensure that retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory continue to be regulated by Ordinance as happened in the past.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Self-government for the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that;
1. Residents of the Australian Capital Territory are the only Australians who have taxation without representation at State and local government level;

2. Australian Capital Territory residents are amongst the highest per capita income taxpayers in Australia yet do not participate in the Commonwealth Government's tax sharing arrangements with the States and the Northern Territory (including local government grants);
3. Responsibility for raising and spending State-type and municipal taxes and charges should be vested in elected local representatives;

4. It is inappropriate for members of the Federal Parliament to continue to deal with local matters in the Australian Capital Territory-members of the governing body responsible for such matters should live in the Australian Capital Territory and be accountable to the residents of the Australian Capital Territory.
Accordingly, your petitioners call upon their legislators to-

Confer on the Australian Capital Territory State-like self-government established on a sound financial basis which is to be agreed between elected representatives of the Australian Capital Territory and the Commonwealth Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting and Television Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That because television and radio-
(a) affect our social and moral environment,
(b) are family media watched and heard by many children at all times, and
(c) present too much explicit violence and sex.
They therefore need stronger control than other media and the existing standards need stricter enforcement in both national ABC and commercial sectors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will amend the Broadcasting and Television Act, in relation to both national and commercial broadcasters, to legislate-
(a) for adequate and comprehensive programs in the best interests of the general public,
(b) for a ''Dual System of Regulation'' enforced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by internal regulation and external control,
(c) For an independent consumer body to present the best interests of the general public, and
(d) for immediate and effective penalties to be imposed for breaches of program and advertising standards.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Epping North Post Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the Non-Official Post Office at Epping North is under threat of closure and the Postmaster, Mr R. Rowley, has been told by Australia Post that if he retires in order to transfer the office to another person, that the office would be closed. He has also been informed that even if he remains as Postmaster the matter of closure will be reviewed in twelve months' time.

We submit that the office has been serving a community need for many years. The area is in a cul-de-sac so that the residents only alternative would be to travel three kilometres by bus to the nearest Post Office at Epping. At least four schools in the area use the office for banking and the office is not far from the group of small shops used by the community who would be inconvenienced by the loss of postal and banking facilities. There are many pensioners in the area using the Post Office and plans have been approved for a hostel to be built nearby to house 100 aged people who would certainly require an accessible Post Office.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Epping North Post Office be retained and that the office be re-classified as one to remain in the Post Office Network.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Casino in Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra would debase the National Capital and increase crime in Canberra.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should seek to preserve the dignity of the National Capital by disallowing any ordinance to authorise the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:
1. That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the poverty line.
2. That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require:
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and
(b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Budget imposition of additional sales tax to both existing sales taxed items and to previously exempt goods
(a) will add to the regressivity of the tax structure by imposing a similar burden on all sections of the community-regardless of the capacity to pay tax;
(b) will be highly inflationary and a distincentive to economic performance in key sectors of industry

(c) is yet another breach of Government promise, given the Treasurer's undertaking in the Parliament on March 12 of this year that there would be no increases in indirect taxation (without at the same time giving personal tax relief)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to repeal the budget amendments to sales tax legislation and to withdraw its sales tax amendment bills which add sales tax to presently exempt goods as from January 1, 1982.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the interim list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed a further mining lease against the advice of conservationists.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

(a) That residents of densely populated suburbs in the vicinity of the airport and residents of other suburbs in the flight path of international and domestic jets are experiencing an unreasonable degree of aircraft noise.
(b) Further, that these same residents will be subjected to prolonged bouts of such aircraft noise if a decision is taken to extend the curfew at both the domestic and international airports.
(c) That this decision has been foreshadowed on two occasions as follows:

(i) In submissions to the Public Hearing held by the Public Works Committee of this Parliament in regard to Stage One-Redevelopment of Brisbane's International Airport; these submissions proposed an extension of the existing curfew when the new runway is completed (approx. 1986). This proposal received the full support of the Queensland Government.
(ii) TAA's request for an extended curfew to coincide with the introduction of the Airbus.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will refuse to extend the existing curfew and will reconsider its siting plans for the proposed new runway so as to minimise noise pollution over high density suburbs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decision of the Federal Government to discontinue the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) will further reduce the prospects of young Australians for employment, and place additional undue hardship on the unemployed.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government continue the CYSS program and support the voluntary Community Management Committees in their valuable work to assist the unemployed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth: That the serious youth unemployment problem is a direct result of the community's failure to create sufficient jobs.

In these circumstances the decision to abolish Community Youth Support Schemes (CYSS) is a socially retrogressive step. The CYSS Projects provide valuable support services and work training for many unemployed.

We, the undersigned, are concerned that the closure of CYSS Projects may lead young unemployed to become involved in anti-social behaviour such as crime, vandalism, prostitution, rebellious behaviour and mob action. There is the even more frightening prospect that many more young people will give up hope of obtaining a job, become idle and even contemplate suicide.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse its decision to abolish CYSS Projects and provide sufficient funds to enable the various CYSS Centres to continue their valuable work with the young unemployed in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the continual increases in mortgage interest rates in Australia has unduly caused a reduction in the standard of living and this is reflected in the severe difficulty experienced by Australians in meeting household budgetary commitments.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will freeze home loan interest rates and provide income tax rebate on interest paid to home loan finance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Timorese Refugees
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in Australia there are hundreds of Timorese who have been separated from their families. This is a result of the 1975 Civil War and the Indonesian invasion of later that year which displaced and divided many Timorese families. Some came to Australia some went to Portugal and others are still in East Timor. The continued separation of many Timorese families from their relatives in Timor and Portugal is the cause of much anguish and hardship.
Therefore we humbly request that the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia:
(1) to bring from East Timor for family reunion in Australia:
a. the rest of the 600 on the agreed list drawn up between Indonesia and Australia in 1978.
b. the parents of isolated children already in Australia.
c. the rest of the 2,668 nominated in 1977.
(2) to bring from Portugal and elsewhere those Timorese refugees who wish to immigrate to Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Import Ban on Seal Products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the annual slaughter of Canadian Harp Seals, and believe that they should not be massacred in this way. We feel that while the Australian Government allows the import of seal products into this country it is in fact condoning the matter.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately places an import ban on all seal products to aid the abolition of the pitiless Harp Seal slaughter.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation and Pensions
PETITION.PARA: The Right Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Through the Federal Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. B. Hayden, M.H.R., we the undersigned citizens of Australia:

Wish to strongly condemn the great decrease in Federal Government funding to the States and as a result, the serious downturn in employment, hospitalisation, medical care, housing, hospitals, schools, education, student opportunities and in public utilities generally.
This, together with increased interest rates, indirect taxes and rising prices, is causing untold hardship.
We demand of Government that there be an immediate easing of fund restrictions and the imposition of a Resources Tax and Wealth Tax to meet these national needs.

Further, we demand of Government there be an immediate substantial increase in pensions, allowable income above pensions, rise in tax ceiling and extended issue of Health Benefit Cards to the 2,000,000 underprivileged aged, incapacitated and unemployed Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aid to Socially Disadvantaged
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia and parishioners of Christ Church Dingley respectfully showeth-that in view of recent actions of your Government distress is being caused to the socially disadvantaged e.g. senior citizens, young unemployed, dependent mothers. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Government will actively work to aid these people rather than make their burden heavier.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Volunteer Firemen
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

For many years volunteer firemen in the State of New South Wales have given loyal and selfless service, fighting fires and saving life and property, on behalf of the community. In so doing they personally risk their lives and deprive themselves of precious relaxation time.
The voluntee firemen believe that they are serving in the interests of their country in a similar way to the members of the Citizens Military Forces.
For this reason they are most critical for having to pay Income Tax on income derived from such services which they render to the New South Wales Fire Brigades.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will take immediate steps to: Grant volunteer firemen in the State of New South Wales serving in the New South Wales Fire Brigades, tax exemption on earnings of volunteer firemen in a similar basis to that granted to the members of the Citizens Military Forces in accordance with the Income Tax Assessment Act, 1936-1970, Part iii, Division 1, Section 23.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The proposed increase in sales tax on the white goods and shelf goods industry, if implemented, would have a devastating effect on employment in South Australia.
The white goods industry in South Australia is one of the largest industries the economy of this State relies on.
Any increase in sales tax would depress the industry further and throw thousands of workers out of work, also dependent companies would go out of business.
We therefore call upon your Government not to increase sales tax in this industry for the good of the workers employed and the economy in South Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to increase sales tax on white goods and shelf goods.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of childrens services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 Budget. And further, that annual Budget allocations in the area of childrens services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other business expenses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned, condemn the thrust of the recommendations of the Lynch Razor Committee. In particular we condemn the implementation of the 'user pays' dogma in education, health and welfare, which are treated like commodities and denied to those who cannot pay.
We condemn:

1. the proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees.-Access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the introduction of fees for all tertiary students;

2. the proposed introduction of a loans scheme-to students this will mean graduating with a heavy debt burden or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a 'poor risk' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness;

3. the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans-any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education;

4. the proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment-this will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early;

5. the proposal not to fund 30 colleges of advanced education if they are not rationalised-this attack, aimed at teacher education, will create a teacher shortage in the mid 1980's and restrict access to education now.
We, the undersigned, call upon the government to reject these proposals!
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, Federal Parliament, Canberra. The humble petition of the undersigned residents of Salisbury in the State of South Australia.

Petition that: Competition between banks and finance companies by giving ever increasing interest rates to obtain the investors' capital, is against the nation's best interest. It penetrates every form of activity by constant demands for higher wages to meet these explosive conditions.

It is an intolerable burden to the younger generation of family life, that by necessity are the recipients of these excessive interest rates that are catastrophic to house purchase and natural living. We therefore respectfully petition for an urgent annual realistic controlled reduction right ''across the board'' on all existing and future interest rate agreements. With a maximum interest percentage ceiling on investors' capital, and a scale of interest charges for loans as appropriate.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will give effect to our submissions.

PETITION.TITLE: Income Tax Zone Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of the eastern goldfields in the State of Western Australia respectfully petition:
That the Government reverse its zone allowance policy as outlined in the recent Budget and:
(i) Abandon its attempt to exclude residents of large country towns from receiving zone allowance benefits.
(ii) Substantially increase the income tax rebate from the proposed $36 plus 20% of the dependent allowance for Zone B residents and $216 plus 50% of the dependent allowance for Zone A residents.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives take steps to ensure that Government policy on income tax zone allowances as outlined in the Budget is substantially amended.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives as in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:
That your Petitioners are aware that the proposed Sales Tax is only one aspect of a Budget needed to support the growth and development of our Country.
And that every Australian, whether rich or poor must aid this aim.
But that the social conscience of a country must be judged by the way in which it responds to the needs of its poorest, most helpless citizens.
And that this latest imposition will be responsible for Australia being judged not only by its own people but by the rest of the world.

We, the citizens of Queensland most humbly pray that: In the cause of justice and equity, your Honourable Members will reject any attempt to impose a Sales Tax on all essential goods including packaging of foods, shoes, clothing, literature and building materials.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your petitioners resident in the Tasmanian North-West Coast and West Coast municipalities of Circular Head, Wynyard, Burnie, Penguin, Waratah, Zeehan, Strahan, Queenstown and Gormanston are desirous of retaining first class air service through the major airport serving the area, namely the Wynyard airport.

Since the Government has agreed to provide $5.5 million for Devonport which serves a smaller population and area, we ask the Government as a matter of urgency to also provide sufficient funds to upgrade Wynyard airport to the standard required for it to accommodate medium size jet aircraft.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled will give urgent consideration to this request.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of citizens of the Geelong region in the State of Victoria respectfully request the Federal Parliament not to accept the IAC recommendations on the motor vehicle industry as they would, if accepted, have a disastrous economic effect on the region and would create massive unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) expresses its appreciation to the volunteer firemen of New South Wales for the valuable public life saving and property protection services they perform;

(2) notes the petition from 3,700 citizens of New South Wales presented by the member for Shortland on 17 November 1981 requesting that tax exemption be granted in respect of payments made to volunteer firemen as members of the New South Wales Volunteer Fire Brigade; and
(3) is of the opinion that the Federal Government should urgently amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to meet the terms of the petition.
The motion will be seconded by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House affirms its opposition to apartheid and welcomes the decision of 83.4 per cent of the residents of Constantia, a suburb of Cape Town, who voted in a recent poll to open their own area to all races.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) notes the Government's failure to debate general business notices of motion No. 81, in the name of the member for Melbourne Ports and given on 25 November 1980, and No. 103, also in my name and given on 10 June 1981;
(2) further notes with concern that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has been advised to expect an increasing number of suicides by Vietnam veterans during the forthcoming summer months;

(3) recognises that the Vietnam veterans have been calling for a judicial inquiry into the use of chemicals in Vietnam for at least 2 years, and that such an inquiry is supported by the Senate and 27 ex-service organisations; and

(4) therefore calls on the Prime Minister to accept his personal responsibility for Australia's military operations in Vietnam as stated by him in this House on 9 March 1971, and announce immediately the establishment of the judicial inquiry which Vietnam veterans have been seeking so that justice will be, and be seen to be, done without any further delay.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROFESSIONAL RADIO AND ELECTRONICS INSTITUTE OF AUSTRALASIA: INDUSTRIAL DISPUTE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the report dated 21 October 1981 by Commissioner Vosti to the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission dealing with the industrial dispute involving members of the Professional Radio and Electronics Institute of Australasia employed by the Department of Transport on the maintenance of radar facilities. Will the Minister comment upon the findings by Commissioner Vosti condemning the Public Service Board for, amongst other things, 'constant harassment of the PREIA advocate whilst putting the Institute case' and 'displaying a lack of industrial integrity'? The commissioner's finding states:

QUESTION.PARA: If the tactics adopted in this inquiry are a true reflection of the standard of industrial relations and integrity established by the Board in its handling on industrial relations generally then it leads me to the conclusion that those necessary ingredients for successful employer, union relationships are almost non-existent at Board level or, to put it more charitably, are at a very low ebb.

Will the Minister also comment on that finding? Finally, I ask the Minister: In view of this totally damning indictment of the Public Service Board by an independent member of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, what steps does the Government intend to take on its side as the employer to create these necessary ingredients for successful employer/union relationships in the Commonwealth Public Service? Will it now cease its persistent attempts to apportion blame solely to the trade unions for problems in that important area?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will investigate the matter to which the honourable gentleman refers and give him a reply as appropriate.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer and relates to the Treasurer's statement of 8 November that a survey of major lending authorities indicated that they had not foreclosed any mortgages and taken possession of any homes as a result of interest rate increases. I ask: Does the Treasurer accept that this kind of survey result does not adequately or even partially reflect the difficulties currently faced by home buyers? Is the Treasurer aware of the time lag between interest rate increases and mortgage foreclosures as home buyers undertake a wide range of financial arrangements and sacrifices to maintain their capacity to meet increased mortgage repayments? Can the Treasurer assure the House that, notwithstanding the comments made in his statement, he is aware of the difficulties presently being experienced by home buyers as a result of high interest rates? Can he assure the House that the Government is aware of, and is prepared to take action to alleviate, the increasing difficulties now confronting present and prospective home buyers?

—The short answer to the honourable gentleman's question is yes. I inform the House that I made those statements in the context of some fairly ill-informed remarks by the Victorian Minister of Housing, who sought to suggest that the Commonwealth Government was totally responsible for the problems being experienced by Australian home owners at present and that all that was needed to solve the problems was the injection of a few hundred million dollars more by the Commonwealth Government. The fact of the matter is that State and local governments are at least as responsible as, if not more responsible than, the Commonwealth Government for the cost of housing and land in Australia. In fact, all the information which comes to me indicates that by far the most disabling factor for potential home buyers in recent years has not been increases in interest rates but rather increases in the price of a house and land throughout Australia, particularly in the metropolitan area of Sydney where, because of the very rapid escalation in prices in that city, particular problems have been created for home buyers in that part of Australia. That information indicates that, except in relation to people who have very recently taken out loans, the great majority of people now paying off their homes would be paying less, as a proportion of their weekly earnings, notwithstanding the interest rate increases, than they would have been paying, say, back in 1978. That is because of the fairly obvious fact that, although interest rates have gone up since 1978, in the generality of cases wages have gone up at a faster rate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that under the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act the Queensland Government will be able to issue oil drilling licences in the 70 per cent of the 3-mile territorial sea in the Great Barrier Reef region where the Cairns section has not been declared? Why did the Prime Minister not declare the whole Cairns section to the low water mark instead of just 30 per cent? Does the Prime Minister still believe that current research may show that drilling may be possible on or near the reef in future? Finally, I ask whether the Queensland Premier was correct when he stated this morning:

QUESTION.PARA: We will run the whole thing. We--
That is, the Queensland Government-
will make the zones, the regulations and neutralise the Commonwealth proposals. We will write the rules, we can write them all ourselves.

Will the Queensland Government, as stated by the Premier this morning on AM and in the media, be in a position to impose its own regulations and zoning plans involving yet another Commonwealth capitulation to the belligerent Queensland Premier?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not at all sure that the honourable gentleman has interpreted correctly what was said this morning, but in any case I had not heard it. The basis of the proposal, the understanding, that had been worked out between my colleague and Mr Ahern, the Queensland Minister, was the advice of the Great Barrier Marine Park Authority so that the ecologically sensitive areas that impinge on the coastline would be protected. Tomorrow we expect to get the formal advice in terms of the Act from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, and proclamations will proceed on the next day, Thursday. So the boundary is based on the advice of the Authority, which is charged with that responsibility and which is in the best position to make proper judgments in relation to it. The protections for the reef come not only from the declaration of marine parks but also from the overriding power and authority of the Commonwealth-from the Commonwealth Act, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act. That is something that we need to understand and remember. A Commonwealth Act provides the backdrop to our total capacity to protect the reef, and in any circumstances in which its use is necessary it will be used.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it would be a good thing to understand precisely what has been agreed. The understandings between my colleague and Mr Ahern are basically those that were put to the Premier last Friday, which he was unwilling to accept then and which I understand he is now willing to accept, although I have not heard that from him. I understand that the Queensland Government has accepted the propositions which were put to the Premier last Friday and which at that time, as honourable gentlemen probably understand, were not accepted in full by the Premier.

Once the proclamations have been made on Thursday a number of steps need to be undertaken by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. It will call for submissions for a management plan. Those submissions can be made by a great variety of people-by conservationists, by people who are interested in undertaking activities such as tourism, fishing, or whatever else they might be. Then it is for the Authority to develop and publish a draft plan which will be the subject of further comment. That comment can come from any party, including the Queensland Government or the Commonwealth Government or people in Queensland who might be in the conservationist arena or the commercial arena. Once there has been further comment as a result of the initial draft plan, the Authority will submit a plan to the Minister, together with representations that have been made to the Authority. The Minister can either accept the plan or refer it back with his own suggestions.

Once the Minister accepts the zoning plan, which obviously will have gone through a number of stages involving public comment but which basically will have been in the hands of the Authority to determine-that is the important point for this House to consider-the plan will then be put to both Houses of this Parliament and within 20 days either House may reject the plan. So there is ultimately a parliamentary process which the zoning plan also has to pass. In all of this the public can be involved, the State Government can be involved, and the Commonwealth Government is involved, but it is the powers of this Parliament under the Acts of this Parliament that ultimately provide our total capacity to do what needs to be done.

These are the procedures that were worked out in relation to the Capricornia Section of the park. The procedures in relation to the Cairns Section are similar except in one respect and, again, this was part of the Ahern-Wilson understanding. When the regulations are made through the processes I have outlined-managed by the Authority, determined by the Authority, recommended to the Minister, and all the rest of it-if in relation to the 5-kilometre limit, where it comes into the coastline, the Queensland Parliament wants to pass some complementary legislation applying precisely what has been agreed through the processes I have outlined, of course it can do so to put a back-up to the processes. That is the only difference between this section and the Capricornia Section, which did not come into the 5-kilometre limit. However, at that point no changes to what had been agreed would be accepted by the Commonwealth in any sense, shape or form. That needs to be understood.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what he said.

—I am just telling the House what the position is, what the position was last Friday, what the position was when the Minister was negotiating an understanding with Mr Ahern, and what the position was last Thursday, as stated by the Deputy Prime Minister and me. If Queensland wants to pass some legislation in that area to back up the five kilometres it may do so, and we would welcome that. Obviously we hope that there will be co-operative arrangements so that it is the Queensland ranger service and all the rest that apply the rules and regulations of the park. There is really no point in the Commonwealth being forced to establish a separate service to do that. Again, it is the Authority that would have the overall responsibility of reporting to this Government and of making sure that any zoning plan had been properly complied with. If it were not, something would have to be done about it. That is the position. I think it would be useful for honourable members if I could have leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the joint statement by the Deputy Prime Minister and myself of last Thursday, 12 November.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
For Media Thursday, 12 November 1981
JOINT STATEMENT BY PRIME MINISTER AND DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER
Cairns Section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park

The Great Barrier Reef is one of the wonders of the world. It is a focus of national pride, and all Australians treasure it. There is deep concern in the community for the welfare of the reef, and a universal conviction that proper care of the reef is a priority responsibility of governments.

Since 1975, the whole of the reef has been protected by the Commonwealth Government under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act. Australia is indeed a world leader in conservation management of the marine environment. The policy of the Commonwealth Government is to proclaim the various sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park progressively. The Capricornia section was proclaimed in 1979.

The Cairns section has been the subject of negotiation for more than 12 months, the one outstanding issue being whether the western boundary should be the low water mark on the mainland or a line some distance off the coast.
The view of the Commonwealth Government is that the low water mark on the Queensland coast must form the boundary where features of ecological significance are involved.

The Commonwealth Parliament has full jurisdiction and responsibility right up to the low water mark. The Commonwealth Government was willing to allow discussions with the Queensland Government to be extended to a very considerable length in the interests of achieving co-operation and agreement. But despite the length of the discussions, agreement has not been reached.
Accordingly, the Commonwealth Government has decided to move at once towards proclamation, and the enabling action leading to the proclamation of the Cairns section will be started immediately.

The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment will immediately request the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to identify precisely the boundaries involved and report to him on its recommendations to allow him to recommend to the Governor-General that the area be proclaimed.
The total length of the Western Boundary will be some 550 kilometres, and for about 30% of this distance the boundary will be the low water mark on the coastline.

Among the ecological features included, will be the sea grass beds north of Cape Flattery, which are an important habitat for dugong-an internationally recognised endangered species; high quality reefs fringing the mainland and islands; and marine areas adjacent to Queensland-proclaimed national parks which extend down to the shoreline.

The Cairns section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park will be some 36,000 square kilometres. When this is added to the 12,000 square kilometres in the Capricornia section, the park will then be many times larger than any existing or proposed marine park anywhere in the world.

The Marine Park concept and the way it is being implemented will ensure the conservation of the Reef ecosystem. It is the Government's policy that regulation should be the minimum necessary to conserve the Reef. As with the Capricornia section, there will be perfectly satisfactory provision for recreation, shipping, tourism, commercial and amateur fishing and other activities. The Park boundaries will exclude port and other marine areas adjacent to intensive industrial or agricultural developments on land, unless conservational reasons dictate otherwise.

The selection of the boundaries of the Cairns Section of the Marine Park has been made only after the most careful consideration of alternatives by the Government and by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

The eastern boundary of the new Cairns section will follow the eastern boundary of the Great Barrier Reef Region itself. In the south, the boundary will be a line commencing at low water mark and coincident for most of its length with the line adopted for State purposes between the Cardwell and Johnstone Shires and thence passing immediately south of Taylor Reef to the eastern boundary of the Regions. In the north, the boundary will be a straight line commencing at low water mark on the mainland at 14 degrees 40 minutes south and passing through Two Mile Opening to the eastern boundary of the Region. Lizard Island is within the new Section of the Marine Park.

Once the Cairns Section is formally proclaimed, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is required under the Act to develop a zoning plan for the Section and, in this context, will be seeking public submissions. All submissions which the Authority receives will be examined carefully and will be taken into account in preparing a draft Zoning Plan. The draft plan will then be published so that members of the public are aware of the detailed nature of the Authority's proposals and are able to comment on them. The draft Zoning Plan will be open for comment for at least one month.

I regret that the Queensland Government has not come in with us on the western boundary of the Cairns Section. But I believe there is support throughout the whole of Australia for the course of action being followed. I hope that now a decision has been made, co-operation between the two Governments in Park matters will proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction, concerns works associated with the construction of Brisbane's new international airport and terminal. Is the Minister aware of complaints of flooding from Nudgee residents living in the vicinity of the recently constructed Schultz Canal? Have new works in the area caused ponding of areas which would increase mosquito breeding? Have recent heavy rains and flood run-off caused erosion of the banks of the Schultz Canal? If so, what action is proposed to rectify the damage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of concern expressed some months ago by people who live in the general area of Nudgee beach. But, following the fall last week of 330 millimetres of rain-the sort of fall which can cause considerable flooding in areas of Brisbane-those fears have been largely allayed. A fall of that order 12 months ago caused a flood of 1 1/2 metres in the Brisbane Airport area. Last week, because of the protective works undertaken, there was no such flooding. It is now reliably estimated by engineers from Commonwealth and State government departments that the present works will withstand a flood six times larger than that of last week. To indicate to the honourable member for Petrie the severity of a flood of that order, the floods in Brisbane in 1974 were only five times larger than the flood of last week. The honourable member has drawn to my attention what could cause a problem with regard to mosquito breeding. I assure him that the Department will continue to monitor that so that any inconvenience will be limited.

ANSWER.PARA: In reply to the last part of the question, I advise the honourable member that, following representations made by him earlier in the year, the length of the rock wall was increased by 110 metres to 260 metres. That has withstood all the problems in the flooding last week, and Nudgee Road was not flooded. Another protective measure which it was fortunate we adopted was the erection of a man-proof fence around the lower reaches of Schultz Canal, because people were using the banks for fishing purposes and were not allowing the mangroves to be established to stabilise the banks. All in all, last week was a good test and the honourable member can assure the residents about whom he is concerned that the proposals adopted and the plans and procedures carried out can allay any fears that they may have had six months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment recommend that the urgent request by the Confederation of Australian Professional Performing Arts for a supplementary grant of $1.18m to the Australia Council be met in order to alleviate the crisis facing the performing arts? If the Minister does not propose to support this request, what steps is he prepared to take to restore funding to the Australia Council at a level that will allow it to maintain all artistically viable companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amount of funds allocated by the Government for the arts, in particular that section of the development of the arts dealt with by the Australia Council, is determined at the time of the Budget. The amount provided to the Australia Council is provided to it on the basis that, except in the case of the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and the Elizabethan Theatre Trust, it is in the hands of the Australia Council to determine how it will divide its funds between, firstly, administration and, secondly, general support for the arts. Having made that determination, it is a matter then for the Australia Council to determine distribution between its boards and the allocation within each of its boards to provide assistance and encouragement to artistic endeavour in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be pointed out, however, that the Commonwealth Government is not the only sphere of government that has some significant responsibility for providing support to the arts. It is a matter also for State and local governments, the corporate sector and individuals. The Australia Council allocated the resources available to theatres and performing arts companies so as to give them encouragement by way of a reward for expanding the resources available to them. It was a matter for the Australia Council to determine whether it simply cut the amounts across the board in respect of an increased number of performing arts companies or whether it adopted a different approach so as to help others who should have and do have an interest in the development of our performing arts.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the proposed national inquiry into the wage fixing system, foreshadowed back in May. Will the Minister indicate what progress has been made to date and, in particular, when the membership and the final terms of reference will be announced?

—I can inform the honourable gentleman that this matter is now before the Government and I expect a decision to be taken by the Government shortly. I will then be in a position to announce the membership, form and composition of the inquiry.

—I refer the Prime Minister to his statements of last Sunday concerning the possibility of a double dissolution. Is the Prime Minister aware of the dicta of Sir Garfield Barwick in Western Australia v. The Commonwealth in 1975 where he said that double dissolution Bills may not be stockpiled or laid aside until a later date which might be more suitable for an election? Is the honourable gentleman also aware of advice given by Mr Menzies and earlier by Sir Samuel Griffith that the Governor-General is not bound to follow the advice of the Prime Minister in relation to section 57 of the Constitution? I therefore ask: Will the Prime Minister advise the Governor-General that he has an independent discretion in relation to section 57 and, in view of the comments of Sir Garfield Barwick, will he advise a double dissolution at the earliest opportunity?

—I thank the honourable gentleman for his legal advice. I am glad to see that he now recognises and concedes on behalf of the Australian Labor Party that in certain dire and extreme circumstances the Governor-General has an independent discretion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources. Can the Minister advise the House of the current state of uranium exports from Australia?

QUESTION.PARA: The honourable member continuing to ask his question-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The first part of the question is in order; the second part is not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —Some members of the public, and of the Opposition, are trying to give the impression that there is not a future in the Australian uranium industry. It might be interesting to know that, since the Prime Minister announced that the Australian Government would permit the development and export of uranium, 102 shipments have been made out of this country, consisting of 6,000 tonnes of uranium which has come from the Mary Kathleen mine in Queensland, the Nabarlek mine in the Northern Territory and the stockpile which was owned by the Commonwealth. Since 1977, 10 new contracts have been entered into entailing 46,000 short tons of uranium which will be delivered between 1982 and 1996. This is a considerable amount of uranium--
—Yellowcake.
—Uranium oxide, or U3O5, if the honourable member likes.
—It is U3O8. I am standing in for Barry Jones while he is away.

—I am sorry, U3O8. I hope the honourable member is a bit wiser than the honourable member for Lalor. This is a very considerable amount of uranium and it guarantees the future of mines around Australia and the jobs of many people. Certainly those unions involved in this development support it conclusively. There seems to be some difference of opinion within the Australian Labor Party or at least members have differences of opinion in different parts of Australia. I will quote what the Leader of the Opposition said to the Australian Broadcasting Commission when he was in the Northern Territory last Tuesday. He said:
