ANSWER.PARA: We have never sought to encourage the trade unions to apply industrial prohibition, industrial action, and we still don't. We don't endorse any such action.

Of course, he knows that in the Northern Territory the Labor Party's uranium policy is an absolute disaster. With a by-election coming up in the Northern Territory he had different words to say from the words he uses in this House. But we all know that the development of uranium is very important for the world's energy needs. Certainly, it is a very significant part of Australia's future development. This Government supports it and will see that it succeeds.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence: In view of the fact that the Government has announced that it has added the Invincible class aircraft carrier to the list of options available in considering a replacement for the HMAS Melbourne and also that it will be examining the purchase of two minesweepers from the United Kingdom, is he able to indicate whether, as part of that consideration, the Government has agreed or has been asked to agree to set aside the normal Australian industry participation program which, in the case of these three items of defence equipment, could exceed $100m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is completely correct, as my friend says, that the Government has under consideration an aircraft carrier of the Invincible class and two minesweepers. But I point out to the honourable gentleman and to the House that no decision on this matter has been made. I am bound to say that, looking at the matter prospectively, if a decision were made there would be substance in my honourable friend's contention that the Government's normal search for some 30 per cent Australian industry participation would be put in jeopardy. I think it is propitious to take this opportunity to point out to the House the absolutely lamentable state of Australian shipbuilding in Navy yards today. I have expressed to my honourable friend the honourable member for Melbourne my utmost concern regarding industrial conditions in the Williamstown yard. It is my earnest hope that the Australian Council of Trade Unions will seek to co-operate with the Government to ensure that some reasonableness and sanity can be restored to that yard.

ANSWER.PARA: I will indulge myself to this extent, and say that no matter which kidney of government might be in office it would be absolutely impossible to build any follow-on destroyers in that yard while the present conditions obtained. I believe that at the end of the day reason must govern our individual and corporate existences. I hope that the unions represented in that yard will see the difficulties that are posed by their present behaviour. I hope that they will respond to the very earnest beckoning made to them by appropriate officers of the ACTU and seek to co-operate with the government of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport to recent announcements by the Government concerning the construction of international terminal facilities at Adelaide and Hobart airports. Do these approvals mean that construction of an international terminal at Perth will be delayed? If so, what is the length of the deferment? If not, does the scheduled completion date of 1985 for an international terminal at Perth Airport still apply?

—The decision by the Government to construct an international terminal, apron and taxiways to facilitate international flights from Adelaide by October 1982 and its proposal to upgrade the terminal facilities at Hobart will not in any way affect the scheduling arrangements for the Perth Airport. At present, as the honourable gentleman would know, we are developing a planning strategy for Perth Airport. I expect that to be completed by early next year. I know that the honourable member for Canning and the honourable member for Tangney have requested such a requirement for the Perth Airport. The completion date will, of course, be largely dependent on the outcome of that strategy. There is no intention at this stage to alter the program and the proposal in respect of Perth announced early in the year. But we want to be sure that we place the air traffic control tower and the international terminal in a place that will take into account long term requirements at Perth Airport and also meet the community requirements in respect of air traffic noise and so on.

—I ask the Prime Minister: Why will his Government not declare all of the Cairns section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park extending to the low water mark? Will the Queensland Government still be able to issue oil drilling licences inside the 70 per cent of the territorial sea to remain under Queensland State control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said on many occasions, and in fact the Queensland Government has also said it on a number of occasions, that we will not allow oil drilling in or around the region of the reef. I have already indicated that that 70 per cent would still be protected under the Acts of this Parliament. If we believed that anything was going to happen that could damage any part of the reef those Acts would give us power and authority to act and, if it were necessary, we would do so.

ANSWER.PARA: I was also asked why we did not declare the whole section in to the low water mark. In fact I answered that in reply to an earlier question. The boundaries are based on the advice, which is informal up to this point, from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Its formal advice will be coming to us on Wednesday, which will mean that the appropriate proclamations can be made on Thursday.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I address to the Minister for Defence, is in part supplementary to the earlier question asked of him about industrial strife at Williamstown. As a member of the Government members defence and foreign affairs committee I was invited to travel on HMAS Parramatta from Melbourne to Sydney in the last couple of days. The refit of HMAS Parramatta, which I think was commissioned in about 1960--
—Is this a question?
—I am not giving information; I am asking a question.
—The honourable member might rephrase his question so that he seeks information.

—I am seeking information. Is the Minister aware that when HMAS Parramatta went in for a two-year refit in 1976 the refit ultimately took 4 1/2 years at a cost to the Australian taxpayer of $35m to $36m and that the reason for this--
—The honourable gentleman must ask his question or I will have to rule him out of order.
—I am asking: Is the Minister aware that the reason for this extra time and extra cost to the taxpayer was industrial trouble at Williamstown?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The information given by the honourable gentleman would, on reflection, appear to be substantially correct. The refit took far, far longer than was anticipated. May I correct the impression that all the fault at Williamstown rests with the trade unions.
—You are giving it.
—I am very sorry if I did. I am seeking to make amends. Some time ago a very distinguished relative of the present honourable member for Wills--
—The same name; no relation.

—Well, I thought I was favouring the honourable member. That person was commissioned to inquire into the state of affairs at Williamstown dockyard. He has produced a report. It is a very detailed report. The Government has it under consideration.
—Can one have access to a copy?

—I say to my honourable friend that I was asked this question by a member of the Press gallery at a Press conference some time ago. I said that I would be prepared to consider it. A great deal of the information was given on a commercial, in-confidence basis. As a consequence of that it cannot be made available publicly. I unhesitatingly say to the Leader of the Opposition that I will place a copy in his hands knowing that he will respect the oath he took as a member of the Executive Council. The report does light up this simple but nevertheless daunting state of affairs: Unless reason is brought back into the conduct of all the yard's operations, it will simply not be possible for follow-on destroyers to be built and for refits to be carried out at the Williamstown dockyard. I want to make that point.

ANSWER.PARA: I stated to the House some time ago that I met the members of the shipbuilding committee of the Australian Council of Trade Unions.They argued their case in a robust and cogent way. I took no exception to that at all. They acknowledged the difficulties that are there. Recently the Department of Defence had occasion to vet, and I do not use the term in any offensive sense, some of the people applying for work at the yard. I have discussed the matter with a number of honourable gentlemen on both sides of the House. I do not seek to be sententious about any persons who have transgressed against society. Indeed, in the past I have sought to lend some encouragement to rehabilitate them in society. Nevertheless, the Department of Defence and the Royal Australian Navy have a responsibility to ensure that the best possible quality of labour is available. Running in tandem with that, the Department of Defence, the Government and the Minister of the day, have an obligation to ensure that the best quality of management is available. That remains the search of the present Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. It refers to Australia's role in the proposed Sinai multinational military monitoring force. Can the Prime Minister inform the House how far the accumulation of weapons has proceeded among Israeli settlers in the Sinai and especially in the Rafah salient who are preparing to resist by force Israel's withdrawal next April as provided for in the Camp David Accords? Can he also tell the House how far advanced is the systematic takeover by these settlers of areas left vacant in the Sinai by people who have returned to Israel in advance of the withdrawal next April? Does this resistance affect in any way the understanding that Australia's participation in the peacekeeping force be conditional on all parties to the Accords adhering to them 'by word and deed', to use the words of the Prime Minister of 22 October in this House? Finally, if this resistance is not considered to be an infringement of the Accords, is it intended that Australian troops be involved in removing or dealing with those settlers who resist withdrawal by force of arms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, that would not be part of the responsibilities of the multinational force. What was said in relation to that force obviously applies to commitments by the governments of Egypt, Israel and the United States. I have no reason to believe that those governments are not strongly in support of the maintenance of the Camp David Accords and the withdrawal processes in a proper time and a proper manner. I have no reason to believe that the Israeli Government will not fulfil its part of the bargain in relation to its own people and its own personnel. I can advise the House of nothing else in relation to these particular matters at the moment except that from reading the newspapers honourable gentlemen will well understand that various negotiations are proceeding which could well involve a number of other countries making public statements about participation in the force.

ANSWER.PARA: One thing in an overriding way which has altered the views of many people in many different places is that since President Sadat's assassination people have suddenly been confronted with the fact that, even though there have been many proposals for peace in the Middle East, the Camp David peace process is the only one that has achieved anything. If that, therefore, is thrown out the window by lack of support in ways in which that support is needed and necessary and capable of being provided, then the only peace process that has achieved anything at all in the Middle East will have been abandoned. I think many countries have come to the view that it would be a major tragedy if that occurred. That is why there has been the obvious reassessment and, indeed, the bringing forward of any decision by Australia before there was a fully balanced force. We hoped that our decision would assist in achieving a proper balance in that force because that, of course, is necessary to give it its fully multinational character. I think the fact that many countries are reassessing their positions in relation to that and the fact that the Australian decision may have had some part, however small, in helping to bring that about, is an indication of the way in which a decision by a government in a country such as Australia can help in a peace process.

Let me emphasise again that this is an observing force and a monitoring force. It is not a fighting force and it is not an enforcing force. It is a monitoring and observing force. Of course, if fighting were to break out or if any of the parties were not to fulfil their obligations under the Camp David process, then the whole matter would have broken down. I hope that within the next week or two some of the countries may have got into a position in which they can make decisions and reinforce what has already occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware that a new high yielding variety of wheat called Roseworthy College 311, of great importance to the South Australian wheat growing environment, has been developed and that this variety has been refused registration by Queensland and Western Australia? Is he aware that the South Australian Wheat Quality Advisory Committee, composed of bakers, researchers, breeders, growers and bulk handling authorities has passed this wheat, after extensive testing? Will he make sure, in an attempt to resolve this difficulty, that the matter can be listed for discussion by the Australian Agricultural Council at some subsequent meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say that in the agricultural community at large there is a deal of prejudice against the use of crossbreeds or hybrids, whether it be in the grain section, in animal breeding, of whatever. That just happens to be a fact of life. I cannot say specifically whether RAC 311 has run into this particular prejudice. I will see what information is available on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that a great deal of work has been put into this particular breed of wheat by the authorities mentioned by the honourable member. I realise that it has the full support of all those members throughout South Australia. I am not sure whether I can have the matter listed for discussion at a meeting of the Agricultural Council; I will need to check that. If it is possible to do so and if some gains can be made out of that, I will certainly do so and let the honourable member know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of the eight-point peace plan proposed by Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia which clearly entails the recognition of the right of Israel to exist? Is he aware of reports that Yasser Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organisation, recently described Prince Fahd's proposal as a positive step and a very important platform for a solution of Middle East problems? Can he describe to the House contacts that have been maintained for some time at a high official level between the Australian Government and the PLO and inform the House of how productive these official contacts have been, especially whether they have been able to enlarge on this new and apparently encouraging development and the publicly declared attitude of the PLO towards the state of Israel?

—If, out of those proposals, the PLO is prepared to drop the plank in its policy which involves the destruction of the state of Israel, it is within its power to make that fully and plainly known and understood in the Middle East and around the world. It would be a very positive step towards peace if it were prepared to do so. At this stage, I am not aware that it has been prepared to do so. Obviously, a number of people are aware of those other proposals. I make the point that the only proposals that have succeeded in achieving anything in the Middle East are the Camp David Accords and the peace process that has flowed from that. If any honourable member wants to run the risk of jeopardising those proposals when they are the only ones that have advanced anything whatsover, he runs the risk of jeopardising peace in the Middle East for many years to come.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industry reconcile the low cattle prices and the decreasing population and yardings with the shortage of meat that is often complained about by housewives endeavouring to purchase meat supplies? Is the Minister satisfied that the present sales arrangements offer a satisfactory return to the producer and provide adequate supplies, economically priced, to the Australian consumer?

—There has been a significant drop in the number of cattle available for slaughter over the past two or three years for a variety of reasons. Cattle numbers have fallen from 33 million head to about 24 million head. As a result, the volume of beef produced has declined significantly. I am not aware of any complaints from housewives that they are unable to purchase beef. Indeed, I thought the contrary position obtained. There are still significant volumes of beef available for the export market. I cannot say that the matter has been brought to my attention in any way at all. Despite the fall off in the numbers available for meat production, the fact is that the price of beef is very soft. I think this can be attributed mainly to the problems of the United States of America with its depressed economy, oversupply of white meat-chicken and pork-and low beef prices. That reflects very much on the international scene. It reflects finally on the saleyard price paid for Australian beef. The last part of the honourable member's question raised queries as to the method of sale and the return to the producer. Studies on carcass classification are still in train. I know that a great deal of the producing sector of the industry hopes that it will advance the situation in terms of the sale price ultimately achieved by the producer. No final decision has been made on that yet. That still lies in the future. The producer is dependent upon supply and demand. That situation has existed in the industry for generations. I am unable to make any comment at this point on when work will be completed on carcass classification or even on the impact that that will have on the market place. I hope that it will be completed soon and that it will have some impact.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW REFORM COMMISSION REPORT: CHILD WELFARE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 37 of the Law Reform Commission Act 1973, I present the Law Reform Commission report on child welfare, together with the text of a statement by the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Government is grateful for the comprehensive report of the Law Reform Commission which recommends changes in virtually all aspects of child welfare in the Australian Capital Territory and in the procedures of the ACT Children's Court and the Australian Federal Police. These matters are within the province of my colleagues, the Ministers for Administrative Services, Health and the Capital Territory as well as the Attorney-General.

On 15 May 1980 in response to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, the Attorney-General informed honourable senators that, when tabling a report of the Law Reform Commission, the Government would indicate the arrangements for handling the Government's consideration of the report. He also mentioned that reports of the Commission require close and careful consideration before they can be implemented.

Careful study is clearly required in respect of this report on child welfare. My colleagues will be arranging for relevant officers to consider the report in detail. In addition, views will be sought from the ACT Children's Advisory Committee. As child welfare is a State responsibility relevant State Departments will also be consulted as will be the ACT House of Assembly and organisations concerned with child welfare in the Territory. In due course there may be a need for further discussions to be arranged with the Law Reform Commission.

Following those considerations of the report, my colleague the Minister for the Capital Territory expects to present options to the Government for child welfare legislation in the Australian Capital Territory.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW REFORM COMMISSION REPORT: CHILD WELFARE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to take this opportunity to make a brief statement on the report on Child Welfare as it is an issue of great concern to the people of Canberra. I think it highlights the difficult problems we have in the Australian Capital Territory of getting changes to ordinances which in fact are antiquated. The particular child welfare ordinances was described as: 'Confused both in concept and language and reflects values and attitudes of times gone by'. This ordinance has been investigated now for a period of three years. When I was a member of the Legislative Assembly I can remember that we investigated that matter for two years, brought down recommendations, but were then told that this would be investigated by the Law Reform Commission. It is an issue of great concern to the people of Canberra because it deals with social issues such as child abuse, what we do with children in need of care, care proceedings, how we treat juveniles, and what sorts of conditions we lay down for child care. It is an important issue that needs to be discussed by this community. I hope it will be fully aired in the community. I welcome the report. I thank you, Mr Speaker, for giving me an opportunity of making a brief comment.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: COMMITTEE OF INQUIRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the final report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Howard)-by leave-agreed to:
(1) That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the report, and
(2) That the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In tabling the final report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, I wish to express the gratitude of the Government to the members of the Committee and the Committee secretariat for the work they have done over a period of almost three years in putting together this very comprehensive document. I especially acknowledge the distinguished leadership role and contribution of Mr Keith Campbell as Chairman of the Committee. The Government is also very appreciative of the contribution that the financial and broader community of Australia has made to the workings of the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is certainly the most detailed analysis ever of the Australian financial system. It has made a number of quite sweeping and fundamental recommendations for change which cover many aspects of the financial system, and which call for a considered and careful government response. The report will now be very closely studied by the Government. We will welcome public comment and debate. In particular the views of State governments will be sought as many recommendations affect the States. As already announced, a special task group has been established to advise the Government on its response to the report.

Whilst for obvious reasons I am unable at this stage to respond to specific recommendations in the report, I can make two observations of a general character. The broad approach of the Committee has been to argue for a less regulated, more competitive and freer financial system and one which places emphasis on stability and investor protection. Such an approach is consistent with the Government's basic objectives in this area. If implemented, many of the recommendations of the Committee would continue the process of measured and prudent deregulation in the financial system which has taken place in recent years.

However as the Committee itself recognises the report is essentially an economic document which concentrates on the efficient workings of the financial system. It is inevitable, therefore, that the Committee has made some recommendations which raise social and political sensitivities. Indeed, in certain areas the Committee has advocated changes to long-standing methods whereby governments have provided either assistance or a preference to different sections of the community. I have in mind, in particular, areas such as housing finance and the role of certain institutions in providing finance for different areas of the community, such as the rural and small business sectors.

In considering the report the Government must of necessity address itself not only to considerations of economic efficiency but also to social and political issues which are of enormous importance to many Australians in their everyday activity. It is important to note in this regard that the Committee has not questioned whether the Government should provide special assistance in any area nor has it questioned the level of that assistance. It has quite properly acknowledged that governments do have reasons other than purely economic ones for providing special assistance or conferring a preference. The Committee has simply made recommendations regarding the way in which that assistance might be delivered or preference conferred more efficiently. It is now up to the Government to assess carefully the Committee's recommendations. In doing so we shall naturally seek to achieve a balance between economic, social and political considerations and realities. However, I make it clear that the level of assistance to particular sections of the community should not and will not be an issue in the Government's consideration of the report. The Government's priorities in these areas are well known and will be maintained. Furthermore, the Government will not change existing arrangements for the provision of assistance in these areas unless it can be completely satisfied that the alternatives are not only more efficient but also fully meet the Government's social and political priorities.

I again thank all of those who have worked so hard to put together the report which touches virtually all of the financial institutions of our nation. The Committee's recommendations are wide-ranging and cover many areas of great complexity which will require thoughtful examination. I look forward to a period of public debate and scrutiny of the report which will be invaluable in guiding the Government's own deliberations upon its contents. I conclude by expressing on behalf of the Government my thanks to the members of the federal parliamentary Press Gallery for the first class manner in which all members of that Gallery, to my knowledge, have observed a 48-hour embargo on the publication of this report. I think documents of this kind ought to be made available to the Press well in advance of publication. I thank the members of the Gallery for their superb co-operation on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This is a momentous report. I thank the Treasurer (Mr Howard) for making a copy of it available to the Opposition over 24 hours before the announcement.
—Thirty-six hours; don't be mean.

—Well, I am being gracious. It is a most momentous report because of the extraordinary amount of information that it reveals about the operations of our financial system. I think we have all seen that in the interim report; there is, indeed, more of that in the final report. It is of interest because of the devastating impact on our society that would flow from the adoption of the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. It is momentous because it confronts this Government with the full implications of its own ideology. To that extent it is indeed a very momentous report. We shall now see to what extent the Government really believes in its free enterprise rhetoric by the degree to which it adopts this report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is based squarely on the Government's professed ideology, as shown firstly by its terms of reference. The terms of reference of this report make it quite clear that the committee has had to bear in mind the Government's free enterprise objectives and broad goals for national economic prosperity, et cetera. The emphasis on free enterprise objectives is of importance. The Treasurer, in announcing the establishment of this Committee and its terms of reference, made various comments which are quoted in the preface to the final report. Those comments ran along the lines that the objective of the inquiry was not to bring about more regulation by the Government-this is reported by the Government in thick black type; in other words it knew from the very outset what its instructions were-but that it was to bear in mind the Government's free enterprise philosophy and not in any way to produce recommendations which would involve increased regulation. Those were the Committee's marching orders. To make sure that this objective was accomplished the Government established a Committee which was composed of persons who were very largely from the finance industry-a technocratic group the members of which undoubtedly believed in the ideology propounded by this Government.

The Chairman of this Committee was the head of a property development company; the chairman of a merchant bank which is 49.9 per cent owned by Citibank, a foreign bank and one of the largest banks in the world-he has since resigned from that position but he held it when he was appointed chairman of the committee; and a director of IBM Australia Ltd. In addition, the Committee was composed of a merchant banker; the head of our largest life insurance company; the head of the Australian Resources Development Bank, which is owned by the trading banks; a Reserve Bank of Australia official; and a Treasury official. I think that it can be seen from that list that there was no Ben Chifley in this committee of inquiry into our financial system, as there was in the previous committee in the 1930s. There was no-one with an opposing view or a broader view than the very narrow view of the technocrats involved in the finance industry of this country. I believe that the report suffers enormously because of that and because of the enormous constraint which was placed upon it by the terms of reference and the instructions from the Treasurer, which were faithfully reported by the Committee in its preface.

The report confronts the Government with the implications of the implementation of its own ideology. It does so because it shows quite clearly that deregulation-of which we have heard so much in this House-in the finance industry means higher interest rates for home buyers, higher interest rates for small business, higher interest rates for farmers, higher interest rates for government, increased government taxes and charges to cope with increased borrowing costs, less finance for housing, a more volatile exchange rate with decontrol of our foreign exchange and less control by the government over the form of development of the Australian economy. That is what deregulation means. This report brings out those implications very fully indeed. It also shows that reliance on competitive markets to ensure competition in the finance industry involves the introduction of foreign banks and higher levels of foreign investment in the Australian finance industry. It shows that reliance on private enterprise means selling off-the Committee strongly recommends this-the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, the State banks, the State government insurance offices, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, which the Government has already announced it intends to sell off, and the abolition of the Commonwealth Development Bank. If the Government finds all that a little difficult to carry out, the report says that at least all these organisations should be made to operate on exactly the same basis as the private enterprise organisations in those areas so that they will have no regulatory influence at all other than that of an additional competitor in the market. They are the broad implications of the Government's ideology in respect of this industry. Doubtless the Government will find some part of those regulations comforting indeed. I suggest that it will find many of them extraordinarily difficult to deal with.

The Government has a profound, severe problem in accepting the implications of its ideology, particularly in the area of interest rates. It is shown quite clearly in the report that the interest rates will be increased. A commissioned study reported in the report shows that it is expected that, with deregulation, interest rates on housing loans by banks would increase to up to 2 per cent above the government bond rate. At the time when the study became available to the Committee of Inquiry, the bond rate was 13.1 per cent. The bond rate is now 14.6 per cent at the lower end and 15 per cent at the top end, for longer term loans. A 2 per cent margin above that would mean housing loans at 17 per cent. Admittedly, the Inquiry does not accept that this will necessarily be the case and gives the reason why it thinks that deregulated home loan interest rates would not rise to that margin above the bond rate, but it does not in any way deny that they would rise to the bond rate and perhaps go above it.

One of the reasons it gives for interest rates not rising to the full 2 per cent above the bond rate is that there would be much less demand for housing. Of course, that is fairly likely and is also a very important implication of what has been recommended in this report, that is, that a lot less finance should be available for housing, that housing should compete in the market on a thoroughly unsupported basis with all the other demands for capital in this country. In that situation home buyers will have less capability of obtaining finance against the demands for finance by multinationals and others seeking to develop resources in particular. I believe that area is of extraordinary importance in this report.

The Treasurer in his statement today produced a report which the Opposition simply cannot accept. We cannot accept it on varying grounds. Firstly, we cannot accept its ideological basis. That basis is, of course, that reliance on markets will bring about a more optimum result for society than will government regulation. We believe that that is not likely to be the case because, firstly, markets are not perfect. Indeed, they are marked by oligopoly in this country, particularly in the banking industry, and there is thus a lack of real competition, especially as the Government has allowed amalgamations which have diminished the degree of competition. That diminution of competition is then used as a reason for the introduction of foreign banks, as we forecast at the time when the Government allowed those amalgamations to occur.

At times the report seems to say that it is satisfied with the degree of competition. At other times it stresses the need for an effective trade practices Act to ensure competition. In fact, as we all know, the Trade Practices Act has been weakened by this Government and reliance on the Trade Practices Act, as it is likely to exist under this Government, seems to us to be relying on a very weak reed. Even if markets are perfect, the results may not accord with what we as a society regard as optimal because we want to assist various disadvantaged groups. The report acknowledges that but says that it is best to give that assistance by other means, that is, by Budget measures such as subsidies or tax concessions. It does not attempt to define the increasing costs that would come from those measures or the implications for tax levels of having to provide increased taxes to cover the tax assistance that would be given through the Budget by way of subsidy or tax concessions to home buyers to overcome the enormous increase in interest rates which is likely to come from deregulation. By not giving that costing the report is quite deficient. Despite such a scheme it is quite clear from the report that housing would lose out to other investments.

We regard the impact of the implications of this report as thoroughly unacceptable. Increased interest rates at a time when interest rates are already at a record high level is something that society as a whole simply does not want. I cannot believe that the Committee, in propounding a proposal which would have that implication, really has its finger on the pulse of this nation. It suggests in the report that it feels that the community wants some further deregulation. I suggest that the last thing the community wants is higher interest rates for home loans. The last thing the community wants is more difficult availability of finance for housing. I believe in those circumstances that the implications of this report are quite important and that the report will be rejected completely by the community. Not only home buyers but also small businessmen and farmers will reject totally a report which has these implications. There are many other indications which we find deficient but I do not have time to go into them.

We regard the report as deficient in a few particular ways. It is absolutely amazing that in the interim report and, so far as I can see, in the final report-I have not had time to read the 830-odd pages-there is no mention whatever of bank profits or the profits of any element of the finance industry. I find it an extraordinary deficiency that in this mammoth report, with the mountains of information that have been produced, it has not been thought necessary by the Committee to study the profits of the industry to see whether they are at a reasonable level or whether they may be regarded as excessive and whether that may have some implications for the degree of competition or the necessity for government regulation. There is not one mention of banking profits or the profits of any other element of the industry. This is at a time when banking profits have been soaring. Studies have shown that bank profits in Australia are amongst the highest anywhere in the world. Today we see in the Press that one of our largest banks has produced a 30 per cent increase in its profitability. This follows a similar increase announced by the National Bank of Australasia Ltd last week.

It seems to be an extraordinary deficiency that the Committee has not at any stage deemed it necessary to report on or study the level of profitability or the performance of banks at large. There is no mention of the way in which the banks have flouted the attempts of the Reserve Bank of Australia to impose quantitive controls on bank lending. They have lent in excess of the amounts to which the Reserve Bank made it clear it wished to limit them. I think that is also an extraordinary deficiency. There is an amazing reliance of a very unspecified form of the ability of welfare policies or some other budgetary policy, which is unexamined, not spelt out and uncosted, to offset the damaging effect that the deregulation procedures recommended in the report would have on the majority of people in this country. There has been no attempt at all to go into those details. The report simply states that it will leave those matters to the welfare sector or to a budget measure of some sort. I regard that as a major area of deficiency.

Finally, there are some aspects of this report of which we approve. I will make those elements clear in the next few days. We think there are a number of minor recommendations which are extremely helpful and important, some of which we believe fly in the face of government policy. I commend the report for that. I believe that overall this report is one which cannot be accepted by the Australian people. It puts the Australian Government on its mettle. It should say whether it really believes in its ideology. If it does so, I believe the Australian people will say that they no longer want this Government to run the country.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The willingness of the Government to make the housing sector a victim of its misguided economic policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, after unemployment the most serious social problem in this country is housing. Yet over the past six years of this Government the growing problems of housing have suffered tragic neglect. As a result this country has a large and growing number of homeless people. Hundreds of thousands of people are living in substandard, over-priced rental accommodation. Thousands are living in caravans, temporary or makeshift accommodation. An increasing number of people are being excluded from the chance of buying their own home, particularly first home buyers. A growing number of people who are now paying off their homes are faced with crippling repayment burdens.

SPEECH.PARA: We have stagnation across the home building industry in all but a few regions in this country. In fact, the Victorian housing industry is in a situation of over 22 per cent under capacity. This has been occurring for several years. Home building firms are going to the wall. We have a loss of skilled labour from the home building industry but, under the policies of this Government, there is worse to come. The recent speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is an indication of the line that has been followed by this Government. This Government has no policies for creating stability in the housing finance market. It has no intention of stimulating the home building industry or of expanding the provision of public housing. It has no concern to ensure security of housing for the Australian people. Under this Government we face a future of continuing housing neglect. This Government is pursuing a policy which deliberately sacrifices the housing sector for the purpose of expanding corporate profitability in the resource development sector.

Last night the Secretary of the Treasury, Mr John Stone, made clear the thrust of the Government's economic policy-its deliberate intention to make a victim of the housing sector. Today the Treasurer has tabled the report of the Campbell Inquiry into the Australian Financial System which signals a further phase of victimisation for the housing sector. I might say that it is also a threat and a sell-out to the overwhelming majority of ordinary Australian people. Yet in the view of Mr Stone and the Treasury-a view which has dominated Government thinking over the past six years-significant sectors of the Australian economy should be squeezed back in order to make more room for expanded foreign capital inflow and to facilitate a transfer of domestic funds towards investment in resource development.

The thrust of this Government's misguided policies is to transfer wealth away from wage and salary earners, the public sector, the housing industry and other domestic activities that the Treasury considers relatively unproductive. It has been the thrust of this Government's taxation policies, industry assistance policy, budgetary policy, monetary policy and interest rate policy to transfer funds towards a wealthy elite for investment in resource development. In the public sector the housing industry has been one of the main victims of this Government's ruthless policy. Funds made available by the Federal Government for public housing have dropped from 3.9 per cent of total Budget outlays in 1974-75 to one per cent this year. In real terms Federal housing funds have fallen from $1,413m in 1974-75 to $399m in 1981-82. This Government has transferred not only funds away from housing but it has also transferred its national responsibilities to ensure housing security on to the States; and it has thrown it back on to the individual, and particularly that large group of individuals, details of which have been given in the Campbell report.

There is now a dangerous backlog of neglected housing needs which requires a substantial increase in outlays for public housing if Australia is to avoid serious social upheaval. But the private housing sector has also been a major victim of this Government's misguided policies and, given the glasshouse recommendations of the Campbell report, the private housing sector is likely to face even more serious disruption. The Campbell report has recommended:
All official intervention in the determination of bank deposit and lending interest rates should cease and existing controls should be abolished.

The acceptance of that recommendation-it is the philosophy of this Government to in fact accept it because the whole trend has been on that line-will mean a great tragedy not only now but also in the next decade or two when we have increasing population, both natural and through immigration, in this country. The recommendation for across-the-board deregulation of interest rates, if implemented, will create havoc in the housing industry. It will cause a further rise in home loan interest rates which will act to exclude a greater number of people from access to home ownership. Already four out of five wage and salary earners are excluded from access to affordable housing finance. Interest rate deregulation will impose heavier burdens on those people now paying off home loans. Already under this Government home loan interest rates for savings banks have risen in less than two years since February 1980 from 9.5 per cent to 12.5 per cent. On a $30,000 loan repaid over 25 years, that increase in the interest rate of 3 percentage points has raised the monthly repayments by $65 a week. People paying $262 a month now have to pay $327 a month which adds $19,800 to the total loan to be repaid over the 25 years. This has occurred to new home buyers and is also placing an increased burden on people paying off their mortgages at present. That is only a part of the story that will occur if deregulation continues.

The Campbell report recommends that housing loan interest rates should be determined by so-called market forces and not be held down to affordable levels by Government intervention. The prevailing market interest rate at present on semi-government authority loans is between 15.5 per cent and 15.7 per cent. A $30,000 loan repaid over 25 years at 15.5 per cent interest rate would mean a monthly repayment of $395.92. That repayment would exclude virtually nine out of 10 wage and salary earners from access to housing finance. In addition, the charging of such an interest rate would impose intolerable burdens on existing home buyers and people paying off their mortgage at present. Monthly instalments would rise a further $69 a month and total loan repayments would rise something like $20,650 which would make the total repayments for a $30,000 loan over 25 years $118,780. To give the House further details I seek to incorporate in Hansard a table I have prepared on interest rates.
