TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This table sets out the monthly loan instalments and total loan repayments on interest rates at 9 1/2 per cent, 12 1/2 per cent and 15 1/2 per cent for a $30,000 loan over 25 years. I have been talking about a $30,000 loan. House prices at the bottom end of the market in Sydney are $55,000. So if one is able to get a $30,000 loan one has to raise a deposit of $25,000. That is how impossible the position is. In fact, the median price of a house in Sydney is $84,000 while in Melbourne the median price is about $55,000 and a house at the bottom end of the market is about $45,000. So we can see the serious situation that arises in those areas. If free market forces are allowed to prevail, people will be repaying $134 a month more on a $30,000 loan than they were in February 1980, or a total increased repayment of over $40,000. That is what the policies of this Government are doing.

SPEECH.PARA: I am frankly amazed at the ruthlessness displayed in the recommendations of the Campbell report. How can the average home buyer compete with companies such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, Exxon-the biggest company today-Utah or General Motors-Holden's Ltd? How can the ordinary individual compete with those powerful organisations? The authors of this report have a distorted view of the operations of the finance market. It is as if there were no such thing as a concentration of wealth in a few large companies and in the greedy hands of these selfish people. The Committee has recommended that controls over the lending of banks and building societies that favour the housing sector be lifted-and I stress the word 'lifted'. This will ensure a further flow of funds away from housing and will act to deepen the level of concentration of wealth which already distorts the financial market. The point I want to make is that these recommendations come out of the same stable-I stress those words-as the advice the Government has been following over the past six years. It is the consistent extension of the logic of the Government's policies and no amount of opportunist side-stepping over the Campbell recommendations at this stage when the cards are placed clearly on the table can alter that fact. This Government is pursuing a course that endangers the housing industry and which threatens the housing security of the overwhelming majority of the Australian people. The Campbell Committee recognises in a way some of the hardships that will result from the implementation of its recommendations because the report states at page 639:

Housing construction activity will, of course, continue to exhibit some degree of instability, reflecting the sensitivity of demand for housing to increases in interest rates, and the dependence of purchasers of housing and home builders on credit.
I note that the Committee curiously stated:
The Committee has not sought to determine whether there is an appropriate level of resources going into housing.

The Committee made no estimate of the need of the housing sector for funds and failed to consider seriously how effectively and equitably the existing arrangements in the finance market will meet those needs. On page 646 of the report the Committee included a table, but without comment. I stress these next words because the Government has to look at the seriousness of the situation. It showed that while 45 per cent of income earners received less than $185 a week that group accounted for only 3.4 per cent of loans from banks. Those 45 per cent of people received only 3.4 per cent of the loans yet this Government, which really supports the very wealthy, is going to squeeze those little people more and more. That is the law of the jungle: Free market forces must prevail. Instead of addressing the problem of how to increase access to housing finance more equitably the Committee proposed a series of measures that will skew the distribution of housing loans even further in favour of those on high incomes. The Committee commented at page 648 of the report:

Those persons most likely to be affected by sizeable interest rate increases are those who have not yet acquired their first home . . . or who have borrowed recently and whose repayments are a high proportion of their income.

These are the people most in need of housing in Australia, yet they are the people whom the Government's policies are failing. We need at present a five-point plan co-ordinated at the federal level and pursued co-operatively at the State and local government level to expand the provision of funds for public sector housing, to ensure stable liquidity flow into the housing finance market, to provide effective assistance to first home buyers, to protect existing home buyers having trouble meeting their home loan repayment commitments and to stimulate employment and activity in the home building industry by targeting for a level of construction appropriate to existing capacity to meet emerging housing requirements. The housing industry, except in a couple of regions in Australia, is at a very low ebb and it is about time this Government stimulated the housing industry to create employment, when there is so much unemployment. It is about time the Government stopped people moving away from the housing industry and built it up in the interests of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am gratified indeed that the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) has placed this matter before the House because it provides me with the opportunity of enunciating once again the Government's very real achievements and the responsibility and integrity of the Budget handed down in August. I want to rebut some of the honourable member's misguided statements. I have no wish to debate the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. It is not now the time to debate it, and we have made that quite clear. It is a pity that the honourable member for Reid did not read the statement made by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) because he said that adequate time will be allowed for a proper and sober assessment of the report. I am a little concerned because although the honourable member for Reid does not usually do this, today he took a selective, biased reading of carefully culled quotations in order to give a distorted picture of the report. I am disappointed that he has seen fit to do that. However, on the credit side for him, for once he is right. The housing sector is sensitive to overall government economic policy. The housing sector needs an economic policy which maximises long run economic growth; provides sustained demand through lifting real family incomes; maintains a healthy rate of population growth; ensures young people can get jobs and, consequently, form households; keeps building costs within reason; promotes efficient finance markets; minimises inflation and price increases; and assists a steady availability of housing finance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's achievements in those areas are already clear and I want to repeat them. We have come a long way since the economic ruin of those disastrous years of 1972-75. We have rebuilt the economy. That is not an idle statement. I will cite statistics which show the job we have done. Inflation is down from 17 per cent to 9.1 per cent. In the last two years government policies have created 320,000 new jobs, which indicates that the economic climate we have created is one of confidence. Real income which is, after all, the thing that really counts, has increased by almost 4 per cent in the last year bringing increased living standards for all. Migration has increased steadily each year and is up from 21,000 in 1975-76 to almost 120,000 at present. Gross new farm product grew by 4 per cent in 1980-81 and private business fixed investment increased by 21.2 per cent in the same year. Quite obviously, that is a climate of confidence.

This climate of confidence has been reflected in the housing industry. The year 1980-81 saw approximately 148,000 housing commencements. That figure allows, of course, for revision of the Australian Statistician's June quarter figures. That is the highest level of commencements in almost a decade. It is interesting to note that commencements in New South Wales and Queensland were at an all time historical record level. However, there is always a price to be paid. We have to be realists. Economic achievements we have made so far have caused a price to be paid and that price has been discipline-a steady discipline over government spending, a discipline over the growth in financial aggregates, a discipline over the deficit, a discipline over the grandiose borrowing plans of State governments and local and semi-government authorities. Some State Ministers, unfortunately, seem to think that money grows on trees.

I want to mention a couple of key factors. The 1980-81 Budget was a milestone. It saw, for the first time in many years, a substantial domestic surplus. That, more than any other factor, will help us to reduce the pressure on interest rates. The second fact that is vitally important is that it reinforces our very real efforts to cut the heavy pressures that State, local and semi-government authority borrowings were placing on financial markets. We achieved that discipline through decisions we took in the Loan Council in June of this year. It was a pity that our attempts at discipline and financial responsibility were not matched by the States. When they thought that they would have to exercise some discipline and that they would have to go out on the hustings and indicate to people that they could not give them the things that they wanted they roared like scrub bulls because, for the first time in their lives, many of them had to be responsible.

We realised that these decisions were not popular decisions, but being a government of responsibility and a government with steel in its spine our economic policy is all of one piece. It is a policy that emphasises responsibility and the need to get the fundamentals right. Our policies do not need to be popular, but, by George, they have to work and they are working. This Government is a good government. It is not a government composed of members who believe that they can pander to the whims of everyone. That would be a government of weak reeds, swaying and bending in the breeze. One cannot look at our economic track record without conceding that our policies are continuing to work.

Our decision to let banks increase their interest rates on home loans was not popular, but it was responsible. If we had bowed to pressure, such as that coming from the irresponsible fringes of party politics to keep interest rates artificially low, we would have witnessed the drying up of the finance pool. That would have been far more unpopular. We would have been denying young people access to home loans. We were not prepared to do that. Unfortunately, there has been an inevitable easing in the number of loan approvals for housing. While the savings banks were able to increase their lending in early 1981, building societies, particularly those subject to unrealistic State government interest rate controls, did have to cut the funds they were providing to home seekers. Some State governments were unwilling to take responsible decisions prior to an election, but once the elections were over they did what we told them they should have done.

We must get this matter in perspective. The year 1980 was probably the best year we have seen in terms of the number of loans approved by banks and building societies. There is already evidence that building societies are getting into a position where they too will be able to improve their lending. The latest advice coming to me is that, in most parts of Australia, their funds intake has improved, that they have been able to restore their liquidity levels and that, therefore, we can expect an improvement in the flow of loans from permanent building societies through 1981-82.

I do not and I know my Cabinet colleagues and other Government members also do not want to give the impression that the Government is not concerned about or sympathetic towards young home seekers, home buyers, pensioners who have to rent their dwellings, Aboriginals, other special groups and those who are being helped through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The Government has taken firm action in the 1981 Budget to lift its overall spending on housing and accommodation. I repeat, expenditure on housing and accommodation in the Budget rose from $555m last year to $660m this year, an increase of 18.9 per cent covering the whole spectrum of housing and accommodation for all types of people.

As honourable members know, we are currently reviewing our whole range of housing policies. This review underlines our flexibility in responding to changing circumstances. It will determine whether the Government is getting value for money from its current programs and examine the need for new home ownership assistance measures. However, it is not just a Commonwealth problem. Far too many Australians try to sheet home the blame for all financial problems to the Commonwealth Government. The States and local government have their own responsibilities. I support the statements made by the Treasurer in answer to a question without notice earlier this afternoon.

I want to speak about one area of concern-conveyancing and stamp duty. In Victoria, a first home buyer currently pays up to $1,256 State stamp duty on the purchase of a house worth $50,000 with a $40,000 mortgage. However, in Tasmania a first home buyer receiving a full home savings grant pays absolutely no stamp duty at all. This shows that with a bit of flexibility, common sense and concern, the States could do a lot more to help first home buyers to bridge the deposit gap. In the case of Tasmania, I like to see this sort of co-operation between the States and the Commonwealth.

I get a little concerned when I pick up the Press and read certain statements made by other Ministers for housing. I can assure the Minister of Housing in Victoria that vilification and vituperation are not the hallmarks of a fighter. Success in his own sphere of endeavour and responsibility is the hallmark of a fighter. The fact is that in Victoria, as I stated, it costs $1,256 for stamp duty. If the Victorian Minister followed the example of the Tasmanian Minister and reduced the charges in line with these in that State it would help considerably people who wish to purchase their first homes. Victoria spends less money on welfare housing than any other State in Australia. I challenge the Victorian Minister to do two things: Increase his State's spending on welfare housing to equal the Australian average and give a rebate of, say, $400 or $500 over and above the present rebate which is given to first home buyers. If he can do that, I believe that he can quite rightly claim to be interested in housing. What does he do at the present time? He has spent on advertising $15,000 which would help people to get their first home. He is wasting money in trying to camouflage the issue. Instead of being a fighter and a man of responsibility he is what we might term a political gelding. He seems to think there is something to be done, that there is a problem and he would like to be involved. He realises that he cannot do anything about it, and all he can do is whinny and neigh.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. We are debating a matter of public importance raised by the Opposition about the housing crisis in this country. All we are getting at the moment is a fight between the Liberal Party and the National Country Party about housing. When are the parties to the coalition going to come together and solve the people's problems?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Another area in which State and local governments bear a heavy responsibility is housing costs. Studies carried out for the Commonwealth-State ministerial council on housing costs showed that land development costs could be cut by thousands of dollars in many local government areas if State and local governments would work together to rationalise standards. The same sort of remark could be made about building regulations. Members of this House would be well aware of the manufactured housing awareness program that we have launched jointly with the States. This innovation could offer a real solution to housing cost problems in many of the high growth development areas. We will be supporting wholeheartedly a conference organised by the Master Builders Federation in April next year to keep up the pressure on State and local governments to remove the causes of unnecessarily high housing costs. The success of our economic policies in holding down building costs can be seen in the latest figures for material price increases. In the 12 months to October 1981 the figure was 8.4 per cent, contrasting with 15.4 per cent in the 12 months to October 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: In its fight against rising costs, the Government has taken a firm and very positive line against the introduction of the 36-hour week which, on current estimates, would add somewhere between $4,000 and $6,000 to the cost of new housing. When we look at the last six years of the Fraser-Anthony free enterprise coalition Government, we can identify those economic gains which have placed Australia as one of the Western world's most favoured nations. With a degree of self-satisfaction, although the battle is far from over, we can view our controlled inflation rate, our employment situation and various other so-called barometers in the light of performances achieved in other developed countries. Our performance, by comparison, has been good. In its latest report, the Reserve Bank of Australia notes that we are maintaining our high rate of home ownership. Our home ownership rate of almost 72 per cent compares with 62 per cent in Canada, 50 per cent in England and Wales, 69 per cent in New Zealand, 65 per cent in the United States of America and 33 per cent in West Germany. While interest rates in this country have increased-no government, no Treasurer, no minister likes to see them at these levels-they are most favourable when compared with rates which apply in the housing markets of other countries.

The current rates in Australia for housing loans vary between 13 1/2 per cent and 14 1/2 per cent. Interest rates on new loans overseas are 15 per cent in the United Kingdom, 17 per cent in the United States and 21 per cent in Canada. The rates which now apply in Australia have been made possible through the rigid enforcement of the Government's economic policies and by the discipline with which the Government has faced opposition to those policies. The successes of these policies are self-evident and they are being reflected in various areas of commerce and the community together with an associated restoration of confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all aware of the obsession of this Government with the need for restraint in government expenditure. However, I still find it impossible to understand why housing has been forced to bear such a disproportionate share of such restraint. Nearly all home buyers have to borrow to buy a home and, consequently, interest rates and the availability of finance are crucial factors in the quest for home ownership. Because of the policies of the Fraser Government, interest rates have reached record levels; there is intense competition for finance both in the private and public sectors to finance resource based industries and related infrastructure; the Government, through government bonds, is taking an increasing share of household savings; and the housing sector is being squeezed.

SPEECH.PARA: In this Parliament, we are subjected to claims that government policy is directed at giving scope for a wide range of innovative policies. When the Housing Assistance Bill 1981 was debated in this House on 2 June, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) stated:
The current Bill increases the flexibility given to the States and continues the process of ensuring that assistance is directed to people in need.

This is absolute nonsense and such statements of principle bear no relationship to the facts! Yet the Minister for Housing and Construction continues to make such ridiculous statements while he presides over vicious cutbacks in funding for housing and supports policies which have caused record interest rates and a severe restriction on funds available for housing finance. As recently as 17 September 1981, on Estimates Committee E when considering estimates for the Department of Housing and Construction, the Minister again expressed confidence that our high level of home ownership by world standards would continue, a matter which he repeated today in the debate. It is difficult to know whether the Minister for Housing and Construction is ignorant of the facts or whether he prefers to ignore them.

Figures released yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show a substantial slowing down in the price of building materials. This is caused by the lower demand for housing because of record interest rates and lack of housing finance. Commenting on the figures, the Deputy Executive Director of the Housing Industry Association, Dr Silberberg, stated:
There are now thousands of Australian families squeezed out of the home market because of the present level of interest rates.

Dr Silberberg further predicted that, unless this Government moves quickly to restore home ownership opportunities, there will be 15,000 fewer homes produced in 1981-82 with a shortfall of at least 22,000 new dwellings in 1980-81. This Government refuses to face the fact that half of all employees in Australia earn less than $200 a week. Yet to borrow $30,000 to purchase a home requires a gross weekly income of about $350. The Government's cavalier attitude to increases in interest rates ignores the fact that a one per cent increase in interest rates reduces borrowing power by about $2,500 for a family which can afford mortgage payments of $100 weekly.

The policies of this Government have caused tragic consequences. These are clearly seen in the report of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Building Research Division which states that the number of families able to afford maximum loan conditions for an average lower cost house in Melbourne has fallen from 80 per cent 10 years ago to less than 50 per cent now. It makes one wonder whether the Minister looks at any of these independent reports or whether he continues to prefer to run the line that, because of the fact that we have always had a high rate of home ownership, it will continue. The facts indicate quite clearly that, unless this Government takes action as a matter of urgency, that claim by the Minister will not be able to be maintained.

Home buyers have become so desperate for housing finance that they are now prepared to borrow from finance companies at exorbitant interest rates. The magnitude of this problem is clearly seen in the figures released by the Australian Bankers Association Research Directorate on 3 September this year. These figures disclose that value of housing loans from banks grew by 5.2 per cent over 1980-81. For the same period, the value of housing loans from building societies increased by 2 per cent but the value of loans from finance companies for that period increased by a massive 44 per cent. The response of the Minister for Housing and Construction to this information clearly indicates the appalling attitude of this Government on this crucial issue. His reaction was that, if people are prepared to go to finance companies for housing finance, this indicated that they still have a commitment to home ownership. What is does show, despite the view of the Minister, is that people have become desperate to obtain finance to purchase homes. It is not a matter of them having a commitment; the fact is that it is the only finance available to far too many people who are desperately seeking finance to purchase a home. Many of these people borrow money from finance companies on a first mortgage but the tragedy of people who borrow that sort of money on second mortgages is seen in what is happening throughout Australia at the moment.

The Treasurer (Mr Howard) has recently indicated that he does not accept the fact that mortgagees auctions are being conducted throughout Australia at the moment. That is incredible because it completely refuses to accept the facts. At the present time people have been caught and locked into the increases in interest rates from building societies and banks but more particularly the people I indicated earlier who are forced to borrow on second mortgages from finance companies, are finding it absolutely impossible to maintain their mortgage payments. The position now is that not only will people find it impossible to purchase a house but also, tragically, so many people who have a house are likely to lose it in the near future. In Victoria, the problem of the public housing sector has reached a desperate stage. Despite the claims today by the Minister, it was announced that Victoria will, over the next year, pay to the Commonwealth Government $2.6m more in interest and loan repayments than it receives in housing allocation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is for public housing.

—That is for public housing as the honourable member for Reid has indicated. Despite the rhetoric of the Minister this Government has indicated its contempt for those Australians so desperately in need of housing. The reality is that this Government has singled out housing for unprecedented cutbacks in funding. Public housing is the only category to have suffered a fall in Commonwealth outlays in real terms. Clearly, when one looks at the tragedy of people unable to get a home, I agree entirely with what the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) has said-after unemployment this is the most significant social problem in this country. This Government must be judged as having failed dismally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I acknowledge that, given that interest rates have risen rapidly, there is concern in Government circles for the house purchaser who is suffering hardship. Already it has been widely reported that Cabinet has before it for consideration proposals which will come to grips with short term problems. This well-publicised circumstance, coupled with whatever is contained in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System-which I have not yet seen-and whatever it recommends affecting housing finance gives the lie to any alleged lack of care on the part of the Government and, at the same time, gives rise to doubts as to the motives for raising this matter of importance at this time. Knowing that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) has proposals before the Cabinet and under consideration, it is obvious that he will not pre-empt Cabinet deliberations in this debate; not that it is proved to be necessary, given the argument advanced by Opposition speakers. However, I am not under that constraint because I do not know the details of what is before the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems associated with higher mortgage interest rates seem to have elicited three short-run reactions: Firstly, income tax deductibility or tax credit on housing loan interest; secondly, interest subsidy; and, thirdly, hardship relief. Any arbitrary rules which must be attached to either tax deductions, credits or interest subsidies are almost certain to exclude some cases of demonstrable hardship. Studies undertaken by the Perth Building Society, the largest in my State of Western Australia, and the first or second of the three largest and most reputable building societies in Australia, indicate that at most 1 1/2 per cent of purchasers who have taken out loans over the past two years may be in some sort of difficulty-sometimes serious difficulty. I might add that that estimate of 1 1/2 per cent of purchasers is not the Perth Building Society's experience. In its experience, the percentage is much lower. Therefore, the estimate probably errs on the high side.

These purchasers deserve-I am confident that they will receive-priority in any considerations now before the Government. Reference has already been made by the Minister to expectations as to new housing starts during the financial year. He referred to an estimated and staggering 140,000 to 150,000 dwelling units expected to be commenced this year, which is up 13 per cent on the previous year-hardly evidence of restraint by the Government in relation to its housing policy or to the housing sector generally. The largest national housebuilder in Australia, Jennings Industries Ltd, has already recently reported a 30 per cent increase in new orders over last year. Other cottage builders with whom I have consulted, with products which cater for the market, have similar stories to tell. There has been an increase in orders. Sydney might be the exception but that can probably be explained by the extraordinary level of dwelling construction in that city over the past three years. House builders whom I know and to whom I have spoken are already anticipating a scarcity of resources, particularly labour in metropolitan and probably remoter areas. Well they might, because the non-residential construction sector and the building sector generally are operating at a very high level. Labour is interchangeable between non-residential, high density residential and the cottage building sector. If anything is likely to exacerbate the problem of rapidly increasing house building costs it is a scarcity of suitable skilled labour. I suggest that that is potentially in the offing. The maintenance of what I see as a resurgence of the cottage building industry will be the catalyst for further cost pressures to the detriment of intending purchasers of houses.

With that scenario the Government's overall economic management remains of paramount importance. Within the framework of continuing sensible economic management Cabinet will consider and decide what must be done with the best interests of those in need and the Australian taxpayer in mind. It must be recognised that the outcome of adopting some of the alternatives open to the Government will not be confined to obvious and costed impact on expenditure, either in the form of subsidy or, in the case of tax credits or tax deductibility, in the form of revenue forgone.

Both tax credits and tax deductibility schemes will have the effect of making house loans cheaper, thereby increasing the demand for new housing. Given likely pressures on costs, to which I have already referred, a likely outcome will be increased prices for houses which will increase the average size of home loans and, anticipating a shortage of funds, further upward pressure on interest rates. The net result of tax credit or tax deductibility schemes will be that net loan repayments will end up being the same as they were before either scheme was adopted. In considering what is to be done for those currently suffering hardship, care must be taken not to look for quick-fix short term solutions which have after effects which will be of detriment to future purchasers.

The Opposition advocates control of interest rates. It does not say how funds will be attracted into lending institutions and become available to those seeking to purchase a house. The options open to the Commonwealth Government in relation to levels of interest rates in the one sector where it has control, that is the banking sector, appear to be these: Firstly, by exercising control in the areas in which it has the legal power-the banking sector-the Commonwealth may stipulate that bank borrowing and lending rates are arbitrarily kept at levels below those offered to investors and borrowers generally. Or, secondly, it may allow interest rates to rise to something like the going market rate enabling institutions such as banks and building societies, which are predominantly lenders to dwelling purchasers, to attract investment funds. The first option has been disregarded because the effect would be a general absence of funds from investors who could logically be expected to seek better returns elsewhere. Reductions in, or an absence of, investment funds would see demands for borrowing outstrip available funds and probably culminate in demands for injections of taxpayers' funds for long term lending as one industry association did a couple of years ago. The alternative, which has been adopted, has the advantage of attracting investors' funds into institutions permitting borrowers access to funds which would not otherwise be available even though the interest on those borrowings will be, and have been, at rates higher than we in Australia have been accustomed to paying. Although it is difficult to be categorical on the point it seems that the availability of funds at current interest rates remains good. That was supported, I think, by a recent article in a newspaper which indicated that building societies had funds available, an improved situation over that which they experienced earlier this year.

It is a basic tenet of the coalition Government parties to maintain a higher level of home ownership in Australia. To that extent we have been successful, as evidenced by the fact that Australians enjoy one of the highest levels of private home ownership in the world. As evidence of our concern I refer to a program already under way. The Opposition has conveniently ignored the fact that tax deductibility for interest rates was abandoned in Australia after the demise of the Whitlam Government. It was replaced by the Homes Savings Grant Scheme which had the advantage of allowing a front-end reduction of debts up to $3,000 thereby reducing the principles secured by mortgages and, in turn, eliminating the interest commitment of recipients over the nominal life of a mortgage. I add that I am sympathetic to any proposition which calls for that benefit to be paid at, say, the date of occupation or settlement rather than nine months later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is now concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Werriwa from moving:

That this House censures the Minister for Communications for having misled the Parliament with respect to his knowledge of activities by the Australian Dairy Corporation when under his ministerial control.

This issue really demands another airing in this Parliament given the comments of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) at the weekend and the evidence given to the Australian nation on the radio program PM last Thursday night. At the weekend the Deputy Prime Minister accused the critics of his dear old mates the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) of being toad-like creatures skilled in the personal smear. I will get on to that matter later.

In speaking to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders I point out to the House that the matter we now wish to raise does not relate to all the previous debates when the main issue under discussion was whether the Minister for Communications had known of the continuing breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangement and whether he was at all concerned with the sales of skim milk powder to Holland Milk Products Inc., the subsidiary of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd in the Philippines. What was in the evidence last Thursday night quite clearly showed that the Minister had knowledge of this matter as early as April and May in 1976.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman--

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that the honourable member's motion relates to the suspension of Standing Orders whereas it is clear that he is traversing factual matters which might or might not become relevant if and when that motion is carried.
—The point of order is correct. Indeed, I was just moving to ask the honourable member for Werriwa to give reasons for the suspension of Standing Orders as distinct from the reasons for censuring.

—The Standing Orders need to be suspended because of the on-going saga of Asia Dairy Industries and the role of the Minister for Communications in this matter in 1976. Asia Dairy Industries and the Australian Dairy Corporation were clearly--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr N. A. Brown) put:
That the honourable member for Werriwa be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and charge that the Government-

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr N. A. Brown) put:
That the honourable member for Blaxland be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, this Minister has persistently misled this House and it is time this scandal was ended one way or the other.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr N. A. Brown) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Kerin's) be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —After seven years of struggling it is with pleasure that I move the second reading of this important and much needed legislation. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This private member's Bill was presented in the Senate by Senator Evans on 19 August this year. In his second reading speech he dealt fully with the purposes and proposals of the Bill. I commend Senator Evans for his foresight and initiative. In essence, the Bill, with minor modifications, seeks to implement the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission's report entitled 'Insurance Agents and Brokers'. What is particularly pleasing to note is that the Senate supported the Bill without any division on 29 October this year. Equally important, the Senate flatly rejected the reasons upon which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) claimed in this House on 10 June this year that a Federal government should not legislate at a national level and that it is best left to the States. In fact, no body of opinion with any understanding of the insurance industry supports the Treasurer's stand, with the exception of one or two Press editorialists. The statement of the Treasurer-in repeat what I said in June-destroys five years of detailed and constructive investigation and recommendations on the need for legislation for insurance brokers. It is a slap in the face to the industry, to the community and, above all, to Professor David St Leger Kelly and the staff of the Law Reform Commission. To my knowledge up to now the Treasurer has not even had the courtesy to pay tribute to the work of the Commission. Let me congratulate equally Senators Bolkus, Watson, Jessop and Missen on their support in the Senate for this Bill. I recommend that honourable members opposite study the excellent speech of Senator Missen in particular.

Let me canvass the Government's track record in this matter. As I said on 10 June, the need for regulation has long been recognised overseas and within State jurisdictions by all sections of the community involved in the brokering industry. The Queensland Insurance Act 1960-1976 provides for the licensing of brokers. The United Kingdom brought in legislation in 1977. The Whitlam Government drafted legislation before it was dismissed in 1975. Since then, there have been a number of somersaults by this Government. In April 1976 the then Minister assisting the Treasurer announced that the Government would introduce legislation for the supervision of insurance brokers. In March 1977 the Government reversed the decision and announced its intention to pursue a scheme for self-regulation in conjunction with the Insurance Brokers Council. In 1979 the Treasurer announced that he would seek government approval to develop legislation for voluntary regulation arrangements for brokers. Six months later he again changed his mind. In effect, the Government refused to grasp the nettle claiming that there was no consensus amongst the various bodies representing brokers on the forms of control that ought to be or might be introduced.

The Government cannot claim in its defence that the insurance broking lobby is against legislation. Bodies representing the insurance brokers in all sections of the insurance industry have persistently supported and demanded legislation. We have the spectacle of the Western Australian Government being obliged to bring in legislation. The New South Wales Minister has repeatedly indicated that if the Commonwealth fails to act New South Wales will be obliged to do so. The Victorian Minister is committed to bringing in legislation. Unquestionably the only two States left will be obliged to bring in legislation to protect the consumer section of the industry. What will the Minister have? I will tell him what he will have. He will have a plethora of mis-matched, ineffective, inefficient State laws. The situation is scandalous.

Let me briefly advise the House just what a mess this Government's negative approach will inflict on a national industry. In Western Australia the licensing system excludes life insurance but includes general insurance. If a life insurance agent is also selling general insurance he is obliged to register. As I said, Queensland has had legislation in respect of the insurance industry for many years but it is confined, in effect, to general insurance. It applies only to brokers. If a life insurance agent is selling general insurance policies he is not obliged to register. New South Wales intends to legislate. It will follow the Western Australian Act but will include life insurance. Victoria has made no official announcement but has indicated that it will be obliged to legislate. Tasmania and the Northern Territory have made no indication at this point that they will legislate. In South Australia we have the spectacle of the State Liberal Government implementing negative licensing. What this means is that, if a broker commits a misdemeanour or an offence and fails to comply with government criteria, he will be deregistered even though there is no registration. What a shambles we will have. Senator Missen, in support of this much needed legislation, perhaps summed up this aspect more cogently. He said:

I think it also ought to be borne in mind that the report of the Commission came down in 1980, the consumer affairs Ministers of the States met in Melbourne after that-on 14 November 1980-and resolved as follows:
Insurance brokers

Ministers agreed to express their concern to the Commonwealth that the need for urgent action to implement the Australian Law Reform Commission's proposals to regulate the activities of insurance brokers.

It was agreed that there was a need for the Commonwealth to examine legislation involving a fidelity fund to compensate consumers for losses caused by cases of brokers failing to perform. It was also agreed that the legislation should provide for the registration of insurance brokers.

This is not something which has been imposed on the States, it is something which they have requested. The Victorian Minister urged the Federal Government to introduce legislation to register insurance brokers and require them to set up trust and fidelity funds. He pointed out that there had been recent examples of collapses of insurance brokers. One liquidator had been appointed for Kinloch (Insurances) Pty Ltd with debts of $3m. The same month Anthony H. Brown and Associates Pty Ltd went into liquidation and One Stop Insurance Shop Pty Ltd collapsed with debts of $322,000. So there is a constant need. Those examples call for action. State Ministers have supported those claims and demands.

The legislation is based upon the report. It is also based upon defalcations, details of which are set out in the second reading speech, which totalled about $7m in the years before the Law Reform Commission Report. From the time that the report was prepared at least another $7m appears to have been defaulted. The total is probably more like $20m now because it is not known precisely what are some of the losses among a number of the companies. It is utter nonsense to claim that this important aspect of insurance, namely the role of the intermediary-that is the broker or agent-can be isolated from the national legislature and dealt with on a fragmented basis by the States. The Commonwealth Parliament has already intervened and taken action in regard to insurance. We have the Life Insurance Act of 1945 and the Insurance Act of 1973. Certain regulatory bodies and commissioners are operating already in those two fields. As is proposed in the Bill they will play a very active role in the regulation of brokers. Intermediaries are an integral part of the insurance industry. Laws must be not only uniform but also national if the industry is to have the effectiveness, the efficiency and the credibility it deserves.

There are two myths Paul Revered by the Treasurer that must be destroyed once and for all. The Treasurer constantly states that losses represent 0.1 per cent of total broker premiums. My answer is that a vast majority of broker premiums relate to commercial and other large scale insurance. The losses as a percentage of consumer insurance premiums would be much higher than 0.1 per cent. Furthermore, some policyholders will suffer a loss of 100 per cent of premium. Secondly, the Treasurer claims that 92 per cent of losses represent amounts due to insurers. What is the answer to that? This analysis is utterly misleading. Every cent of that 92 per cent of losses is recoverable by insurers from their clients. Furthermore, the remaining 8 per cent owed directly to those insured is a sizable sum. Losses between 1967 and 1979 were 8 per cent of $7m, or $560,000. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document setting out what the Bill does and what it provides.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
INSURANCE (AGENTS AND BROKERS) BILL 1981
What the Bill does
1. Statutory System of Registration of Brokers
Administered by Insurance Commissioner and Life Insurance Commissioner;
Obligations upon registered brokers:
compulsory professional indemnity and fidelity guarantee insurance (cl.17);
separate insurance broking account in which all premium and claim moneys must be kept and investment of which is limited to 'prescribed securities' (cl.21);
regular inspection or audit of books, accounts and records (cl.33);
full disclosure to insured and insurer of details of insurance contracts, including details of the broker's remuneration (cl.25);
Registration liable to be suspended or cancelled if broker or its employee convicted of any offence relating to insurance or to dishonest conduct (cl.20).

Funding: The system of registration is intended to be self-funding. Based on an estimated registration fee of $200 and an expected registration of 1,000 brokers, the budget of $200,000 would allow for 2 permanent staff plus 2 casual. It is not envisaged that there will be elaborate investigative machinery.
2. Regulating the Conduct of Insurance Agents
Bill establishes clear demarcation between agents and brokers (cl.11);

Insurer responsible to the insured for any conduct of his agent which is relied on by the insured (cl.10) except where it would be unreasonable for the insured in his particular circumstances to rely on the agent's conduct;
No-one other than a registered broker may describe himself or his business in such a way as to mislead a person into believing that he was a broker (cl.30);

Agents are prevented from behaving as brokers because cl.28 (as amended in the Senate) requires them to forward all premium moneys to the insurer forthwith, thus removing any possibility of investment of premium moneys by anyone other than a registered broker.
3. Regulating the Conduct of Brokers and Agents Alike

Payment of premium by an insured to an agent or a broker discharges the insured's liability to the insurer (cl.13) i.e. the agent or broker receives the premium as agent for the insurer and the insured is not vulnerable if the broker collapses or defaults before paying over the premium;

Bill creates offences for an agent or broker to deliberately misrepresent the cost or effect of, or benefits available under, an insurance policy or to misrecord information on a proposal or claim form or to advise an insured or intended insured to do so (cl.12);
Penalties are graded on the same basis as those in the Companies Act 1981 and the Securities Industry Act 1980, and are of similar severity for similar offences.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I will indicate the principal headings of the Bill. The first is 'Statutory System of Registration of Brokers'; the second is 'Regulating the Conduct of Insurance Agents'; and the third is 'Regulating the Conduct of Brokers and Agents Alike'. The legislation is well set out at the beginning of the report of the Law Reform Commission. The Commission stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The private insurance industry is today organised on a national basis. It is undesirable that, in important aspects of the law governing relationships with the insuring public, this national industry should be subject to vague and uncertain rules developed long before the growth of modern insurance. It is equally undesirable that it should be subject to differing legislative requirements from one jurisdiction to another. The needs of the industry and of its customers can only be met by development of a national law of insurance contracts in Australia. This law should promote:
uniformity, to the extent that the Federal Constitution permits
clarity, by removing doubts in existing case law and statutes--
I will deal with this matter later-
relevance, in recognising the realities of the respective positions of the insured, the insurer and the intermediaries (agents and brokers) who facilitate and effect contracts of insurance.

I believe that statement sets out very fairly the need, and the recommendations that justify the action proposed in the Bill. I also note that the need for regulation has been supported by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard page 360 and page 363 of the report.
Leave granted.
The pages read as follows-
IV INSURANCE AGENTS AND BROKERS
A. Background
20.187 There is little regulation of insurance brokers or agents in Australia and self-regulation has been fragmented.

20.188 Until recently, Queensland has been the only State which has provided for the licensing of brokers. In that State, requirements are laid down for the handling of premiums and the delivery of documents and the State Insurance Commissioner has powers of supervision extending to the suspension or cancellation of a licence. In other States the actions of both agents and brokers are constrained, by and large, only by common law.46 (In August 1981, licensing requirements were introduced for brokers in Western Australia.)
46 Details of the requirements applying in Queensland and of the efforts of agents and brokers to regulate themselves are outlined in Chapter 16 of the Interim Report.

20.189 The Law Reform Commission published its report on Insurance Agents and Brokers in September 1980. A number of its recommendations relate to issues which have been raised with the Committee or which bear on the stability and efficiency of this sector of the financial system.
B. Approach to Regulation
(a) Agents
20.190 The Law Reform Commission cites various State Consumer Affairs Departments/ Bureaus as noting complaints in regard to misrepresentation by agents of:
premiums payable for motor vehicle insurance cover;
the size of surrender values for life insurance policies; and
the type of life insurance policy being bought.

20.191 Neither common law nor statute are clear regarding the insurer's responsibility for the actions of their agents; this confusion has been compounded by attempts to exclude liability via contractual exclusions.
20.204 On the other hand, the Committee would not favour sole reliance on self-regulation. Governments clearly have a role in protecting individual consumers against fraud and misrepresentation.

20.205 The Committee also stresses the desirability of consistent regulation. This has been recognised by the Treasurer, who has expressed the hope that any state legislation will recognise the benefits of the existing self-regulatory arrangements and have regard to the advantages associated with uniformity in controls. He has indicated the Government's readiness to assist in achieving uniformity between the States in this area.

20.206 The Committee favours a system of 'co-regulation', with government legislation laying down the ground rules for an arrangement basically involving self-regulation by an appropriate industry body on which there would be some government representation. It believes early action should be taken by the Government to ensure that appropriate co-operative national legislation is developed. This could provide for the holding of funds in trust accounts in connection with their business as brokers, as recommended by the Law Reform Commission.

20.207 It is also desirable that guidelines for the disclosure of information by brokers to their clients should be developed, as this would facilitate caveat emptor. Such guidelines might cover disclosure of such matters as:
the nature of any contractual relationship between an insurer and the broker; and
the remuneration received by a broker from the insurer in respect of a client's business.

20.208 On the latter question, as the broker represents the policyholder, not the insurer, it is reasonable to expect that such information should be made available. As well, details of brokerage fees in other areas of the economy are invariably available to those using brokers (e.g. stockbrokers, real estate agents).
20.209 The Law Reform Commission has suggested that disclosure of such information would:

provide a concerned client with the information which is essential for a check to be made on whether the broker's remuneration appears unusually high, a fact which may itself suggest that a broker has been motivated more by his commission than by his client's needs. Disclosure would also encourage and promote informed assessment and, perhaps, questioning by the client of the cost of the services of an insurance broker. It might well lead to a client comparing the cost of the services of different brokers. There are limited opportunities for inquiry and comparison when the client is not told of the amount paid to his broker. As the amount of remuneration is already determined as between insurer and broker, disclosure to the insured would not itself involve significant costs and might in due course even encourage a reduction in the total costs of insurance. The market forces which operate in favour of competition can be most effective when the consumer is made aware of the cost of services rendered on his behalf.
20.210 The Committee endorses this view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The purpose of this Bill is to deal with the severe problems faced by members of the insuring public in relation to misconduct by insurance agents and brokers. There are thousands of insurance agents and brokers in Australia. The vast majority of them act honestly in the interests of their clients, but cases of misconduct occur and, when they do, severe losses are needlessly inflicted on honest people. This Government, indeed the Treasurer, has shown a distinct lack of enthusiasm for the controls suggested by the Commission after an exhaustive inquiry. Yet the Commission's central recommendations have the support of the insurance industry as a whole. It is for that reason, and because of the factors noted in the Commission's report, that Senator Evans has introduced this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Insurance intermediaries are of two classes, namely, agents and brokers. Agents act for one or more insurers, not for insureds. Brokers act for insureds and place business with several insurers. A person may call himself a broker whether he is a true broker or an agent tied to a single company. The public is readily misled by a practice like that. The major problem with agents is that some insurers will not accept responsibility for them. They choose their agents, but when something goes wrong it is for the insured to worry. The insurer simply denies liability. In the past this has led to scandalous decisions. Insurers have made insureds sign a statement to the effect that the insurer's agent is not the insurer's agent at all. Instead, he is the agent for the insured. The courts have upheld this charade. Insurers have also been able to avoid liability by denying that their agents had authority to do certain things. We all know how agents and employees often fill in proposal forms themselves. When they make a mistake, the insurer should accept the responsibility. This Bill provides for that. Unfortunately this often does not happen.

The most frequent complaint that I have had to handle is in relation to motor vehicle insurance. A car salesman is an agent or a sub-agent for insurance. He offers to arrange insurance for the buyer, often at scandalously high rates. He fills in the form on the strength of the answers given him by the buyer. The buyer tells him he has had two accidents in the last five years. The salesman knows that the insurer may not be willing to insure a buyer with that record, so he writes the word 'no' alongside a question concerning the buyer's claims history. In that way he makes sure of the contract and, would you believe it, his commission. If the insured makes a claim, the inaccuracy of the answer as recorded by the agent is discovered. The insurer denies liability on the basis of the insured's misrepresentation. When he says: 'It was your agent who made the mistake', the only answer is: 'Too bad'. The insured loses out. I suggest that position is simply intolerable.

Disreputable insurers are encouraged by the law to have no concern for the behaviour and ethics of their agents. This is bad business practice. Insurers have a duty to train and to supervise their agents. They will uniformly do so only if they are made legally responsible for their conduct. The main problem with brokers is well known to all members. There has been an alarming number of broker collapses over the last decade. The Law Reform Commission at page 61 of the report stated that it had been able to find losses of $7m from broker insolvency between the years 1970 and 1979. The true figure for that period will almost certainly exceed $10m. Since 1979 matters have become much worse. In the last 18 months losses have exceeded $7 1/4m, more than was proved to have been lost in the preceding decade. It is estimated now to have reached $20m. This is simply scandalous. One might say that much more is lost by businesses of various types which have become insolvent. Why then is there all the fuss about brokers?

Broker insolvencies are a matter of particular disquiet because what is lost in a broker insolvency is not the broker's own money, but money paid to him for transmission to an insurer. Brokers use premium funds in a quite unacceptable way in running their own businesses. Solicitors, real estate agents and others are forbidden to act in this way, but brokers are free to indulge in the luxury of spending other people's money. The result of the practice is that the premiums of thousands of clients are dissipated in badly run businesses and bad investments. Obviously either the insureds or the insurers are the losers. Under existing law it is not clear in fact who it is. Many insurers claim the right either to cancel the relevant policies or to ask for payment all over again when premiums are lost in this way. That leads to enormous confusion, to additional costs for the insureds, to legal disputes and to a general lack of confidence in the probity of the industry.

Insurers allow brokers to retain premium funds on credit for months at a time. The details are set out in the Law Reform Commission report at pages 62 to 64. It is unthinkable that they should be permitted any longer to put the loss upon innocent insureds. If, for business reasons they want to give brokers credit, they must pay the cost of that decision. Making sure that insurers cannot avoid this responsibility is not enough. Successive insurance companies have warned of another danger associated with broker insolvency, namely, the failure of one or another, or more, of broker reliant insurers. The confusion and loss to innocent insureds in the event of an insurer collapse are well known to all members. They are worse than those directly resulting from the insolvency of a broker. An insured who has a claim against the company for the loss of his house simply cannot enforce it. If he gets paid at all, it will only be in part, usually a small part, and then only after many years have passed. The failure of the Government to heed the warnings of successive insurance commissioners and of the Law Reform Commission itself is reprehensible.

What can be done to reduce the risk? Laws cannot make people honest, as the Treasurer has often said to me time after time, but laws can inhibit people, including brokers, from acting dishonestly. They can provide a means of uncovering dishonesty and of punishing it when it is revealed. By making the price too high, the risk of crime is reduced. Moreover, by no means do all broker insolvencies arise from deliberate dishonesty. Many brokers already keep their premiums separate from their own moneys. Others would certainly do so if the law obliged them. They are encouraged by the present law to indulge in bad business practices. Dishonesty is simply irrelevant.

What should be done to prevent this type of practice? Clearly, premiums and other insurance moneys should be held in trust accounts and their use should be restricted. In the event of insolvency, they would not be available for the general body of creditors, but only for the individuals and insurers to whom they are due. The practice of investments might be continued, but subject to restrictions aimed at reducing the risk of poor investment by a broker. A set of laws should be implemented so that it would be easily avoided without back-up mechanism. Some supervision, minimal in scope, is essential. Audits on an annual basis should be required. To enable this to be supervised, all insurance brokers should register with insurance commissioners, or with one or other of them, depending on the type of business which they run. The cost of registration and suspension should be met by fees-in other words, by the industry itself. The government purse would not be affected.

In proposing this Bill, Senator Evans has drawn heavily on the draft Bill attached to the report of the Law Reform Commission. The Bill contains a number of provisions aimed at further protecting the public against the risk that a broker is not truly impartial. It also required brokers to possess professional indemnity and fidelity guarantee insurance. State legislation, undoubtedly, will be ineffective. What effect will this type of legislation have on the legal framework? Let us analyse that matter. A single Supreme Court judge in Victoria, Mr Justice Gobbo, in his decision following the insolvency of a broker, claimed that the insured had, in effect, lost his premium, had to carry his own liability and the liability was not sheeted home to the insurer. During the last fortnight, the Full Bench of the Supreme Court in Victoria, in dealing with a case involving insolvency of what it termed an insurance consultant-another term for a broker-took the opposite view. It claimd that the insurer was responsible and, in effect, the insured never lost his premium. A single Supreme Court judge in New South Wales has reserved judgment on a similar case following the insolvency of a broker. Who picks up the tab? It will be interesting to see what decision the judge hands down. But one can reasonably expect that the case will go before the Court of Appeal in New South Wales. Where does all of this lead us? The next stop, obviously, will be appeals to the High Court of Australia. The States may even appeal to the Privy Council. Why? Because it is a common law issue.

What does all this add up to? It adds up, firstly, to utter confusion in the insurance industry and more particularly, a costly exercise for those who are obliged to protect the insurers and, secondly, to a harvest for the legal profession. The net effect will be that members of the legal profession will be the only beneficiaries because we have failed to legislate nationally. It is an extremely expensive business to bring cases before the courts. Costs will total hundreds of thousands of dollars before the case is ultimately resolved, I suppose, by the High Court or the Privy Council which, let me add, will make decisions in the current climate on appeals on a particular point. Even then it cannot resolve the issue.

I am not a lawyer, but let us look as the matter. Perhaps the barristers sitting opposite ought to look at the position because up to this point in time each case has been judged when there exists no appropriate national or uniform legislation or directives as to accounting procedures and other arrangements between the broker in particular and his insurer. Each case will be different because of the vast differences in the respective State legislations. Consequently, the decisions of either the High Court or the Privy Council on a given case may be of no value in other cases. Litigation will mount and the legal profession will be the only beneficiary. The only avenue open to obviate this mess, this confusion, and to avoid needless litigation and the infliction of costs is legislation which, firstly, clearly distinguishes between agents and brokers and secondly, makes the insurer responsible for the premium received by a broker. That is what this Bill sets out to do. It offers protection to the insurer by imposing on brokers proper accounting standards and procedures.

What is the downstream effect of this separate State law, this diverse State law, this fragmented mish-mash which this Government has inflicted and wants to persist in inflicting on this country? I say bluntly to the Treasurer that there is not a single State statute on this issue which addresses itself to the real issue; that is, to make the insurer responsible for the loss of brokers' premiums. In no State statute is that provided for. We can do that only at a national level and we ought to do it. Confusion will mount and so will the legal costs until this Government is forced to face its national responsibility and enact national legislation.

This Government has trotted out cliches with respect to the inability of legislation to make people honest. One can only agree that no amount of legislation could provide a guarantee against fraud and against business failure. That is simply not the purpose of the legislation. The purpose of the legislation is to state what are proper business practices and to penalise those who are unwilling to follow them. At present, many so-called brokers are following practices which do not merely border upon the dishonest; they are dishonest. If, as some judges appear to think, the premiums held by brokers in investments are still the property of the insured, not the insurer, then brokers are making money out of their clients' funds. That is the clearest possible breach of trust. The Commission concluded that the funds held by brokers were not held on behalf of the insured, but on behalf of the insurers. Only on that basis can the conduct of brokers be regarded as honest. On that basis all that trust account requirements are doing is to impose upon brokers the same restriction as is placed upon solicitors. In fact, it is even less of an imposition on brokers than it is on solicitors because brokers are, under our legislation, entitled to make money out of these funds. That, of course, can only be explained on the basis that the funds held by brokers are held by them for insurers rather than the insured. One cannot provide a guarantee against fraud. One can certainly penalise it and make the course of fraud less eligible. One can also provide no guarantee against business failure. But one can assuredly provide for protection of moneys held by brokers which do not belong to them.

I strongly support this much needed initiative by Senator Evans. I have every confidence that when honourable members opposite take the effort to examine this Bill, they will appreciate why the Senate adopted it without any division and why they likewise will reject the Treasurer's stand and support the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and seek leave to continue my remarks when the Bill is debated again.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROFESSIONAL RADIO AND ELECTRONICS INSTITUTE OF AUSTRALASIA: INDUSTRIAL DISPUTE

TALK.START.PARA: Mr Speaker, may I have your indulgence to provide information to the House in answer to a question asked of me earlier this afternoon by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke)?
—The honourable gentleman may proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I give the following information to the House in answer to the question asked of me earlier this afternoon by the honourable member for Wills concerning comments by Mr Commissioner Vosti about the conduct of the Public Service Board in a case relating to a reclassification claim by the Professional Radio and Electronics Institute of Australasia: Firstly, the Public Service Board has received and is analysing the report by Mr Commissioner Vosti referred to by the honourable member. Secondly, the report-this is important for the House to understand-is a report to the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Thirdly, the Board has informed me that it does not believe that the criticisms made by Mr Commissioner Vosti are at all fair. Fourthly, the Board is preparing a submission to be presented to the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which will address, amongst other things, certain of the points made by Mr Commissioner Vosti and will be contesting them, both on the grounds of fact and interpretation. In those circumstances, I think that it is proper-I believe that the House will agree-to have the processes before the Full Bench take their course. After that has occurred, I will assess what Mr Commissioner Vosti has said and what the Board has said in the light of what emerges from the consideration of the matter by the Full Bench.

—I do not know whether the Minister for Industrial Relations had a chance to mention this matter to my colleague the honourable member for Wills. I think the Minister has encouraged debate because those who are aware of the problem know that, whilst the Public Service Board may take another view, the evidence given clearly indicates support for what the Commissioner has found. This is not just a recent matter. It is a misuse of the forms of this Parliament to be making the sort of explanation now that the Board will try to justify itself again. I think it has already had its chance and failed. I think it would have been appropriate for the Minister to give his answer tomorrow when the honourable member for Wills could have had a chance to ask him a further question.

—It is always a difficulty for the Chair, not knowing what is going to be said. I gave my indulgence on the basis that had the Minister been informed of these matters at the time that the question was asked he would have been able to give the answer. That is the reason why I gave my indulgence. But I do not propose to permit debate because there is no question before the Chair for debate. I think it is now a matter for the honourable member for Wills, that information having been provided, to consider whether he will take any course of action.

—Mr Speaker, with respect, I am at a disadvantage. I had no indication from the Minister for Industrial Relations that there would be any course of action. It seems to me, apart from anything else, that it would have been courteous to give an indication that that course of action would be sought to be adopted. It seems to me, with great respect to you, Mr Speaker, that the appropriate course to have adopted, as no one's interests would have been disadvantaged, would have been for the Minister to answer the question tomorrow at the normal time and we could have proceeded from there. I am at a loss to know what is intended now. Has the Minister given his answer? I simply do not know what has happened.

—The honourable member for Wills was not in the chamber, through no fault of his. The Minister sought my indulgence to provide information relevant to a question asked by the honourable member for Wills earlier today. At that time the Minister indicated that he would take the matter under consideration or words to that effect and provide information later. The Minister just approached me and indicated that he would like my indulgence to provide information. As I thought that would assist the honourable member for Wills and the House, for that matter, I permitted him to have my indulgence to provide that information. In fact, it was done when the honourable member for Wills was not here and the honourable member for Wills apparently was not informed that it was going to be done.
—That is my complaint.

—The honourable member for Wills will understand that there are conventions about giving indulgence. I give my indulgence if it is for the purpose of providing information to the House. It is not for me to go behind the request to ascertain whether any arrangement has been made or anything of that kind. I suggest that the honourable member for Wills now obtain the concurrence of the Minister to see a copy of the Hansard 'greens' as soon as they become available, which will be quite soon. The honourable member for Wills can then consider any course of action he proposes.

—I am indebted to you, Mr Speaker. I will accept that course. I repeat that I think it would have been an appropriate courtesy in this matter for the Minister to have informed me before he intended to ask for your indulgence in this matter.

—If I may have your indulgence for a moment, Mr Speaker, I thought it appropriate, as has been customary on similar occasions, to seek, at the first opportunity, to provide that information to the House. It has just come into my hands and I did that.
—Will the Minister agree to the course I proposed of authorising the Principal Parliamentary Reporter to provide a copy of the Hansard 'greens' to the honourable member for Wills?
—I am quite happy to do that.
