TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House the fact that the purported amendments transmitted by the Senate raise issues of constitutional significance as a result of the restriction of paragraph 3 of section 53 of the Constitution, which provides that the Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people. The Senate resolved to omit clause 6 and by that action purported to amend the Bill. It has been argued that the Senate does not possess the power to amend the Bill but possesses only the power to request an amendment. My task, as Speaker, is merely to alert the House to the problem. It is for the House to decide the manner in which it wishes to deal with the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That this House considers that the effect of the purported amendments of the Senate would be to increase the burden on the people in contravention of section 53 of the Constitution and therefore declines to take the purported amendments into consideration, and
(2) That the Bill be laid aside.

In the Committee stage of the Senate debate on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill the Senate resolved to remove clause 6 of the Bill. Thirty amendments consequential upon the removal of clause 6 were also agreed to by the Senate. It is the Government's view that the effect of the purported amendments of the Senate would be to increase the burden on the people in contravention of the third paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution. The third paragraph of section 53 provides as follows:
The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

The effect of the purported amendment to remove clause 6 is to increase the minimum amount of the Commonwealth's expenditure under the Bill and, hence, increase the amount of the appropriation as the Minister would not have the power to make the determinations that would result in a reduction of the amounts payable to the States. The Senate could, however, have requested the House of Representatives to make the amendments instead of exceeding its constitutional power in the way it has done. But a Governor-General's message, pursuant to section 56 of the Constitution, would be required before this House could agree to such requests, if made. The purpose of section 56 of the Constitution is to deny to private members any right to initiate measures for the expenditure of the public revenue and to keep the initiation of such expenditure in the hands of the Government, which has the overall responsibility of relating total expenditure to total revenue. This fundamental tenet of our Constitution has been breached by the action of the Senate in relation to this Bill. Therefore, on those grounds, I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the motion on the ground that, legally, the problem is not what the Government says it is. Mr Speaker, I think you might share our view-and we do not want to embarrass you on this point-because you said in your message on this occasion that you wanted to alert the House to the problem. I think that is very fair. Earlier, when we had another problem with the Senate which was anxious to press its requests in respect of sales tax legislation you expressed the view that it should not be entitled to press its requests. We agree with you. On that occasion, the pressing of requests would have amounted to seeking to exercise a function to which it was not entitled as it had already rejected the Bill once. But on this occasion, Mr Speaker, I think you might share our views again because you have only taken us to the point of alerting us to the problem and I do not think it is as the Government states.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members look at the Constitution, they will see views about types of laws, whether they appropriate money for annual services or whether they impose taxation. It becomes very clear that the Senate may not amend laws which appropriate money for the annual services of government. Consequently, I draw a distinction between laws that the Senate has power to deal with and those with which it has not power to deal. The Opposition remains very firm-it has not deviated from the point-that the Senate has no right to deal with annual appropriation Bills by altering the appropriation. The Government is really drawing a long bow in this case when it says that this legislation deals with the annual appropriation. Let us make it very clear. Under clause 6 of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill (No. 2)-that is the clause which has been the subject of some discussion-the Minister for Education has the ability to determine tuition fees in respect of students undertaking later degrees. But the Bill gives an appropriation in toto which is completely sufficient to furnish the requirements of tertiary facilities.

There is an additional provision in the Bill that, if the Minister decides that fees have to be paid by students who undertake later degrees, the amount payable to each State will be reduced by the amount of fees collected. So this measure could not possibly increase the charge or burden on the people. It is quite ridiculous to argue, as the Government has argued quite unconvincingly, that anything that might have the effect of increasing the appropriation or, to put it more accurately, decreasing the deductions from the appropriation necessarily involves a burden on the people. That is complete nonsense! The point I make is very clear. There will be no taxation burden as seen in the terms of our Constitution. This will not be one of those issues. Of course it would suit the Government to state in a Bill: 'We will give you a sum of money and that is the Bill that provides it'-it has appropriated that sum of money-'but we would like to reduce it if we decide to charge fees'. The Government could not possibly say that that is increasing the burden on the people. The appropriation has been made.
Section 53 of the Constitution states:
The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

That is the only argument on which the Government could hang its hat at the present time and this Bill does not enable it to do that. In no way does the Bill, as designed and prepared by the Government, increase the charge or burden on the people. Perhaps what it is doing is increasing the burden on the Government which has already appropriated the money in the Bill. All it is trying to do is decrease its burden to which end it has already appropriated the funds. The Government is saying: 'Perhaps we can unload some of that burden by making students pay extra fees'. Naturally we do not in any way support this view.

The Government would get itself out of its dilemma in this matter if it supported the new constitutional alteration proposition of fixed term parliaments that the Opposition put forward in the Senate. This proposition has a clause which states that any Bill appropriating revenue or moneys or imposing taxation shall be deemed to be passed by the Senate, whether it passes it or not, 30 days after it is transmitted to it. It is appropriate that, if that is the view that the Government now has, it might get going about a constitutional amendment and support the Opposition's legislation in the Senate. Then we would be ad idem on the issue. Matters such as this cannot be the subject of some ping-pong arrangement where the matter is continually transmitted between one House and the other. We must get on with the business of Government. The Government has a mandate and has brought down a Budget. It has responsibilities, fiscal and otherwise, and the Senate should not interfere. The Government as elected by the people should run its term of office. In 1974-75, we were not given that concession but our argument has not changed. It has always been that a government is entitled to its annual appropriation. The Senate agrees with that. But this measure is not an annual appropriation.

The Senate also has power to amend Bills but it cannot do this in a fashion that would increase a charge or burden on the people. The amendment does not do that. I make it very clear that it is time that something was done about the constitutional change and a bipartisan attitude is the only way to get it. At the present time the Bill in the Senate says what I think everyone in Australia would applaud, that is, when a government puts forward laws that appropriate revenue or revenue which imposes taxation and these laws go to the Senate that chamber can certainly transmit a message on it but that is about all. It is not to hold on to the legislation for more than one month because, after one month, it shall be deemed to have been passed. Mr Speaker, I think you would agree with that proposal. No longer would we have the spurious argument that the Government advances in this case, that is, that the Senate does not have any power to deal with this Bill. The Senate has the power to deal with it and it justifiably deals with it. It is a matter of great concern to all people in the tertiary field that they may have to pay fees. But, if honourable members look at this matter in terms of the law, it is a specious argument to suggest that this amendment in any way increases the burden on the people or increases taxation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join this debate briefly to support the remarks that have been made by my deputy leader. What the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen) has pointed out very clearly is that the effect of the Senate's amendment does not increase the burden on the people in a way which would infringe section 53 of the Constitution. I repeat section 53, the provision in question, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

In its original pristine form, the Bill provided that certain grants would be made by the Commonwealth to universities, colleges and the technical and further education sector via State governments. If the Minister for Education took two separate actions, the level of those grants could be reduced by amounts determined by the Minister. The action which the Minister needed to take was that he may determine levels of fees not exceeding certain amounts and in respect of certain groups of students. That is, he was not saying that he would determine certain levels of fees. The power did not require the Minister to do that. It simply gave him a power which he could exercise if he felt like it. If the Minister did determine that fees would be collected in respect of certain students at certain levels, he could take a decision to reduce the amounts of the grants to be made to the colleges or the universities. Or, if he was of the view that certain fees should be collected, he could reduce the grants by an amount which he thought should have been collected by way of fees and which equalled that amount.

The two discretionary powers which the Bill was to give to the Minister were: Firstly, he may determine fees and, secondly, if he does, he may decide to reduce the amounts of the grants to be made to individual universities and colleges. It means that, as a result of the Senate's amendment, there was no prospect that the level of the grants to be made to universities and colleges could have been increased. The effect of the amendment was not to achieve that result. The maximum level of the grants was set by the original Bill. So there was no prospect of the Government having to find more money than was already included in the Bill as presented to this House. If the power to determine fees remained in the Bill then there was some prospect that the level of grants may have been reduced. But there was no absolute guarantee that there would have been any sort of reduction because, as I have already said, it relied upon the Minister exercising two separate discretionary powers.

I think from that we can see that the Government draws a very long bow indeed when it says that because the Senate decided to remove the Minister's power to set fees-a power which he may never have exercised in any event, even though he said he would-that would increase the burden on the people. The Minister and the Government arrived at this situation in the Senate because of the botched nature of this proposal. The proposal to reintroduce fees in this form came not from the Department of Education or even from the Minister for Education. It came from the Lynch Committee reviewing Commonwealth functions. It is a hobby-horse of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) which he has entertained ever since those sad days when he was Treasurer of this country. On one occasion, I think in 1976, he proposed that the Government would reintroduce fees in this form. He was defeated on that proposal in the Cabinet. He has waited and has bided his time. Now, when he had another opportunity to pursue this matter he included it in the report of his committee reviewing Commonwealth functions. But it was put up in such a way that the Government would simply be able to re-establish the principle of fees while at the same time ensuring that its effect was fairly limited as far as the Government was concerned.

The Minister wanted to be able to exclude from the imposition of fees all students studying for their first qualification. Indeed, that provision remains in the Bill as amended by the Senate. As well as that, the Minister wanted to require students doing certain combinations of first qualifications to be charged fees. When students were doing one or more first qualifications, either consecutively or concurrently, the Minister wanted some of them to pay fees and some of them not to pay fees. It was a very ill-defined group to which the exclusion would obtain. Therefore, the Minister wanted to reserve for himself the power to determine which students in this group would pay fees and which would not. Again, in relation to post-graduate students and students studying other forms of higher degrees, the Minister wanted some of these students to pay fees and some of them to be excluded from the burden of fees. But again it was not possible, in the way in which the Government presented this proposal, for the Bill to go into the detail in relation to which of these students would be paying fees and which would not. The Minister wanted to keep to himself the power to determine which of these students would pay fees and which would not.

As a result of the Minister keeping to himself this large number of discretionary powers-firstly, whether fees would be charged at all, secondly, to which group of students the fees would apply and, thirdly, the amount at which the fees would apply-we then get to the second problem where, having decided to charge fees at a certain level in respect of certain students, he may or may not have decided to reduce the grants available to universities and colleges, either by an equal amount as collected by fees, or by some other amount as he determines.

The net result of all of these discretionary powers which the Minister was given in the original Bill meant that there was an extraordinarily tenuous connection between the power of the Minister to set fees, the level of grants and the amount of money which was required to be spent by the Commonwealth in respect of universities and colleges throughout Australia. If the Government really wanted to sustain its argument that the removal of the power to determine fees would, in fact, directly lead to a reduction in those grants and, therefore, reduce the burden on the Government's coffers-as has been stated by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition-then there would have to be a very much more precise requirement in relation to the setting of fees. Indeed, there would have had to be a very much closer, tighter linkage between the collection of those fees and the reduction of the grants made available to the universities and colleges.

The Government's problem is really entirely of its own making. The proposal was ill-considered. It was not, in my view, supported by anyone who was serious about the problems confronting tertiary education in this country, particularly the problems confronting Australia's research effort. However, the Government was landed with this problem as a result of the Lynch Committee report. But then the Minister wanted to ensure that it applied to the smallest number of students in such a complicated way that in the end the connection between the payment of fees and the reduction of the grants, or the increase of the burden on the people-whichever way one wants to put it-was extraordinarly tenuous indeed. Under those circumstances I do not think the Government can in any way sustain the argument which it has put to the House this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also oppose the Government's motion. I do so for a number of reasons. Firstly, this is an extraordinarily loose means by which the Government is seeking to appropriate funds if, in fact, it maintains that this is an appropriation of funds. I point out that the clause in question being deleted from the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill in no way alters the appropriation in the Bill. It takes away from a Minister of the Crown the right to determine whether or not the appropriation will be a certain amount, or whether a part of that appropriation will be raised from a section of the people as opposed to Commonwealth revenue. I think that is a distinction which has not been made during the course of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government says that it increases the burden on the people, it increases the burden on some people, if the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) applies the terms of the provisions which have been deleted from the Bill. The only increased burden which could be involved is where the Minister imposes on the States an obligation to raise certain money as an offset to moneys which are already appropriated by this Bill, which obligation is then deleted from the Commonwealth grants and, in fact, becomes an additional burden on a section of the people. This is not only a loose means but also a means which obviously has been devised by draftsmen to get around this Parliament's attempt to use its monetary functions to impose a condition on the States' operation of universities which fall within its constitutional power. The Commonwealth Parliament could not impose a condition of that sort in legislation of its own. This Parliament could not legislate to impose fees on any sections of universities as it is outside its constitutional powers. So we have a provision in this Bill where a general appropriation is made to provide the States with financial assistance for universities. A clause within the legislation provides for the conditional application of fees to be imposed under the States grants legislation in a manner which would be unconstitutional and would be opposed in separate legislation.

There can be no question that any appropriation is involved in the clause which is under consideration in this Bill. The Bill does not specify any amount. It does not specify any fees which will be charged; rather it provides the Minister, at his discretion, with an open-ended opportunity to alter the amounts of grants which will be made to the States from this appropriation. It could well be that under this clause the Minister could impose a fee of $1 and reduce the grant to the States by $1m. These matters are not co-related. There is also no suggestion of a relief from taxation or a relief of the burden on the people. It can be argued that there is a transfer of the burden, a transfer from Consolidated Revenue and the appropriations which are made to Consolidated Revenue, to a limited number of persons on whom a fee is levied by the States in exchange for the funds which are provided for in this Bill.

This is a loose or a smart Bill-one can take one's pick of which term to use. Certainly the appropriation whereby the Parliament gives its rights over the appropriation of moneys to a Minister of the Crown is not of the type which should be made by either House of the Parliament. This Bill transfers the rights to determine that appropriation. I use an extreme case as an illustration. It would be possible to bring in an Appropriation Bill under which an amount is appropriated, as in this Bill, to cover the general appropriations required for the running of the Administration. A clause could be written into the Bill enabling the Treasurer or another Minister to vary those amounts both within the legislation and in total in accordance with the wishes of the Treasurer or that Minister. In other words, if this is, in fact, legislation which meets the criteria of the Constitution and with which the Senate is not able to deal, it is also legislation which is capable of being manipulated in such a manner as to take away from the Parliament totally the right to consider appropriations in a fixed form-a form determined by the Parliament. This is an appropriation which has a rider attached to it in the form of the clause which has been deleted. This clause enables a Minister to alter that appropriation in any way in which he so desires. He has only to meet one basic requirement. There is no provision for off-setting reductions in the appropriations in accordance with the amounts of the fees.

The Government is seeking in this legislation to create a situation where, under its policy of reducing the general level of skills and the availability of training in this community, education is restricted to those people who can afford to pay. This is a very dangerous precedent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman is now speaking to the merits of the clause; this is a different motion.

—It is a dangerous precedent whereby a government seeks to move around its constitutional powers by providing legislation which enables it to impose on others-without specifying in this Bill what it is seeking to impose-an obligation to enact laws in exchange for the wherewithal to maintain tertiary education in this country-tertiary education being accepted as a financial obligation of this Parliament. Such a government could impose laws which this Parliament would find to be beyond its constitutional powers if it sought to pass them as separate legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Viner's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Fife)-by leave-proposed:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the introduction and passage through all stages without delay of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill [No. 2], the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose the suspension of Standing Orders. The suspension of Standing Orders will allow the House to consider and deal with the legislation to provide grants for universities and colleges around Australia and, of course, the Opposition would not want to hold up that process. That is something which ought to be facilitated as quickly as possible. We are happy also for the Government to reintroduce the rewritten sections dealing with the imposition of fees in a separate amending Bill. We are happy for that process to proceed because we know that when that matter goes to the Senate it will be rejected again. No doubt the Government will seek in three months beyond that date to introduce that legislation again, to see it again defeated by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: We are perfectly happy to have the question of tertiary fees being one of the matters on which a double dissolution election is fought. The Government was not courageous enough to say before the last election that it intended to take this action. This will force it out of the dark, out of the background, and force it to declare its hand at the time of the next election in respect of tertiary fees. It got away with misleading the people last time; it will not get away with misleading them again. The chances are that the legislation to reintroduce fees will be the first piece of legislation setting the scene for a double dissolution of this Parliament. We are happy to see that occur. We are happy to fight the Government in the Parliament and on the hustings on the question of tertiary fees, not just because of the issue involved, but also because we know that if the Government were ever allowed to re-establish the principle of tertiary tuition fees it would want to extend it to cover all undergraduate students, which would do enormous damage to universities and colleges around the country. For that reason we are happy to facilitate the consideration of these Bills this afternoon and this evening.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Government has reconsidered its position in the light of the action taken by the Senate to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill and the Australian National University Bill to delete the limited tuition fees provisions, and also to reject the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill which dealt only with fees. The Senate has disagreed with the House in two important respects. It has not been prepared to endorse the provisions of the Bill passed by the House which authorise the limited reintroduction of student fees for selected second and higher degree students, and it has also taken a contrary view to the Government as to the Senate's powers in respect of this legislation. During the debate in the Senate the Government argued that the Senate did not have the power to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, but it did not dispute the right of the Senate to request amendments to this legislation. The Senate, however, decided that it did have the power to make amendments and proceeded accordingly. The Government regarded the Senate's action as contravening section 53 of the Constitution and it invited the House to set aside the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill in the form received from the Senate. The House has done so.

The Government is now proposing a new measure which will provide for the program of grants to the States without the fees provisions to which the Senate objected. If the House approves this Bill, we will then introduce a separate Bill to amend the first Bill to restore the fees provisions. In the case of the Australian National University, we will propose that the House accept the Bill as received from the Senate. When that has been done, we will introduce amendments to restore the fees provisions. The Government is not proposing to take any action for the present about the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill which the Senate rejected.

The Government has had to keep in mind that the principal purpose of the legislation is to appropriate funds totalling approximately $1,725m for the universities, colleges of advanced education and tertiary and further education institutions in the States and the Northern Territory for 1982 and further appropriations for some areas for 1983 and 1984 also. Provision has also to be made for cost adjustments in respect of the program for the 1979-81 triennium. Many institutions will be short of funds by late December unless this legislation is passed in sufficient time for the appropriate instalments of approximately $300m to be made available from the Commonwealth through the State treasuries to the institutions. Their position will be made worse if further instalments of about $100m cannot be made in late January. The grants reflect the Government's approval of the financial recommendations put forward by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in respect of State and Northern Territory institutions and in accordance with the guidelines announced by me on 4 June 1981. On 23 September I tabled Volume 2 of the Commission's report which responded to the guidelines.

The Bill is in the form of the Bill received from the Senate except for some minor differences to overcome technical defects in the amendments adopted by the Senate to remove the new tuition fees provisions. In putting forward this Bill without the tuition fee provisions, the Government has recognised the urgent need to ensure that funds will be available to tertiary institutions in the States to proceed with their approved programs. Some funds are yet to be allocated for 1983 and 1984 and will be included in subsequent annual amendments. However, the Government will continue to press for the limited re-introduction of tuition fees for universities and colleges of advanced education. The Government accepts that fees should not be charged to first degree or diploma students, but it believes that students entering second diploma or degree courses or higher degree courses should pay tuition fees. These fees would be applied to a minority of students and would represent a small contribution to the cost of operating the institutions.

The inclusion of this tuition fees provision in a States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill as a condition to the grants for recurrent expenditure for universities and colleges of advanced education is the only mechanism open to the Commonwealth by which it can take legislative action. There is absolutely no question of the Government attempting to tack-on some extraneous matter to an appropriation Bill. The Commonwealth has the sole responsibility for financing the universities and colleges of advanced education and has the authority to make a decision about fees and to attach that as a condition to its grants. It has been the practice since the grants for the 1974 academic year for the States grants legislation for tertiary institutions to include a condition requiring the States to ensure that the universities, colleges of advanced education and TAFE colleges do not charge tuition fees. The Government has sought to continue that provision, except for second and higher degree students. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For reasons which I have already outlined, the Opposition does not oppose this legislation. I take the opportunity to note, however, that the Government has done what it should have done in the first place, that is, retreated from the extraordinary decision of the razor gang to impose these fees. As I said before, this proposal was not new. It was defeated when Senator Carrick was Minister for Education. He clearly opposed it. The fact that is was revived on this occasion was a source of huge embarrassment to the current Minister for Education (Mr Fife). I am sure that he, of all the Ministers in this Government, would be breathing a great sigh of relief at being able to see the passage of this legislation providing for grants for universities and colleges without the requirement that fees be charged in respect of certain students.

SPEECH.PARA: When we were last dealing with this legislation, I referred to the inadequacy of the level of funding and the fact that it does not represent, as the Minister has sought to maintain, the implementation of the recommendations of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. It diverts from the recommendations in a significant regard, firstly, and particularly, in relation to the capital requirements and, secondly, in relation to the recurrent requirements insofar as the Government's election commitment, its extra new expenditure, has to be met from within recurrent expenditure close to that recommended by the Commission for continuing to maintain the current level of quality and quantity within universities and colleges. However, those points were canvassed on the earlier occasion and we are keen to see the speedy passage of this Bill not only through this House but through the Senate as well.
Sitting suspended from 5.59 to 8 p.m.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Fife) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the limited reintroduction of tuition fees in tertiary education institutions in the States and the Northern Territory. The Bill specifically excludes the charging of tuition fees for students undertaking courses leading to first degrees or diplomas. It also exempts students, who commenced second degree or diploma courses before 1982, from paying fees for those courses, and it sets a maximum fee of $1000 per annum. Subject to these limitations the Bill contains a provision for the Minister to make determinations as to the circumstances in which students should be charged tuition fees or be exempt from such charges. The Bill provides as a condition of recurrent grants that institutions charge tuition fees in accordance with these arrangements and that they do not charge tuition fees in other circumstances. The Bill provides for recurrent grants scheduled in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 to be offset by an amount equivalent to the money from tuition fees which those institutions will be required to charge. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of the issues which are involved in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 were canvassed when the legislation was previously before the House as a composite part of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill in its first version. The Government had intended that the grants made to the States for passing on to universities and colleges would be conditional upon the requirement that the universities and colleges charged fees in respect of certain students and at certain levels as the Minister determined. It is history now that the Senate jacked up on that part of the legislation. Now the Government has decided to attempt to enact those provisions separately. The Government is attempting to amend the Bill which passed this House about 30 seconds ago. If it were successful, of course, it would reinstate the original version of this Bill as it was presented earlier in this session. My guess is that when this Bill gets to the Senate it will receive the same treatment that the clauses of the earlier States grants legislation relating to this matter received a couple of weeks ago, that is the Senate will reject it. The Government will then attempt to introduce the legislation again after a period of three months. If the Senate again rejects the proposal, as I predict it will, the Government will have the first of its pieces of legislation to constitute the grounds for the calling of a double dissolution. We are not the slightest bit perplexed or daunted by that prospect. We know that the Government will not want to fight an election on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to go back to the last election to discover the reasons why the Government, particularly the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), ran into trouble with this proposal. The Government made certain undertakings prior to the last election in relation to tertiary tuition fees. When we consider the power of the Senate in respect of what governments want to achieve and what they put to the people at the time of elections we have to accept-I put this very forcefully-that the Senate must use its power very carefully. We in the Australian Labor Party would go much further and say that the power of the Senate in respect of a number of issues ought to be substantially truncated. To the extent that the Senate has the power and retains it, it must, in our view, use that power judiciously. Firstly, if a government puts a proposal to the electorate prior to an election I think there is an obligation on the part of the Senate, unless extraordinary circumstances intervene, not to frustrate what the government has a mandate to implement. If the government has said before the election that it intends to do things then legislates to carry out those undertakings I believe the Senate ought to pass those proposals.

There is a second category of measures, those for which the government has no mandate and which it did not mention prior to the election. In those circumstances the Senate is entitled to consider the matter on its merits. Then there is a third group of measures, those for which the government has absolutely no mandate on the basis that it undertook, prior to the election, not to implement them. It is a sort of reverse mandate. The government may have promised not to do something and may subsequently attempt to do it after the election. It is a sort of electoral fraud. In those circumstances the Sentate is duty bound in my view to keep the government to its undertakings and force it to abandon any proposal which absolutely and directly contradicts what it said prior to the election. I refer to what the Minister said on 8 October 1980 in an article produced in the Australian newspaper. I will read one paragraph. In a prepared statement the Minister said:

There continues to be speculation about Government plans to re-introduce fees for tertiary education. I have given an assurance publicly and I repeat that assurance, that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible reintroduction of tertiary fees.

That is a specific undertaking. The Minister and certain other members of the Government have subsequently sought to quibble with the fine print of that paragraph. They say it did not mean that the Government would never reintroduce fees but that it did not have anything under consideration on the day the statement was made. That quibbling has to be disregarded because there is no doubt at all what meaning the Minister intended to convey in that statement. The Minister was trying to dampen and quash speculation about Government plans. That is what the first sentence referred to. The Minister stated:
There continues to be speculation about Government plans to reintroduce fees for tertiary education.

The Minister wanted to kill that speculation and to leave in everybody's mind the impression that the Government had no intention of reintroducing tertiary education fees. Yet it took just a few months for the Government to abrogate that promise via a decision of the Lynch Committee, the razor gang, which recommended-the Government accepted the recommendation-the partial reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees. So quite clearly the Government went to the people before the election and said that it would not do it and then a few months later said that it was going to do it. Under those circumstances the Senate not only is empowered but also has a duty to keep the Government honest in respect of those sorts of undertakings which it gives prior to an election. I repeat that that is the main reason why the Government has run into trouble on this measure. However, the proposal itself can be opposed on its merits regardless of whether there was this problem of the breaching of an election undertaking.

In the first instance, the proposal intends to re-introduce fees for post-graduate students, higher degree students and second degree students; that is certain categories of students who are not exempt. This proposal, if enacted, would strike quite directly at the heart of the research effort carried on in universities and colleges around Australia, but more particularly in universities. That research effort has already been greatly affected by the reduction in funds over a period of years in relation to general research funding which has been made available by this Government through a variety of sources. It has to be acknowledged that post-graduate students are central to the research effort of universities. They are the ones who are responsible for very much of the research effort. Even if the research itself is directed by full time members of the university community, the post-graduate students are fundamentally important to the carrying out of that research.

As well as that, this proposal represented a quite specific penalty directed at anyone who had the nerve or gall to undertake any sort of post-graduate education to get a second degree. Those classes of student were selected for this specific penalty of up to $1,000 a year. The quaint thing about it was that those people who had some measure, inadequate as it is, of public, university or college support by way of post-graduate awards were not to be charged the fees, and those who had no public support were to be specifically penalised in this way. It really is impossible to justify that sort of approach and to impose that sort of penalty on that quite specific, quite limited group of students. There is no question at all that it would have had a severe impact on the level of enrolments next year in those courses to which the fees apply.

It has been impossible to obtain any idea, in direct terms, of what the effect on enrolments might have been quite simply because the universities, at least in relation to post-graduate students, are the ones more particularly involved and their enrolment figures are not available until early next year. In any event, one suspects that because of the impending imposition of these fees a lot of people would have enrolled late this year in courses which they intended to undertake next year in order to escape the imposition of the fees because, as the Government made it clear, there was no intention to apply the fees to those people who were already enrolled. So it may have been in this first year that the effect of enrolments would not have been all that severe for that reason-that is for next year-but in succeeding years there is no question that in respect of those who were required to pay the fees it would have been quite substantial.

The point that we particularly took exception to was that the Government was quite clearly trying to re-establish the principle of fees. It always has been keen. There is a very active and noisy group on the back bench in this House and in the Senate which is desperately keen to see university fees and college fees reintroduced for the undergraduate level as well as the post-graduate level. The numbers are variously estimated at anything from 20 to 30, which makes the group a quite sizable and influential minority within the Government ranks. This measure, partial as it was, was a sort of a sop to those people to keep them happy until such time as the Government could extend, when political circumstances might have been more favourable, to include undergraduate students as well.

The Minister can say for as long as he likes that there was no intention to reintroduce fees for undergraduate students, but the Minister unfortunately has to live with the fact that his word after the last election is no longer reliable and nobody believes a word he says. He broke a promise made at the last election and no one will believe him ever again. I suspect that that is why he will not be in this portfolio for very much longer. He will be off to other pastures where he can make new commitments and break those commitments subsequently.

The members of the noisy group on the Government back benches have constructed very elaborate arguments about the importance of the user-payer principle in relation to higher education. They argue that the benefits from higher education accrue to the community and to the individual and, therefore, there should be a contribution from both in respect of the cost of providing that education. At the same time they go to great and windy lengths to indicate there is a great bias in terms of the socio-economic composition of the university population. They point to the fact that the university and college populations consist of the sons and daughters who substantially come from the wealthier part of the community. They seem to ignore the fact that the imposition of fees will do absolutely nothing to improve that situation, but rather will exacerbate the problem to make universities and colleges more and more the preserve of the sons and daughters of the rich. They have made no attempt to demonstrate how the imposition of fees will create one extra place for somebody not already enrolled in a college or university.

The second point which they seem to assume erroneously is that Australia already has enough enrolments in the higher education area. We heard an even less elegant version of this argument from Senator Harradine a few nights ago. Senator Harradine in the end supported the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats in knocking out this fee proposal, but he spent a lot of time during that debate frothing at the mouth about how this had something to do with the fact that it made it easier and easier for a whole lot of bludgers to clog up the universities to the exclusion of kids from middle and lower income families. Somehow these people who were sitting around, in his words, doing their fourth and fifth degrees were denying places to kids from families headed by service station proprietors and the like. He went on at great length.

In the first case Senator Harradine, and I suspect others, labour under a huge delusion. It is no picnic hanging around a university with no public support. It has to be recognised that anybody doing a second qualification gets no Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance, no scholarship and no public support at all. People are not entitled to social security benefits if they are involved in full time education. So anybody who is involved in doing a second qualification either has to have substantial private means or must be extraordinarily determined to undertake that course at a huge private cost. Whilst students may not have to pay fees, they certainly have to support themselves during the undertaking of that course. As well as that, this whole argument, the whole user-pays argument, the whole reference to the bias in terms of the university population, ignores certain important facts; that is, if we are concerned about access to tertiary education we should ensure that everybody who qualifies for tertiary entrance should be allowed to proceed regardless of their economic circumstances. It was that problem which exercised the mind of my predecessor in Fremantle, the Labor Minister for Education, Mr Beazley. He talked about bringing in a revolution of access through the introduction of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. He understood the problem. He understood that the statistics were very unfavourable. Even today something like 18 per cent of the university and college population come from 5 per cent of the most wealthy families in the country, while another 18 per cent come from the poorest 50 per cent of the families in this country. He set about trying to correct that distortion, and quite rightly so. What he did was to try to improve the financial support which was available to those people who had qualified but who, for economic reasons, under the old arrangements were not able to undertake a tertiary education. What honourable members on the other side of the House fail to address themselves to is the question of how the imposition of fees would do anything but exacerbate the sort of distortion which we set out to try to correct.

This also raises the question of the overall participation rates in higher eduction. What we have seen is a shift, a reduction, in the full time enrolments in colleges and universities over the last few years. There has been a fall of about 20 per cent in the number of kids who are going straight from school to full time education in universities and colleges. That is a matter of great concern to us and it should be a matter of great concern to the Government as well. In 1974, about 18 per cent of kids who finished their final year of secondary school went straight on to university or to college but now that number is down to about 14.5 per cent. That is a substantial fall in just five or six years and it is something which we ought to be concerned about. In that regard I quote a few lines from the most recent report of the Tertiary Education Commission. The Commission, in referring to the fact that one of the reasons which the Commission identifies as the cause of this problem is the inadequacy of student financial assistance, says:

In the context of changes to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) and the introduction of a loans scheme, the Commission believes that it should draw the matter again to the attention of the Government. Both the increasing pace of technological change and the fall in the number of full-time jobs for teenagers make it important that able young men and women avail themselves of educational or training opportunities. A decline of one-fifth in the participation of young people in higher education is surely a matter for community concern. It runs contrary to Government policies relating to technological change and to transition from school to adult life. It raises questions about Australia's long-term capacity to meet the challenges ahead of it.

When we couple those statements with the fact that more and more kids are dropping out of school earlier and earlier and therefore not even getting to the starting gate in terms of entrance to tertiary education, we really see the magnitude of the problem beginning to unfold before us. That is why we are so adamant that the question of fees should not proceed, that it is a matter which ought to be rejected on principle. We are deeply concerned about access to tertiary education. We are deeply concerned about improving participation rates in tertiary education. We are concerned about seeing kids from poorer families staying at school longer so that they get a chance to get to universities and colleges and that when they get to the starting gate they have sufficient financial support to ensure that they actually proceed with that education. Mr Deputy Speaker, I have mentioned to the Minister that I want to incorporate in Hansard a small section from the Tertiary Education Commission report. I now formally seek leave to have it incorporated.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PARTICIPATION IN HIGHER EDUCATION

1.10 Table 1.3 sets out student numbers in higher education from 1974 to 1981. Total enrolments have continued to grow over the whole period, although the rate of growth has slowed in the last few years. There has, however, been a major shift from full-time to part-time and external study. Not only have full-time enrolments declined as a proportion of total enrolments (from 63.5 per cent in 1974 to 53.2 per cent in 1981), but over the past four years they have declined in absolute terms: there are now nearly 12,000 fewer full-time enrolments than there were in 1977.

The decline in the participation of the young is clearly illustrated in Table 1.4, which gives numbers of students, by sex, commencing higher education direct from school, and the proportion they bear to the 17 year old population. In absolute terms, there has been a decline of nearly 4,000 between 1977 and 1981. As a proportion of the age-group, the numbers declined steadily from 1974 to 1980; for 1981 they are about the same as for 1980, that is, about one-fifth less than they were in 1974. 1.12 In Volume 1 (Part 1, paragraph 9.15) the Commission indicated its concern with the decline in the participation of the young in higher education. In the context of changes to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) and the introduction of a loans scheme, the Commission believes that it should draw the matter again to the attention of the Government. Both the increasing pace of technological change and the fall in the number of full-time jobs for teenagers make it important that able young men and women avail themselves of educational or training opportunities. A decline of one-fifth in the participation of young people in higher education is surely a matter for community concern. It runs contrary to Government policies relating to technological change and to transition from school to adult life. It raises questions about Australia's long-term capacity to meet the challenges ahead of it.

1.13 As pointed out in Volume 1 (Part 1, paragraphs 2.30 and 2.31), the decline in the participation of young people in higher education appears to be related partly to their assessment of the benefits of higher education and partly to the availability of financial support for full-time study. The latter is a matter for Commonwealth Government policy. Since 1975 a major source of support for undergraduates, namely the teacher training scholarships awarded by State education departments, has been virtually eliminated. Moreover, the real value of grants under TEAS has been eroded by inflation and the real severity of the means test increased. The reversal of the downwards trend in the participation of the young will, at the least, require improved financial assistance to students. One possible way of achieving this is through a loans scheme. The Government has announced its intention to introduce such a scheme; this may increase access to higher education, although its impact will depend on the availability of credit, the conditions under which loans are made, and the arrangements for repayment.

1.14 In Volume 1 (Part 1, paragraph 7.15) the Commission supported the charging of fees for non-award courses; the Commission, therefore, does not argue against the charging of fees for courses of a continuing education nature. However, the Commission is concerned that the Government's decision that tuition fees should be charged for second and higher degrees runs counter to the Commission's support for increased emphasis on enrolments for higher degrees in universities (Volume 1, Part 1, paragraph 9.16). The situation could be improved if revenue from fees were used to increase support for higher degree students.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the limited re-introduction of tuition fees at the Australian National University. The principles involved in this Bill are the same as those in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all struck with a quaint sense of deja vu because the House has just rejected these propositions and and they are now being represented to us. We are now being asked to agree to proposals which the Government has just acknowledged should not be enacted in this legislation. It is a charade which the Government wants to go through because it recognises that it cannot get through the Senate a proposal for which it has no mandate and a proposal which it specifically promised it would not attempt to enact. This proposal relates to the Australian National University which, unlike all other universities in this country, is a legislative responsibility of this Parliament, set up by this Parliament and therefore its statutes can be amended by this Parliament along the lines of this sort of legislation. Of course, for reasons which I went into when a similar Bill was before this House and for reasons which were elaborated on in the Senate by an Opposition spokesman, we will oppose the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take advantage of this occasion to raise a couple of arguments that I would have raised on the previous Bill-the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill had I had an opportunity, but as this Bill contains the same principle that opportunity is presented to me now. I am sorry that these measures are being dragged through the House in the way in which they are because they are being made the basis, in announcements by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), of the possibility of a double dissolution. I would have thought that, before the country was put through that trauma, some sort of explanation might be offered as to why it should be. No explanation has been offered here to this point. I am concerned that, in the general community, there may be an impression that what has been happening to this Government in the Senate on the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 3) (1981) and other Bills is similar to what happened to the Australian Labor Party when it was in office between 1972 and 1975. The circumstances are, of course, completely different.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1972-75 we had a government in office which sought to enact a program which it had obtained a mandate from the people to enact. Approximately 80 Bills were either rejected or severely amended during that period by the Liberal-National Country Party majority in the Senate. On this occasion we have a piece of legislation for which no mandate has been sought. Indeed a reverse mandate, if I can put it that way, has been given because the Government gave undertakings not to introduce fees. Nevertheless it has proceeded to do so. It is a very sad reflection, I think, on the quality of the relationship between this Government and the electorate that it should have seen fit to do that.

I make one or two other points which relate to the Australian National University. I can make them more directly on the ANU because it has the particular courses to which I wish to refer. I think that the Government, having decided that it wishes to proceed to the point where a double dissolution is threatened on this matter, has to present an argument to the Australian people that this is a weighty and sufficient issue to go to that expense and trauma. A reasoned analysis of this proposition suggests that this is nothing of the sort. In the first place this Bill in particular and the other one passed today raises negligible revenue. At the very best it would not be 40 per cent of one day's expenditure on education in Australia and it would probably raise much less. In the second place, it imposes a regressive burden on poor students. Pious statements have been made that what we have to do with this legislation is make people pay for the education that they are receiving but of course some people will pay and others will not.

For example, consider the case of a business student at the ANU who is doing a Master of Business Administration. That business student will now be obliged to pay, if this legislation goes through, $1,000 a year in fees. Let us assume that that business student, as is most likely, is a government employee or a businessman. That person will be able to relate that fee to efforts made to expand his earning capacity related directly to his job. The Taxation Commissioner will permit a tax deduction. The MBA student will therefore be able to claim, if he is on an income of $25,000 or $30,000 a year, at least $500. Therefore, $500 will be all that that student pays. The same situation applies to a lawyer who is seeking to do a Master of Laws degree. Such a student if he is a lawyer on a similar sort of income will be able to make precisely that sort of claim. However, this will not apply to a person who seeks to move on in qualifications from a Bachelor of Arts degree to a Master of Arts degree if that person has been funding his own education through university on the basis of a part time role in the work force and a part time role in the university. Very considerable damage will be suffered by such a person because a tax deduction will not be open to him and he will be living on pittances and will be obliged to pay an extra $1,000.

The Government has not looked into the question of tax deductibility of these fees and the impact of that on the revenue that it will raise from it. I know that the Government has not done this because I asked a question in the appropriate estimates committee as to whether it had. I was told that the Government had not considered that matter. A very important element of equity in this proposal-this most inequitable proposal-has not even been considered by the Government and that I think is a scandalous situation. The proposition hits at the very heart of the voluntary reseach effort in the Australian community, in this legislation the voluntary research effort in Canberra. Let there be no doubt whatsoever about that.

Whether a person has to pay for his education has an impact on whether he or she will go to university. There is precious little research published on this matter by the Government. One would have thought that it would have made some effort to do something, given that it was introducing this legislation. However in its recent publication, 'Studies of Tertiary Student Finances', something does come out. Several pieces of research, which have been done at Government expense and privately, have revealed substantial numbers of students who are dropping out of tertiary education for financial reasons. One of the principle categories, this report states, is:
Students of mature age, possibly married, highly motivated but finding it difficult to meet their long-term financial commitments.

Unquestionably, those sorts of students will find themselves even more damaged. A student, who enters university or a College of Advanced Education on the basis of a mature judgment, will be the student who will find himself or herself disadvantaged and excluded from the education process.
This report concludes with the statement:

In summary this section has presented a review of recent literature and research (primarily Australian) related to the importance of financial factors as an influence on student progress in tertiary education. The studies demonstrate that financial factors are of some importance to progress in tertiary education. But there is clearly a need for more research in order to investigate the types of students whose progress is most likely to be affected by financial factors, and the ways in which insufficient finance contributes to the decision of these students to withdraw from tertiary education.

Throughout this report there is no assumption that students withdraw on the basis of inability. They withdraw on the basis of inadequate finance. This Government really ought to have done some work on that matter before it introduced this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Honourable members will be aware that clauses precluding spouses of persons involved in industrial action from receiving unemployment and special benefit were deleted by the Government from the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981 during its passage through the Parliament. This was done pursuant to a request of the Senate, not because the Government agreed with the request, but to prevent delay in the passage of the remainder of that Bill which, inter alia, authorised the payment of additional unemployment benefit to single beneficiaries aged 18 years and over. In deleting those clauses, the Government announced that fresh legislation containing those provisions would be introduced at the first available opportunity. This Bill introduces those provisions.

Before October 1979, the Social Services Act precluded payment of unemployment benefit to a person who was a direct participant in a strike. However, it enabled unemployment benefit to be paid at the 'married' rate to the spouse of a person ineligible for unemployment benefit on those grounds. The Act was subsequently amended to provide that unemployment benefit payable to the spouse of a person engaged in industrial action was to be at the 'single' rate. A further amendment precluded payment of special benefit to a person who, because of industrial action, was not qualified to receive unemployment benefit.

This Bill now proposes that, for so long as a person's spouse is disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit because of involvement in industrial action; or unwillingness to undertake suitable work; or failure to take reasonable steps to obtain such work, that person will also be ineligible for unemployment benefit. Additionally, persons will be ineligible for unemployment benefit for so long as payment of that benefit to their spouses is postponed because of their misconduct as a worker, because they have become voluntarily unemployed or because they have failed to accept an offer of suitable employment.

Consistent with this approach, special benefit will also be withheld from persons not eligible for unemployment benefit in these circumstances. The Government has decided, however, that if a person is precluded from receiving unemployment benefit and special benefit, in a case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support, his or her spouse may be eligible for special benefit at the single rate, with additional benefit for any children.

We are not here concerned to discuss the merits of strike action as contrasted with other means open to employees in dispute with their employers to resolve these disputes. What we are concerned with is how the cost of strike action is to be borne. The Government holds strongly to the belief that these provisions should become law. In the case of the provisions relating to industrial action, we do not believe that Australian taxpayers should be asked to subsidise strike action through the social welfare system.

Trade unions choosing to take such action make a free decision to strike. If they choose to take such action, they should bear the consequences of their action, not the tax-paying community. Trade unions cannot expect, in those circumstances, that the rest of the community will pick up the bill for the support of the families of members of the trade union involved in the strike. The legislation as it stands at the moment permits a situation where trade unions can choose to strike, knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members can be largely insulated from the financial effects of their actions.

Unless frivolously or maliciously entered into, the object of a strike is to obtain, by the exercise of economic pressure directed against the employer, a benefit for those who take such action. As a result, the benefit sought is itself economic, such as increased pay, a shorter working week, or special allowances. Not infrequently, strikes are settled on a basis that effectively compensates those who have gone on strike for pay lost during the duration of the strike. The point to be emphasised is that to strike is an exercise in freedom of choice. It is one taken by the membership of a union to promote its own interests and only its own interests. It is taken against the interests of the employer and, what is directly relevant to this Bill, it is one which is not taken in the interests of the community as a whole.

Indeed, the effect of strike action is often in conflict with the interests of the community as a whole or some part of it. Frequently, the community suffers as a result of strike action. This may be reflected simply in inconvenience or in terms of direct economic cost. Furthermore, in a larger sense, it may be said that in the longer term the community always suffers as the cumulative result of the strike action is to decrease the availability of goods and services, and sometimes to do great damage to particular sectors of the economy, or to particular employers. These matters need only to be mentioned to make clear the absurdity of any argument that benefits should be paid to strikers or their families, and should be paid by the community at large. For it is the community at large that provides through taxation the funds from which strikers are presently paid the benefits that this Bill proposes to eliminate.

There have been numerous cases where the wives of strikers, who have appeared to have no genuine intention of joining the work force themselves, have registered for work in places such as mining and construction towns where there is no real possibility of employment for them. This has enabled them, under the existing legislation, to obtain unemployment benefit, and so transfer to the taxpayer some of the real cost of the industrial action taken by their husbands. So, the Australian public is attacked from two directions. First, it has to bear the personal disruptions, inconveniences and associated costs that result from the strike. In addition, it is then called upon to meet the cost of providing income support for the families of those involved in the strike.

To act to correct this situation is not to 'punish' the families of strikers but to ensure that people accept the financial consequences of their own actions and do not look to the rest of the community to bear the costs. Similarly, there is no good reason why the community should automatically and immediately be expected to assume the normal financial responsibilities of people who are not willing to work, who voluntarily and without good reason give up their job or who are dismissed through their own misconduct. This is happening at present because the spouses of such people can register for employment in their own right and, if they are unable to obtain employment, can claim unemployment benefit both for themselves and their 'dependent' spouses. We believe that whether people refuse to work because of industrial action or whether, in some other way, they show themselves unwilling to enter or remain in the work force, there is no reason why the rest of the community should shoulder their financial responsibilities. This Bill prevents them from manipulating the social security system to shift the consequences of their actions. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Honourable members will be aware that the Social Services Amendment Act 1981 extended the scope of the double orphans' pensions provisions in the Social Services Act 1947 to enable those pensions to be paid to persons having the custody, care and the control of refugee children who are admitted to Australia where the parents of those children are outside Australia, or the whereabouts of the parents of those children are unknown.

A technical, but important, defect has been found in the definition of 'refugee child' in the legislation and this Bill will amend that definition to cover all children the Government considers should fall within the extent provisions. The existing legislation defines 'refugee child' in terms of a child granted refugee status by the Australian Government. There are, however, children who are admitted into Australia as refugees who do not have the formal status of refugee granted to them. The Government intends these children to fall within the class of children in respect of whom double orphans' pensions are payable. In addition, there are children admitted into Australia otherwise than as refugees, under special humanitarian programs, whom the Government considers should be regarded as within the class of children in respect of whom double orphans' pensions should be payable. I am sure that honourable members will share the Government's concern that the double orphans' pension provisions be extended in respect of those groups of children who came to Australia whose parents are outside Australia or the whereabouts of whose parents are unknown. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW AIR TRAFFIC SERVICES CENTRE AND CONTROL TOWER, PERTH AIRPORT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following elements of the work known as the construction of new air traffic services centre and control tower, Perth Airport, Western Australia, which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Air traffic services operations building, technical maintenance centre, radio equipment building and services building.

The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has recommended the construction of these elements which are estimated to cost $2.7m. The Committee recommends also that a start on the construction of the control tower element estimated to cost a further $0.9m be delayed pending completion of a master plan for the Perth Airport. The Government notes the Committee's intention to report further on this element and its siting in the light of the completed master plan. These conclusions are acceptable to the Government and a start on the control tower will accordingly be deferred although detailed planning of the tower to minimise potential delays will continue in accordance with the Committee's recommendation.

The Committee has further recommended that discussions with the Western Australian Government should be re-opened with a view to setting up the Western Australian Airfields Committee within six months. The Commonwealth will move to re-open these discussions as recommended. Finally the Committee recommends that the Department of Transport should re-examine the public parking at the airport to ensure it is compatible with peak loads. This recommendation also will be implemented. If the House agrees to support this motion planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sought to intervene in this debate very briefly as the representative for the area in which the work is to be done. As I understand it the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) seeks approval to proceed only with the work approved by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and not that which the Committee recommended be held over until a master plan for the development of Perth Airport is produced. I think the Minister's statement is to be welcomed on that basis. I welcome also his statement that the Commonwealth Government intends to pursue the establishment of the Western Australian Airfields Committee. I understand that the Commonwealth Government and the Department of Transport have not been the problem in establishing that Committee; it has been the State Government that has resisted its establishment. No blame is to be attached to the Commonwealth Government for its not being created hitherto.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Works Committee's recommendation followed substantial input and appearances before it by local authorities in my area and a number of local members of parliament including myself. I think an explanation is appropriate here as to why we sought delays in the construction of a new control tower-delays which the Minister has accepted. In the first place there is substantial concern in my constituency that no major construction which might pre-empt some options on future airport developments should be undertaken prior to a full consideration of those options in a master plan for the future development of the airport. This master plan was promised to the local authorities in my area as a result of recommendations published in 1979 by a joint committee consisting of representatives of Commonwealth, State and local governments in the area. It has yet to emerge though it is apparently being rushed through the process now.

The control tower related to these considerations because that which has been proposed by the Department of Transport and the Department of Housing and Construction would be unsuitable for one of the options under consideration in a master plan. I refer to the construction of a wide-spaced runway parallel to the present north-south runway. For this latter development to proceed an additional control tower to the one currently under consideration would have to be constructed at considerable expense to the Commonwealth. The local authorities in my area, particularly the Belmont Shire Council and the Canning City Council have put forward excellently argued propositions pointing out the very substantial number of additional houses that would be affected by airport-related noise and environmental pollution if the parallel runway option is not to proceed. It is very important that we keep faith with those authorities as they have, by associating themselves with the 1979 Joint Committee report, taken the unusual step of moving beyond the expected stolid opposition to the presence of the airport in their area to accepting it under certain conditions jointly agreed with the Commonwealth. There are not too many local authorities around Australia that, given the opportunity to argue a case for the removal of an airport, would actually come to those conclusions. That makes keeping faith with them very important.

One of the related considerations which must affect the timing of when the control tower should proceed concerns the question of compensation. Given that the control tower as proposed obviates any immediate development of a north-south parallel runway, another promise of the Joint Committee comes to mind; that is, the Joint Committee argued that, if a properly considered master plan recommended on economic grounds that the parallel runway should not proceed, the residents should be paid compensation to insulate their homes. The Department of Transport has written to the councils asking them to research the environmental impact of the usage of the airport in their area. I hope that this is not a blind but a prelude to legislation for compensation. I hope also that we will not see the master plan rushed through in an ad hoc fashion to accommodate early construction of the tower and later the new international terminal. The Minister's acceptance of the Public Works Committee's recommendations would be made a mockery of were that the case.

As I said, I welcome the Minister's acceptance of the recommendations. I welcome the other announcements made by the Minister and the fact that the Government is now consulting with the local authorities on the question of compensation. I hope that we will jointly achieve a development that is satisfactory to all the parties concerned-the users and neighbours of the airport.
