TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am grateful for those comments. They appeared to be very practical ones. I will draw them to the attention of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) for use on the appropriate occasion. I think it is always good when local members show an intelligent interest in what is going on in their electorates and bring matters of concern to the local people to the attention of the appropriate authorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament, namely: Redevelopment of Brisbane International Airport-Further dredging and reclamation.

The proposal is for the execution of further sand dredging and site reclamation associated with the balance of phase one works, including the provision of a cross runway and general aviation areas. In reporting favourably on the proposal the Committee has made certain other recommendations and comments. The Committee indicated that it holds serious doubts as to the quality of the planning co-ordination between the Department of Transport technical divisions involved and was critical of the failure by the Department of Transport during 1979 to perceive the evident major disadvantages in the simultaneous operation of the two airports at Brisbane. Although there is no doubt that the two airports could be operated together, it was only during the design development stage during 1980 that some earlier assumptions regarding operating and equipment costs were found to be too low and the full costs of such an operation were realised. The Department of Transport moved immediately to rectify the situation and proposed to the Government in June 1980 that a cross wind runway should be provided and the existing airport closed when the redeveloped airport is commissioned.

The Committee also concluded that a completion date of 1986 rather than 1990 for the full phase one works has not yet been clearly justified and went on to state that evidence to be put before the Committee on the remainder of phase one must provide such a justification. The Government commitment is to a 1986 commissioning date for the redeveloped airport. The Committee noted in its report that aircraft noise disturbance will be removed from 3,500 houses at that time. The Government is keen to take advantage of this noise reduction at the earliest opportunity in the interests of the people living in the noise affected area and this is one of the many benefits to be derived from the 1986 target commissioning date.

While the Committee has noted that it was satisfied with the broad master plan concept, it expressed concern that the public information program did not provide information on the master plan as put before the Committee. The public information program referred to was directed at the provision of the cross runway and hence did not cover the aspect of the full airport master plan layout. The basic airport master plan was first shown to the public in the media in 1971 and has been demonstrated on many occasions since. The Department of Housing and Construction and the Department of Transport are about to open a public information centre on the airport site and I can assure the House that the airport master plan forms part of the display in that centre.

The Committee suggests that the Department of Housing and Construction monitor the effects of dredging on the environment and on fishing and prawning. Such monitoring is being carried out and will continue. The estimated cost of the proposed work examined by the Committee was $16m at February 1981 prices. The Committee recommended construction of the work in the reference. If the House agrees to support this motion, detailed planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Capital Assistance) Bill now before the House authorises the payment of capital grants to the States for the current financial year and for the first half of the year 1982-83. The first six months of next financial year are included to allow time for the Parliament to pass similar legislation next year. The capital grant which the Commonwealth has to pay to the States for this financial year as a result of this Bill is $436m, which is the same amount as last year despite an estimated inflation rate of 10.75 per cent for this financial year and which is almost the same money amount as the Commonwealth paid to the States in 1975-76 despite the fact that there has been rapid inflation throughout the period since then. In fact the real value of this grant has fallen by nearly half since 1975-76, that is, the grant the Commonwealth is proposing to make this year will buy only about half as much this year as it would have in 1975-76. Is it any wonder, therefore, that the States are protesting? However, I will come back to their reaction in a few minutes after discussing the Commonwealth's payment to the States more fully.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) began by explaining that capital grants by the Commonwealth to the States were introduced in June 1970 by a Liberal-National Country Party government. This ritual self-congratulation appears in the Treasurer's speech on the States Grants (Capital Assistance) Bill every year. In fact I have the impression, on reading this speech, that the Treasurer has simply taken out last year's speech, changed the dates and the amounts-he has not had to change the amounts very much-and read it out for, as usual, the speech is repetitively self-justifying and misleading. Perhaps it is not surprising that the Treasurer wants to get the credit for making a grant to the States-even a small one-but he neglects to say by how much this grant has fallen in real terms over the last few years. It is certainly the task of the Opposition to provide this perspective.

This Bill authorises payment of the grant component of the Loan Council program for State Governments in 1981-82. The total funds available to State governments for capital works this financial year is $1,307m, of which the capital grant I previously referred to is one-third. The real value of these capital funds has fallen by 44.6 per cent since 1975-76, a very considerable decline indeed. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which shows general purpose capital grants for State governments.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It shows the payments to State governments for general purpose capital funds for the years 1975-76 to 1981-82. It shows that there has been a steady decline in the real value of those funds throughout that six-year period. This means that the States' finance for works such as schools and other capital works from which debt charges are not normally recovered has fallen dramatically under the Fraser Government. This is the reason for the inadequacy of many community facilities; it is why schools are not being adequately repaired; why the conditions of many prisons are appalling; why the police often work in archaic buildings, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: In his second reading speech on this Bill, the Treasurer tended to argue that this sharp fall in the real value of general purpose capital funds for the States did not matter because other funds for the States have been increasing. He mentioned, for example, that total funds to the States from the Commonwealth are estimated to increase by 8.5 per cent this year in comparison with 1980-81. However, he neglected to mention that, in his Budget Papers, he presented an estimate of the rate of inflation for this year of 10.75 per cent. This means that the real value of total funds for the States from the Commonwealth is expected to fall by 2.25 per cent this year, that is, the 8.5 per cent increase in funds compared with the 10.75 per cent inflation rate. Further, this neglects the effect of population growth. During the last 12 months, the population grew by 1.6 per cent. There were 240,000 more people in Australia in June of this year than in June of last year. When the population is growing funds for government services have to expand or the quality of those services declines. The Government has made no allowance at all for this in its payments to the States. The real value of total Commonwealth payments to the States this year is almost 4 per cent per person less than in the last financial year. The Treasurer's comments are, therefore, severely misleading. Is it any wonder that the States are having trouble balancing their Budgets and are being forced to raise their taxes and charges?

The Treasurer also tries to get some mileage out of the fact that the relative importance of specific purpose payments has fallen. Specific purpose payments are allocated to a particular expenditure purpose and the States must spend them in that area. Whilst it is clear that the States want maximum control over what funds are available to them, the decline in the relative importance of specific purpose payments is completely irrelevant if it is not matched by a compensating increase in general purpose payments. In fact, the reduction in specific purpose payments is one of the important reasons for the real fall in the value of Commonwealth payments to the States. Another ploy used by the Treasurer to cloud the issue is to talk about the increased borrowing approvals given to the States' semi-government authorities for infrastructure projects. Infrastructure projects relate to resource development, and include such things as power stations, coal loaders, harbour developments and so on. Infrastructure borrowing approvals in 1981-82 totalled $807m. However, these go nowhere near compensating the State public sectors for the decline in the real value of their capital funds. In 1975-76, the last year of the Labor Government, a total of $4.2 billion was budgeted by the Commonwealth, under various headings, for State public sector capital works. By 1981-82 this amount had grown to $5.4 billion but this was a real decline, once inflation was taken into account, of 29.4 per cent. Thus, the real value of total capital funds available to the States fell quite sharply between 1975-76 and 1981-82.

That decline is substantial enough but as it relates only to the States it could be said that it does not necessarily show that the total public sector capital expenditure has been adversely affected because it does not show the situation for government as a whole when one takes into account the Commonwealth sector as well. To partly rectify that I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing real planned public sector capital expenditure for 1975-76 to 1981-82.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This table is very interesting. It shows the allocations in the 1975-76 Budget and the 1981-82 Budget, the one which operates for this financial year. It compares the amounts in real terms for the allocations to capital expenditure under various headings for the Commonwealth sector. The allocation from the Commonwealth Budget has declined by 58 per cent in real terms. The allocation in the Commonwealth sector for statutory authorities has declined by 16.6 per cent in real terms. The total Commonwealth public sector capital expenditure in real terms has decreased by 30.7 per cent. These are not just minor adjustments to the accounts. They are dramatic cutbacks in the size of public sector capital expenditures. They are enormous cutbacks which have horrendous effects on the abilities of the Commonwealth and the States to provide the level of services which was provided previously. They have enormous implications for the social infrastructure in particular. I will say a little more about that in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the expenditure by the States in this table we see that general purpose capital funds-the funds which are the subject of the Bill now before the House-have declined in real terms by 44.6 per cent, the figure I gave previously. That is an enormous reduction. Specific purpose capital payments have declined by 56.7 per cent, a reduction of more than half in real terms. The total payments to the States in the capital area, excluding infrastructure, have declined by 39.9 per cent. If we take into account infrastructure borrowings which began in 1978 and which have enabled the States to spend in particular areas in relation to resource infrastructure projects, we see that the total capital funds available to the States have declined in real terms by 29.4 per cent. That is an enormous reduction in the total amount of funds available to States for capital expenditures, including infrastructure borrowings. If we put all those areas together and look at the total capital expenditures for the Commonwealth and State sectors and at the real movement in capital expenditures over the six-year period we see a reduction of 28.5 per cent. That amounts to absolute sabotage of the public sector and its ability to maintain an appropriate level of capital works for this nation. They are quite devastating figures. They bring to light the enormous damage that this Government is bringing about in this country through its continued ideologically based cutbacks and slashes in the amount of real capital funds being made available to the public sector.

It can be said, of course, that the table shows only what has happened to funds which have been specifically earmarked for capital expenditure and that other funds are available to the State governments, for instance, through the general revenue grants which can be spent on anything although they are normally spent on recurrent expenditures. It is argued by the Government, not least the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) who is now at the table, that these funds are available to the States to spend on capital works if they so wish. To this let me make two comments. Firstly, the real value of total funds made available to the States by the Commonwealth from its Budget-not just total capital funds but total funds-this financial year is, as I mentioned before, 2 1/4 per cent less in real terms than the last financial year. If there is less money from the Commonwealth Budget as well as markedly less money for capital works specifically, it is impossible to argue that the States can easily maintain capital expenditures by utilising their general revenue grants unless the Commonwealth is saying to the States that they should spend much less on recurrent expenditures, including salaries for school teachers and workers in the public sector generally, which are the main areas of recurrent expenditures. If that were to happen it would clearly have implications for the level of services provided by the States.

Furthermore, if one looks at the total funds from the Commonwealth Budget to the States over the period from 1975-76 to 1981-82 one finds that there has been a substantial real decline in the level of funds made available. It has declined by approximately 10 per cent. I stress this figure to the House. There has been a 10 per cent reduction in real terms in the total amount of funds made available to the States by the Commonwealth in the period 1975-76 to 1981-82. In the period of this Government's control of this country since the end of 1975 the real level of funds has been reduced by 10 per cent when the population has increased by 8 per cent. On a per head basis, therefore, there has been a decline of 18 per cent in the real level of Budget funds made available by this miserly Government to the States. So much for the argument that lesser funds to the States from capital allocations in the Budget can be made up from other Budget payments not allocated to any particular purpose. It is clearly an absolute nonsense given the size of the total cutback in funds to the States of 18 per cent in real terms on a per capita basis. Furthermore, when one takes into account not only funds from the Budget but also funds available to the States and the Northern Territory from outside the Budget, that is through semi-government borrowing programs and the so-called infrastructure borrowing program, it is clear that there has still been a substantial real fall in funds made available to the States. Between 1975-76 and 1981-82 there has been a fall in the real level of all funds made available to the States from all sources in the Budget or outside the Budget of 5.3 per cent. Even if we include the borrowing programs of the States there is a 5 per cent reduction in the real amount of funds made available to the States. When we take, as we must, account of the fact that there has been a population increase in the period of 8 per cent we see that there has been a 13 per cent real decline in funds made available to the States by the Commonwealth from all sources inside the Budget and outside it.

Another point that has to be made in this regard is that because of this reduction in funds to the States, especially the drastic cutback in funds for capital expenditures, there has been a consequential severe decline in the overall level of government investment in the country. The national accounts for the year 1980-81 show that the real level of public gross fixed capital expenditure in Australia-in short, government investment-during the period 1975-76 to 1980-81, the last financial year, declined by 11 per cent. That is a very substantial reduction in the real level of government investment in this country in that six-year period. Furthermore, we are saying that there is 11 per cent less government investment in toto in real terms than for 1975-76. If one takes into account the 6 1/2 per cent rise in population in those years, one sees that on a per capita basis the decline was 17 1/2 per cent.

This is a very severe reduction in the total level of government investment in this country. There has been a 17 1/2 per cent decline since the Labor Government was in office in the levels which operated last financial year, and they will presumably be down further in this current financial year. These are quite staggering figures. They give the absolute lie to Government arguments that cutbacks in capital expenditures can be offset by the use of other expenditure. This Government knows from its own experience that it is far more difficult politically to reduce recurrent expenditure than it is to reduce capital expenditure. The result of this Government's actions in cutting back its own capital expenditures and slashing capital funds to the States is that government investment has been devastated by this Government. That process is continuing in this current financial year. The Bill before the House is clear proof of my assertion.

Four points flow from this fact. The first point is that the impact of this severe reduction on the economy as a whole is substantial. If one cuts back on the level of government investment-which is an important part of the economy-in such severe terms, then each year a negative growth factor is being built into the economy and the possibilities of obtaining substantial economic growth are to that degree lessened. In terms of the overall rate of economic growth and employment growth we see that such cutbacks are absolutely adverse. Secondly, there is the impact of these continuing reductions on the quantity and standard of services provided by government. If one continually slashes the real level of government investment, as this Government does year by year and continues to do in the Bill now before the House, inevitably one will find it more difficult to provide government services of a capital nature and of a recurrent nature. There is a cut back for the whole array of services provided through what is known as the social infrastructure; that is, the array of services which are needed by people if they are to live decent lives in this community such as in the area of education, decent hospitals, roads, public transport, welfare housing, child care and so on. All of these areas must be affected if the Government continually cuts back on the level of government investment.

Thirdly, by these cutbacks in government investment we have a severe unbalancing of the economy because within government investment that is occurring the growth area is resource industries infrastructure; that is, power stations, coal loaders, railways and so on. The social infrastructure, the areas that I have just mentioned a moment ago, are the areas which are taking the burden of the reduction. There is an overall reduction of government expenditure which is absolutely severe. Within that level of investment is a growth area of resource investment. So the social infrastructure, which is the rest of that investment, is where the burden of reductions is being felt. We are reaching the stage where that reduction is becoming thoroughly intolerable.

Fourthly, there is the irony of the situation that despite this sabotage of public sector investment the Government still argues that government expenditure, particularly government capital expenditure, is the cause of increased interest rates. After today's report perhaps interest rates are very much in the news. I refer to the Government's argument that the cause of increased interest rates is the high level of demands for funds in this community and, therefore, what we need to do is to cut back government demand for funds. This has been the continuing refrain of this Government and is a justification for the cutbacks in government investment in this country. It hangs on the thread that interest rates are determined by the demand for funds in the capital market. Quite clearly, the increase in the demand for funds has not come from the public sector. How can it be said that the increase in demand for funds has come from the public sector when government investment has been slashed heavily?

I am sure that honourable members are all aware that the public sector borrowing requirement has been considerably reduced in the last year or two. How can it be said in that situation that the government sector is causing this rise in interest rates and that the appropriate response to that situation is to slash the level of government expenditure even further? It is an absolute absurdity to argue in that way. If we look at where the demand for funds is coming from, we need only to look at what has happened to business investment. Business investment last year went up by 23 per cent which is an extraordinary increase very much related to the resources boom. That increase must be where the rapid increase in demand for funds has come from and to which one must describe the interest rate pressures if one says that interest rates are determined by the demand for funds in the capital market. In these circumstances it is absurd to argue that government investment is the cause of rising interest rates or that an appropriate response to rising interest rates is to further slash government investment. Such investment has already been sabotaged by this Government, as I have clearly shown. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not opposing the Bill, the House is of the opinion that the Bill, by further sharply reducing the real level of funds for State government capital works, is-
(1) making it impossible for the States to provide an adequate capital expenditure program;
(2) reducing the extent and standard of community services;
(3) undermining the efficiency and productive capacity of many industries especially the building industry;
(4) producing unbalanced development by facilitating expansion of infrastructure for the resource industries while severely contracting expenditure on the social infrastructure;
(5) increasing unemployment, and
(6) intensifying pressure on the States to introduce a second income tax'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Mr H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The remarks we have just heard from the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) demonstrate that the Australian Labor Party is irretrievably wedded to big government and, more than that, to big spending government and, therefore, either inevitably spiralling taxation or an increased deficit and hence increased government borrowing and spiralling interest rates. The Bill that we are debating, the States Grants (Capital Assistance) Bill, provides non-repayable capital grants to the States of $435.75m. This grant component of the Australian Loan Council program for State governments of $1,307.25m was agreed to at the June Loan Council meeting. These grants were initiated by a Liberal Country Party government in 1970.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the States are free to apply the grants as they choose, the major purpose at that time was to help finance schools. It is therefore appropriate in debating this legislation to discuss the relative responsibilities of Federal and State governments in the sphere of education. This is especially so in the light of the growing practice of gross misrepresentation of the attitude of the Federal Government towards education, especially as regards funding. The facts on the Federal funding of education do not support the hostile reaction that has been generated through teacher organisations, academic staff associations and student political bodies in concert with the Labor Party. I therefore welcome the opportunity this debate provides to set the record straight. Over nearly six years since the Fraser Government came to office it has effectively fulfilled the proper role of the Federal Government in education by maintaining adequate funding. This was again demonstrated in the recent Budget with the provision of $3,254.7m for education this financial year. This represents an increase of nearly one per cent in real terms; that is after allowing for inflation over the period 1979-80. That, in turn, follows a one and a half per cent increase in real terms in that year as against 1978-79. When combined with funds provided by the State governments which in fact have the major constitutional responsibility for education, over $7000m per year or $20m every day is being spent by governments on education in Australia. That takes 6.1 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. So one could be excused for treating the criticism of the Federal Government's education policies and programs with some scepticism. That scepticism is as valid of criticism of its approach to the school sector as is its approach to other sectors of education.

One source of criticism of the Government's policy in regard to the school sector has been the minority statement by two members of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. It should be noted that this was a minority statement not supported by the other nine members of the Schools Commission. An examination of the minority statement reveals those criticisms to be totally without substance. The minority statement criticises other members of the Commission for not condemning the Government over guidelines given to the Commission. This completely ignores the fact that the annual report is not the appropriate vehicle for such comments. The role of the annual report of the Commission is to carve up the financial resources provided by the Federal Government following its consideration of the recommendations contained in the triennial report of the Commission. If any comment on the guidelines is justified, the triennial report is the appropriate vehicle, not the annual report.

The minority statement also criticises the Government for its selective acceptance or rejection of single recommendations in the triennial report of the Commission. But surely that is exactly what the Government should do. The role of the Commission is to give public advice in its triennial reports to government as to what the Commission sees as needs in education. The role of the Government is to assess that advice in the light of its own policies and available resources and to determine priorities for action. If the Government merely gave blanket acceptance to advice by the Commission, in reality the Commission and not the Government would be governing.

The minority statement also criticises the removal of some discretionary powers from the Commission following recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the so-called razor gang. But every change made in this regard has been to the benefit of those to whom programs are directed. For example, the Government prevented the Schools Commission from laying down detailed guidelines for the Severely Handicapped Children's Program. This is because great variety exists in preferred methods of providing for the education of severely handicapped children. Detailed guidelines of the Commission would preclude this necessary and beneficial variation. Similarly, the decision to administer the Special Education Program through a non-government committee supervised by the Schools Commission rather than as previously by State education departments, removes a source of disagreement and recognises variations in need depending on the type of handicap involved.

Criticism of the Federal Government's allocation of financial assistance to schools in general and to government schools in particular is quite unjustified. The Government has provided $1,008.1m for Schools Commission programs in 1982-an increase of 4.6 per cent in real terms after allowing for inflation. This provides for significant real increases in some programs and maintenance in real terms of most. The cuts in funding involve a modest reduction of $6.3m in a total Commonwealth expenditure on government schools of some $400m. This is quite justified in the light of declining numbers in schools due to demographic trends. The overall real increases are to the Government's great credit. They have been provided despite continuing restraint in Government spending overall and cuts in a number of other areas of Government spending. Thus the Government, in providing $269,174,000 in recurrent grants to government schools has maintained funding in real terms. When related to declining student numbers, this means that Commonwealth funding per student place in government schools has never been higher. It makes nonsense of criticisms of this Government's attitude to the government school sector. There has been consistent maintenance of effort by this Government with regard to government schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to go around and tell that to a few teachers in your electorate.

—I have been going around telling teachers in my electorate exactly that. The result of this maintenance of effort has been that all government schools have reached ahead of target, and many have exceeded, the equipment and staffing goals set as desirable by the Karmel Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission. Federal Government assistance has achieved this, despite the fact that the major responsibility for funding government schools lies with the States, a responsibility which the untied grants provided by this legislation help to fulfil. The States provide some 89 per cent of capital and recurrent funding whereas the Federal responsibility is 11 per cent. The real responsibility of the Federal Government is to identify national needs which have been neglected by the States or forgone. The Federal Government thus has an overseeing role. It must retain flexibility to move funds to fulfil identified national needs.

SPEECH.PARA: In the recent past, resource levels were a national need so a significant additional injection of funds to that area was justified. But, as I have just mentioned, the Karmel goals have now been achieved; so while it is important to maintain effort in that area, as has been done, it is quite wrong to criticise the Government for not providing further large increases in that area because the current major identifiable national need in education is that of transition from school to work. That is therefore the area to which any additional available funds should first and foremost be directed. The Fraser Government is fulfilling its responsibility with regard to school to work transition with a new program of $250m in real terms over five years initiated in 1980. Funds for this program have been increased by 26.6 per cent to $35.2m this year, a real increase of some 15 per cent. This large increase is a clear demonstration of the Fraser Government's commitment to areas of identified need and makes nonsense of the critics. This commitment is further demonstrated by increased funding to other areas of continuing national need-for example, the Special Education Program which is designed to supplement recurrent funding for special schools and schools with special classes to meet the needs of handicapped children and to provide support for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools. By providing $17,768,000 for 1982, the Fraser Government has provided a real increase of 5.7 per cent this year compared with 1981. Similarly, the English as a Second Language Program provides funds to improve the English language competence of students whose first language is not English. Funding has increased by 4.9 per cent in real terms for that Program.

The Federal Government has also been criticised in the minority statement of the Schools Commission and by others for its allegedly favourable treatment of non-government schools. But funding of non-government schools is predicated on a number of factors. Firstly, the Fraser Government believes it has a responsibility to encourage freedom of choice and diversity in education. This does not relate only to the non-government school sector. The Government has also provided funding for a program developing choice and diversity in the government school system. But the non-government school sector is the most significant element of the education system providing opportunity for choice and diversity. Of course, this is a basic tenet of liberalism.

Secondly, those who exercise this choice are entitled to some reimbursement of the taxation revenue they provide to the total education budget, but which they do not use through the government school system. Taxation has some income redistribution effects, not the least in education, but its major role is to pay for community services. It is therefore reasonable that the taxpayer, using an alternative service, receives some reimbursement for that. He or she still contributes to the bulk of the cost of using that alternative service through the payment of fees. To give effect to these elements of choice and partial reimbursement, the Federal Government provides minimum financial assistance per non-government school student of 20 per cent of the assessed average per student government school standard costs. The most recent data for these costs is $1,480 per student for government primary schools and $2,402 for government secondary schools, thereby providing minimum assistance of $296 per non-government primary school student and $480 per non-government secondary school student. It is quite dishonest to claim that resources are being transferred from the government school sector to the non-government school sector in this way. Clearly, grants to the non-government school sector go up only if costs and therefore resources of the government sector go up. Such grants go up by only a small proportion of that government sector increase.

Federal Government assistance to the non-government sector is also predicated on the fact that about 80 per cent of the non-government schools have recurrent resource levels about 30 per cent below those of the average government school. One reflection of this is that primary school student-teacher ratios are 24.4 : 1 for Catholic schools compared with 20.3 : 1 for government schools. Since 1975 the ratio for Catholic primary schools has come down from 27.4 : 1, whereas for government schools it has come down from 22.7 : 1. The comparison at secondary level is: Catholic schools 17 : 1 as against 12.3 : 1 for government schools, having reduced from 19.7 : 1 and 14.2 : 1 respectively in 1975. So, despite being in a significantly better position in student-teacher ratios initially, government schools have not been significantly outpaced in the improvements since then, retaining the significant advantage that they have over Catholic schools. That is why, for these schools, the Federal Government has provided per student grants greater than the basic 20 per cent over recent years.

To ensure that the greatest funding goes to those non-government schools in greatest need the previous six resource categories have been compressed to three with the previous level six alone making up the new group three. Students in group two schools will receive assistance of 30 per cent of the government school standard costs to which I earlier referred, while those in group three schools will receive 38 per cent. For 1982 this provides $444 per primary school student and $721 per secondary school student in group two schools and $562 and $913 respectively for group three schools. Group one school students will receive the minimum of $296 and $480 which I mentioned earlier.

However, one of the main reasons for the increase in funds to non-government schools is simply a matter of numbers. Over the last five years, the number of students in government primary schools has declined by about 1.7 per cent and that decline is projected to continue, while those in government secondary schools have declined by 6 per cent. Over the same period the number of students in non-government primary schools has increased by 5.6 per cent and the number in non-government secondary schools has increased by 6.1 per cent. That is a quite dramatic contrast. In effect, parents are voting with their feet in favour of non-government schools. Instead of bemoaning the fact that, quite justifiably, the funds are following this change in student numbers, those who object should have a good hard look at the reasons for the trend.

Why is it that parents are prepared to make the significant financial sacrifices required, notwithstanding government assistance, to educate their children in non-government schools? Among the reasons becoming evident is the lack of discipline in some government schools and the attitudes and values being transmitted to students by some teachers.

Federal Government support for non-government schools is predicated also on the fact that the Federal Government is the major source of government financial assistance, as a supplement to private effort, for non-government schools, whereas the States are the major source for government schools. The States provide 89 per cent of total government funds for government schools, whereas they provide only 33 per cent of total government funds for non-government schools-that is, capital and recurrent funds. This requires a far greater effort from the Federal Government. However, the critics should admit that not just the Fraser Government has recognised the need of the non-government sector. State governments, Liberal and Labor, have also significantly increased recurrent funding in real terms over the last five years, and by more than the increase provided for the government sector. So five basic reasons justify the Fraser Government's allocation of funds to non-government schools. Not in any way is the non-government sector receiving favoured or special treatment at the expense of the government sector. The government sector contains 78 per cent of all students but receives 89 per cent of government education funds. Non-government schools have 22 per cent of students but receive only 11 per cent of government education funds.

The Bill we are debating tonight provides for untied capital grants to the State governments which they are free to apply in any way they choose according to their priorities. If there is a demonstrated need, they can be applied to education. The Federal Government is therefore fulfilling its responsibility to education not only directly but also indirectly by providing to the States on an untied basis, funds which they may choose to allocate to education. So the criticisms that have been made of various aspects of the Federal Government's education policy are not justified. There is no doubt that this Bill demonstrates the Fraser Government's continuing commitment to providing adequate funds for various projects which are primarily a State responsibility. The States have the opportunity to apply these untied grants to education if they believe there is a demonstrated need. It is on that basis that I support this legislation and urge its speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support wholeheartedly the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). I think it points to some of the key areas of failure in Commonwealth-State financial relations. I am rather sorry that the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman) devoted the entirety of his contribution on this matter, except for a few words at the conclusion, to the question of education because I think that might have been more appropriately considered in one of the education non-debates that the House has managed to have over the last four or five weeks of this sitting. I believe that there are very important points to be made in this House on questions of Commonwealth-State financial relations which are being evaded as a subject of parliamentary debate. I want to deal with them tonight. I want to look at this Bill as one key element of Commonwealth-State financial relations as they have been restructured by this Government. In particular, I intend to consider the impact on Western Australia, my home State and the State worst affected by recent and proposed changes to financial relations with the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has allocated a total of $121m to Western Australia in general purpose capital grant funds for 1981-82, comprising $80.677m in approved Loan Council borrowings and $40.33m in interest free capital grants. Compared with the amount of $120.951m in 1981-82, the allocation to Western Australia this financial year represents a reduction in real terms of around $14.5m. The borrowing program for the State's larger authorities, excluding infrastructure financing, has been cut from a total program of $117.358m in 1980-81 to an estimated $101.6m in 1981-82. This represents a reduction in capital funds from this source amounting to around $31.4m in real terms. Approved Loan Council borrowings for special additions for infrastructure amount to $121.2m in 1981-82. Although Western Australia recevied the most favourable treatment in the total amount of approved borrowings, the level of approval represents around 65 per cent of the State's scheduled borrowings for infrastructure in 1981-82.

Notably, the Loan Council agreed to the States determining the allocation of the approved total between the projects for which the funds were sought. Sir Charles Court, the Premier of Western Australia, has always regarded the infrastructure financing as his project. In 1978-79 he referred to his formal submission to the Loan Council on the subject and went on to say that the new arrangements are a sensible and logical development in Commonwealth-State financial arrangements. In 1979-80 he again took credit for what he called the breakthrough that followed his submission. However, by the 1980-81 Budget, this new tier of borrowings had begun to backfire on Western Australia. Sir Charles Court expressed surprise and regret that general loans funds were being cut to compensate for infrastructure loan funds. This was a virtual admission that he had been conned by the Fraser Government into supporting a move that would clearly hurt Western Australia. The damage is already clear. The level of non-infrastructure loan funds has deteriorated to the point where it is now only slightly more than half the 1975-76 allocation in real terms, that is half the allocation effectively made in the last Labor Budget.

Time does not permit me to discuss the specific uses that the infrastructure funds are to be put to or what could have been done with more general works funds. Some of the proposed infrastructure expenditures are of doubtful value but the general situation of squeezing existing government services on the ground that it is more important to fund the great resources boom can clearly be seen as bad planning now so that even Government Ministers try to dampen any talk of boom or any expectation of benefits for the people of Australia.

To understand the impact of these changes in the allocation of loan funds, it is necessary to outline the broader sphere of Commonwealth-State financial relations and particularly this Government's so-called new federalism. After the Premiers Conference of 1976, at which the financial and administrative framework of the new federalism was established, Sir Charles Court stated:
I am confident that the scheme will now operate successfully and to the advantage of the States.
He went on to say:

These are history making developments and I belive the Premiers' Conference last week will be seen in future years as a turning point in Federal-State financial relations and the beginning of greater State independence and increased self reliance.

He was certainly right about it being a turning point. The direction has been around the bend ever since as far as Western Australian Budgets and the resultant State charge increases on the Western Australian population are concerned.

In 1975-76, total Commonwealth payments and Loan Council borrowings to or for the six States represented 39.1 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays. In 1981-82, the proportion of Commonwealth outlays allocated to the six States is estimated to be 33.4 per cent, even below the level of support in the last year of the McMahon Government at the turn of the decade-1970-71. The net financial effect of the new federalism on Western Australia since 1976-77 and including 1981-82 is a total revenue loss amounting to over $350m. This figure includes the revenue loss of $49.1m which resulted from the abolition in 1980-81 of the guarantee that the State would not be worse off than it was under previous arrangements. This was the guarantee that Sir Charles Court had pinned his hopes on. New federalism for the people of Western Australia has meant higher State taxes and charges, a lowering of living standards and cutbacks in the standard range of essential community services such as health and education. In fact it has been a disaster.

The other factor that must be considered when assessing the impact of these Loan Council allocations over the next year is the Commonwealth Grants Commission review of tax sharing entitlements. The effect of the State factors recommended in the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, based on a six-State distribution, is a reduction in Western Australia's share of Commonwealth tax collections from the existing 12.284 per cent to around 9.826 per cent. The revenue effect amounts to an annual loss of $160.7m, based on the amount available for distribution in 1981-82 and estimates of State population at 31 December 1981. The report of the Grants Commission has been referred back to the Commission for review. It is to be hoped that it will produce an upward revision in Western Australia's State factor, despite whatever incompetence there may have been in the presentation before it of the Western Australian case.

It must be admitted that the Commission's revenue needs assessment for Western Australia is basically accurate and sound. In particular the implicit criticism by the Commission of Western Australia's comparatively low revenue raising effort in the area of mining royalties is vindicated by the fact that the State Government has had immediate recourse to increasing royalties in its 1981-82 Budget. On the other hand, the Commission's assessment of expenditure and business undertaking needs does require drastic reconsideration. The review should expand the field under consideration to include a wide range of basic services such as power, water, housing and other essential services provided by business undertakings in the States. In addition, a more comprehensive analysis of the cost disabilities of providing services of an equal range and standard in remote areas of Western Australia must be undertaken.

The Commission report stated that, in conducting its examination of Western Australia several areas of interest were overflown at low altitude. I suggest that in future the Commissioners might decide to land and have a look at what is going on on the ground; perhaps then they might come to different conclusions about what ought to be done in Western Australia. The Western Australia Government's submissions to the Commission were, however, generally weak and unco-ordinated. This could be a partial explanation, I believe, for Western Australia's relatively harsh treatment by the Commission. Clearly Sir Charles Court failed to impress the Commissioners with his case for Western Australia.

Sir Charles Court attempts to convey the view to the Western Australian community that he has been a solid, hard fighter for Western Australian interests. If Western Australians could only read that extraordinarily lengthy document-I do not blame them if they do not-they would see throughout it evidence of the failure of the Western Australian Government to press the points that it wished to make on matters of key interest to Western Australians. The effective exclusion of power, water and housing from the calculation of State need factors-and in respect of every one of those items Western Australia is at a very severe disadvantage-is an indication of the extent to which the Western Australian Government, despite the fact that these items were within the framework of the Commission's reference, failed to press Western Australia's relative disadvantage in these matters.

To sum up this tale of woe, these Loan Council allocations are but one part of a disastrous situation arising in Western Australia. They express the commitment to the mythical boom that affects the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments. Financial relations between the two have been extraordinary. In the name of States rights, Sir Charles Court has supported major moves by the Fraser Government to slash State spending. He has been conned time and again. It is only now when Western Australia is hundreds of millions of dollars worse off and facing the probability of another disaster from the Grants Commission that Sir Charles Court is beginning to wake up. If he had joined with the progressive State governments, such as that in New South Wales, in opposing these moves from the beginning, these attacks on the States may have been held off. If he had not been so persistent in attempting to bring down the Whitlam Government, his own situation and that of Western Australian consumers of electricity, water and State housing commission homes or whatever would have been far better off than they are now. What State rights have meant in Western Australian is the destruction of the Western Australian State Budget. It is interesting that Liberal governments, one by design and one by incompetence, have done more than any other government since Federation to cripple the State financially, all in the name of State rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past five years, we have seen a massive reallocation of capital spending in this country. The Government has sought to redistribute negatively capital spending from the areas of social expenditure and social need-that is, education, health, transport and housing-providing more and more support for the corporate sector. As the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) pointed out, there has been in real terms a cut of 29 per cent in capital moneys made available to the States, including funds for infrastructure borrowing during the six years of this Government's period in office. The social effects of these transfers of resources are now apparent right across the country. They mean poorer services and reduced standards of living for ordinary people. The Government had undoubtedly hoped that, as a result of these transfers in the distribution of wealth, there would be a recovery in private capital expenditure; that is, companies encouraged by various incentives and tax reductions would embark upon an expansion of activity which would result in an increased rate of economic growth.

SPEECH.PARA: Central to this argument was the assumption that it would be possible to encourage a resources boom-indeed, a resources led recovery. There is no doubt that in part this strategy has had its successes. We have had-albeit unevenly-higher periods of economic growth. We have had an upsurge of investment in certain resource projects. However, this growth has not been subject to any careful planning and would appear to be faltering now with a sharp decline occurring in international markets for resources especially metal markets. The result that is now occurring is a scaling down of resource projects with a number of corporations pulling out of plant projects or threatening to pull out of them. There is a serious danger that, in the pattern of development that has been fostered by this Government, it will be the government sector which will suffer the risks implicit in it. It is quite clear that the public sector-that is, social expenditure but in the final analysis the people-has had to bear the sacrifices. This is apparent in many of the areas to which I have referred.

However, other risks exist to which the same attention has not been given. Much of the public investment which is accompanying resource based development will, in fact, be at risk because of the failure of major projects to go ahead. In 1978 the Government encouraged the States, through their semi-government authorities to go ahead with vastly expanded loan programs especially for electricity generation and other energy-related projects. The States did not need a great deal of encouragement from the Commonwealth and embarked on an enthusiastic program of borrowing. It appears that at this year's Loan Council meeting the Commonwealth indicated that it had had second thoughts about this program. However, we now have, in almost every State of Australia, major public works projects centred on producing more and more energy. Much of this additional electricity will be to service the aluminium industry.

Over the past few months we have seen a massive reduction in the expected levels of development of that industry. So far this year we have had abandoned projects which would have added 600,000 tonnes to aluminium production capacity by 1985. This is without the possible cancellation of the Portland smelter of Alcoa, which is under some doubt. In my view these problems flow from the failure of the Government to interest itself in fundamental policy issues. For example, at the time in which the Federal Government was encouraging the States to embark on a massive expansion of loans for the accelerated development of electricity generation, it was also promising to produce a national energy policy, or at least a Green Paper designed to canvass the relevant issues. In fact the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) never permitted that Green Paper to see the light of day.

The Government achieved what it wanted out of its energy policy which was a massive infusion of revenue from petrol taxes or excise. It has no interest in looking to ensure that the Commonwealth developed an approach to energy policy which related all of the sources of energy or the means of ensuring that energy was distributed to consumers in an equitable manner, or that in the long term we had policies which we would ensure for future generations security of supply. In my view this is an amazing situation. On the one hand we are seeking to conserve liquid fuels by pushing up prices, and on the other hand we are encouraging the use of other fuels, such as natural gas and coal, at a rate as fast as the international market will bear.

But surely the lesson of the last few years is that energy policy cannot be separated in the final analysis into liquid and solid fuels as if they bear no relation to each other. The price of energy is tending to rise domestically whichever fuel one is talking about, with the possible exception of uranium, because of the impact of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries crisis on overall national and international energy policies. I think we are beginning to see the result.

When the Federal Government moved from a cheap oil policy, it was moving towards a dear energy policy across the board. It did not admit this. But that is the direction in which we are being taken as we seek to make energy resources available to the developed world. We cannot imagine for a moment that those companies with an interest in oil are keeping out of the solid fuel areas. Of course they are not. They are buying into alternative sources of energy to ensure that they will continue to dominate the supply of energy throughout the developed world. They have their corporate plans for Australia and it suits them for the Australian Government to continue to talk about the need to leave such matters to the so-called market.

In these circumstances a number of basic issues arise. One of those issues is the matter of energy pricing. With respect to oil we have moved to import parity pricing but with other fuels we have not taken international prices into account. Thus it has been argued by the Department of the Treasury that we need at least to consider opportunity pricing in relation to electricity. Why should we export coal as aluminium at a price which bears no relationship to the price which it might bring as coking coal sold in Japan?

Of course, this is not a simple matter but at least the Government should have addressed itself to it. Similarly, the Government has not sought to require the States to reveal power prices to electricity consumers, such as aluminium producers, before giving loans for expanded electricity generation to meet the needs of those producers. I would have thought that was quite fundamental to the assessment of the viability of such projects.

The Government has made no study of the changing cost structure of the electricity generation industry and what the implications might be for the future. Thus it has been caught unawares by the exponential increases which are now beginning to take place in power prices in a number of States. Indeed, it was recently argued that if further funds are to be drawn by the authorities from tariffs for capital works, this can only mean further massive increases in tariffs. We have seen increases of the order of 40 per cent occur in Victoria over the past 18 months. However, the alternative measure has problems because it will result in the accumulation of a massive debt against future generations of taxpayers.

The Government has consistently taken the view that the planning of energy and energy intensive industries is a matter for the private sector. But there is a real danger that this will mean that the risks are increasingly borne by the public sector while the security and the profits will flow inevitably to the private sector. This in my view, is especially the case in relation to the aluminium industry.

The Aluminium Company of America is currently negotiating with the Victorian Government concerning its proposed smelter at Portland. The company, in the face of a difficult short term market situation, has been threatening to pull out of the project despite the $70m already invested. In the event that it does pull out the State Government will be left with massive commitments to power lines to Portland, and the construction of the Loy Yang power station, the costs of which have been escalating at the rate of $1m a day. The company argues that the enterprise will be only marginally profitable given the present state of international metal markets, especially the first two stages. However, this company is hardly operating in a true market situation, controlling as it does a substantial share of world production. It can afford to plan over a very long period with some confidence that it will eventually be able to wield substantial control over world prices when we have another international economic upturn.

The Victorian Government, faced with an election in a matter of months, is undoubtedly being influenced to make a decision on the terms and conditions offered to the company, under the pressure of a threat to close down yet another major project in the State. For these reasons it is crucial that national policies be determined with respect to electricity and electricity pricing. As the Department of the Treasury has warned there are serious dangers that electricity is being offered to aluminium producers at rates which do not reflect the national economic interest. In part this reflects the fact that we have never faced up to the implications of a policy of electricity for export.

In the present circumstances it is not simply a matter of paying for costs, but a matter of getting a return on Australian resources. Given that we are expanding supply to take advantage of a changing international energy situation the marginal costs are also more relevant than they have ever been. But the marginal cost of supplying electricity is going up dramatically for a variety of reasons. There are the unprecedented high interest rates, the increased demand for expensive anti-pollution devices to be added to power stations, and the diminishing economics of scale associated with the very large stations which are more complex and appear to operate at relatively low levels of efficiency.

In summary, it is then a time in which we need to do some clear thinking. What are our national objectives with respect to energy? To what extent should we give consideration to the long term? Are we simply interested in exploiting resources at the fastest possible rate in a policy which seeks to define national energy objectives and then utilise our resources in conformity with those objectives?

I believe that we are moving along a path of development which poses extreme dangers in the future. I doubt that a country as geographically dispersed as Australia needs to have an energy policy which must mean expensive energy in the longer term. Also, given our resources it ought to be possible to guarantee relatively cheap energy for all our people. Cheap energy flows, in my view, not from rapid development of our resources but from attention to both the most effective forms of supplying energy and also the most effective and efficient forms of the utilisation of energy; that is, attention to energy conservation.

The development of a comprehensive national energy policy is not an optional extra. It is absolutely fundamental. This is a government that has little or no interest in policy. It is interested only in the short term. It identifies the interests of the international corporate sector inevitably with the interests of Australia. It is not even interested in business in the broadest sense. It does not understand the inter-relationship between energy and employment policy. It does not understand, for example, that in a situation of surplus labour and diminishing energy resources different policies need to be adopted. The Government's relentless drive towards restructuring the economy around capital and energy intensive industries orientated towards uncertain international markets has built into it fundamental contradictions.

We as a nation need to make choices. Those choices need to be rational. But they should be made in the light of a comprehensive range of factors including the fundamental priority of maintaining and improving standards of living in Australia for all Australians. What this debate does is to provide an opportunity to point to the fact that the Government is sacrificing in the short term the well-being of ordinary people for the sake of a dream which I believe is not rooted in economic reality. We have no future as an advanced country if we develop around non-renewable resources, owned by transnational companies, shipped overseas in foreign ships and not transformed past the semi-processing phase in Australia.

There is no doubt that industry in this country has had to be subsidised and supported by consumers and tax payers. Before we rush in to provide massive subsidies to resource giants we should carefully assess what their contribution will be to the Australian economy and what they will do to advance our standard of living. The record of these companies in other countries, particularly in the Third World, would suggest that they would not make a great contribution. That is why we need to look for examples of where governments have been prepared to set objectives and to force these corporations to meet those objectives.

If the Victorian Government, and/or the Australian Government wishes to continue to encourage Alcoa to go ahead at Portland it should make absolutely certain that there is no degree of subsidy involved. The private inquiry carried out by Professor Cochrame does not give one a great deal of comfort that that, in fact, will be the case. These powerful companies which dominate the industry ought not to require subsidies. One would have thought that many members of the Government parties would agree to that. It is what many of them argue. But if these big boys of industry require subsidies how can one criticise the competitive sector of the economy asking for assistance from the Government to ensure that it does not go to the wall?

In this mixed economy, for the most part, industry will not be able to pay its own way, particularly in times of flat demand and international recession. The question is: Who gets subsidies for what reason?

The States Grants (Capital Assistance) Bill reflects the fact that people are getting less and less support for basic services. The share of capital resources going to meet social needs is constantly being diminished. We should ensure that the funds that are available in this country, particularly in the public sector are not being transferred out of the country in the form of subsidies to international resource giants.

Finally, I speak in support of the amendment, particularly as it relates to clauses 2 and 4. I emphasise that clause 4 refers to producing unbalanced development by facilitating the expansion of infrastructure for the resource industries while severely contracting expenditure on the social infrastructure. This, indeed, has been the trend through the life of this Government. It is a trend which this amendment condemns. That has been the principal aim of my remarks with respect to the Bill.
