Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nitrogenous Fertilizers Subsidy Amendment Bill increases the period for the payment of the nitrogenous fertilisers subsidy scheme and is of itself not one of the more important Bills introduced in this House. We on this side of the House do not oppose the extension of the period of payment for a further six months. However, the legitimacy of this form of subsidy requires some comment. In addressing myself to the Bill I fully realise that fertilisers of all sorts, particularly nitrogenous fertilisers, are one of the very important elements in food production in Australia. The production of food has reached a rather critical situation throughout the world. The use of fertilisers is vitally important to the well-being of millions of people.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a new development in the use of land which I would like to raise. It has some impact on the use of nitrogenous fertilisers and the use of subsidies. I refer to the approach throughout the world of using food-growing land and fuel crops for fuel. National programs to divert agricultural resources to produce fuel crops come at a time when efforts to expand world food output are losing momentum. Between 1950 and 1971 per capita grain production world wide increased by some 30 per cent leading to substantial improvements in nutrition not only in industrialised countries but also in much of the Third World. However, since 1971 growth in world output has slowed scarcely keeping pace with population growth.

The failure of the world grain output to match the increases in both population and income led to rising food prices during the 1970s. Throughout the 1960s and early 1970s the world had two major food reserves-large, often burdensome stocks of grain and a vast area of crop land idle under the United States of America farm programs. Together, these provided a period of unprecedented stability in world food supplies and prices. As recently as 1972 over 24 million hectares of United States' crop land was idle in the farm management programs. Since then most of that idle farm land has been returned to production. Even with this addition, the production of food in some years has not matched the growth in world demand.

As the 1980s begin the world has only one food reserve left, and that is its stocks of grain. These are at as low a level as they were in the 1972-73 period which led to savage increases in prices in 1974, creating problems for many people in the poorer parts of the world. In addition to the decline in reserves production has become more erratic. Efforts to double food output over the last decade pushed agriculture into areas of marginal rainfall and on to marginal soils. The former is dramatically evident in the Soviet Union, where a crop failure every third year or so is commonplace in the virgin lands-that is, in the new areas brought into cultivation since the 1950s. Over the past decade world demand for grain has been expanding by some 30 million tonnes a year and of this total the bulk is needed to cover the increase in human numbers, leaving very little to upgrade diets.

While the world population growth has slowed, the absolute year to year increase remains at 70 million. In effect, the gradual decline in the rate of population growth has been offset by the increase in the size of the population. Rising incomes have also contributed to the increase in world food demand, particularly in areas where the consumption of livestock products and the grain to feed livestock has been rising rapidly. On the supply side, growth in the world food crop land base has slowed markedly since mid-century, expanding at only one-fifth the rate at which the population is expanding. Amongst all of this we have a new competitor seeking the use of land and fertilisers, and hence the use of nitrogenous fertilisers. I refer to the potential to produce alcohol to drive motor cars as against the use of the same land for food production. Even without the competition from energy crops, the world will be hard-pressed to avoid a decline in per capita food production during the decade ahead if the projected increase in population continues. As against this, we must look at the emergence of energy crops which will compete actively for the land available for food.

We have seen a large inflow of capital into this country, much of which in the last 18 months has gone towards buying up broad acres of land in Australia. It is interesting to note that much of the land that has been bought up is what I would term energy related land-land that eventually could be used for the production of fuel for motor cars as against fuel for human beings. We need only to look at what is happening in some other countries. For instance, the Brazilians signed a protocol in 1979 with the National Automotive Association confirming their intention of producing in the early 1980s 250,000 vehicles that would run entirely on alcohol. They have in effect planted some 200,000 hectares of crop land for sugar cane. Brazilian officials claim that the production of energy crops will be undertaken in addition to, rather than in competition with, other food crops. But energy crops compete not only for land but also for agricultural investment, water, fertilisers, farm management, fuels, farm market roads, agricultural credit and technical advisory services.

The immediate consequences of the Brazilian energy program may be more internal than external but the more recently launched effort in the United States has broader ramifications. If the United States crop land is shifted to energy crop production to fuel automobiles on a massive scale it will be at the expense of the exportable surplus of grain. Over the past generation the entire world has come to depend heavily on the North American grain export, with just over four-fifths of the total being for the United States, and all but a handful of countries now import grain, mostly from North America. A year or so ago the United States Government set a target to produce 500 million gallons of fuel alcohol a year by the end of 1981. It looked to be hopelessly optimistic. Now that quantity appears likely to be exceeded. As more and more alcohol distilleries are built in the United States to meet the official goal of producing 7,500 million litres of ethanol by the mid-1980s, the exportable surplus of grain will be reduced accordingly.

In addition to the traditional buyers of the North American grain market-the flour millers and the feed lot operators-in the grain importing countries there will be a fourth potentially large group. That will be the distilleries. Exactly how high the price of grain could be driven by this approach is difficult to say but any high increase in the price of grain would cause problems. Obviously, the higher petrol prices go the more the distillers can afford to pay per bushel of grain. When petrol prices reach $2 a gallon, given the existing gasahol subsidies in the United States, those United States distillers could easily afford to pay $5 a bushel for maize and, should the price of gasoline reach $3 a gallon, distillers would be able to pay close to $6 a bushel for maize without any subsidies or credits. If the phase-out of oil price controls in the United States proceeds on schedule and the oil price moves to the world market level by the end of 1982, gasolene prices will rise accordingly. Under these circumstances United States distillers will be in a very strong position to bid for a growing share of the grain harvest.

This has implications for Australia. We have vast acres of broad land that could be used for growing cassava, sugar cane and grain for the production of alcohol. If we proceed in an unregulated way and government subsidies are unwisely used to encourage production it may not be in the best interests of this country. It would not be in the best interests of the production of food and it could lead to a lot of instability. I urge this warning on the Government: It should carefully assess just what the position is in regard to energy related land-land where crops will be grown in the future for the production of alcohol fuels and thus will compete directly with food production. As I have said, both Brazil and the United States have major programs now to convert agricultural commodities to alcohol. Countries such as Australia and New Zealand, and to a lesser degree South Africa, are considering the conversion of crops to alcohol for fuel on a commercial scale. This new interest in fuel crops could be an historical landmark. If more and more oil refineries are replaced by alcohol distilleries the world agricultural economy will be transformed. This will have a dramatic effect on Australia and Australia would be attracted to producing crops for alcohol production. I know that at the moment very many problems are to be sorted out in relation to the economics and technology of producing alcohol but in 1981 we could see the start of what might be a crisis situation in regard to the use of land and the use of our fertilisers.

This leads me to ask a couple of questions in regard to the use of subsidies, particularly those which apply to these fertilisers. Fertiliser subsidies can be used to affect production in one, two or perhaps three ways. The first is to assist in raising incomes at times of non-profitable prices for agricultural products. This is not a very good measure to be used because any subsidy used to assist one industry automatically goes across to the very profitable industries, and hence we pass public funds across to help people who are doing very well. The second point is that subsidies could be used to encourage production in the particular direction in which a government wishes agricultural products to develop. This could involve the legitimate use of a subsidy of this nature, namely, to direct production. But we in Australia are at present far past this stage where we need to use a subsidy of this nature right across the board to direct the production of agricultural products. The second reading speech of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) reads:
The question of the future operation of the nitrogenous fertilisers subsidy is currently under inquiry by the Industries Assistance Commission.
The reporting date on the inquiry which was 16 October 1981-
This is the report on nitrogenous fertilisers-

has been extended to coincide with the reporting date of 28 February 1982 for the associated IAC inquiry into phosphatic fertilisers. This action was taken because of the commonality of the issues involved in both references.

The Minister referred in his speech to the fact that the subsidies on both phosphatic and nitrogenous fertilisers have a commonality, and the Industries Assistance Commission report which will come down in February will report on that matter. This raises a couple of interesting points, particularly in the light of a policy-we should bear in mind that the Campbell report on the Australian Financial System was brought down today-based very much on free enterprise philosophies. We have the Campbell report to look at and later in the year the Government will have the IAC report to look at. To counterbalance that I suppose we will have National Country Party pressures. Those pressures, particularly in regard to subsidies, will be in stark contrast to what the Campbell report says and possibly to what the IAC report will say.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much is this subsidy worth?

—The nitrogenous fertiliser subsidy will cost some $2m for the next six months. Any subsidy paid to an industry which could be very profitable is an expenditure of funds out of the public purse which perhaps could go to other more needy people in the community. We are finding at present that this Government is only too happy to reduce the funding for many needy sections of the community. We have only to look at many of the things that have happened in the last six months as a result of the razor gang to see that this Government has two standards when it comes to this type of thing. I am not one of those who say that there are not many reasons why the rural sector should not be encouraged and assisted, particularly when, as at present, this Government's policies are absolutely tearing the heart out of the value of the money that it is expecting to receive from exports. Many industries at present using this nitrogenous fertiliser receive money in one hand from the Government and have it completely taken off them by the Government's economic policies. There is not much point in putting nitrogen on a fruit tree when the product cannot be sold overseas simply because the Government's policies have virtually destroyed the value of our currency.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that we will need to assess within the next six months the whole situation of the fertiliser subsidies. I hope that, when the IAC report on the nitrogenous fertilisers and the phosphatic fertilisers comes down, this Government will take a common-sense approach. We do not want to see nitrogenous fertiliser subsidies being placed in the hands of people who perhaps would develop an industry not in the best interests of world food production. Nitrogenous fertiliser subsidies could quite easily be spent, at the expense of food production, on the development of the production of sugar cane or cassava for alcohol fuels for the motor car. This sort of policy direction is something that the Government must look at seriously and it must take it into consideration before subsidies are put forward. There may be a good case for a complete change in direction after the IAC report is brought down in February.

I am very concerned that over many years, particularly the 1970s, this superphosphate subsidy issue has been used more for political reasons than for good economic sense. I know that many members of this Government, particularly in the Cabinet, receive large sums from the public purse, simply because they use large tonnages of fertiliser. I cannot see the common sense in that approach, because in other countries there is usually a means test approach to subsidies on fertilisers. I have heard many speakers on the Government side push that approach only too willing when they are talking about pensioners, but we do not hear too much of it when they are talking about the tonnages on which fertiliser subsidies can be paid. I suggest that a limit of 50 tonnes would be ample. If it were really necessary for the existence of farmers for there to be a $12 a tonne subsidy on superphosphate or a $20 a tonne subsidy on nitrogenous fertiliser, a cut-off point should be put into the arrangement. In the first place, we have to be sure that a subsidy is justified and, secondly, we have to have a cut-off point.

I strongly oppose any across the board subsidy, because a very profitable enterprise could be using up to 500 tonnes of fertiliser and getting a $6,000 hand-out from the public purse when there is no need for it at all. Of course, the argument then is that such enterprises making big profits would be paying fair taxes and that some of that money would be going back to the Government anyway. Even if they are paying 46c in the dollar in tax, 54c in the dollar is going from the public purse into the pockets of people who are doing very well without handouts from the public purse. While we support the proposal for another six months, I hope that at the end of those six months there will be a big adjustment by the Government to this type of approach and that it will put into operation some of the practices that it is so keen to impose on other sections of the community. If it finds, after the IAC report is handed down, that there is justification for the continuation of some sort of subsidy, at least it should be directed to those in need of that subsidy and should not be paid across the board to big corporations and big farmers who are returning only half of it in tax and pocketing the rest at public expense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), who preceded me in this debate, was going well during his set speech but, when he got to the impromptu areas of his speech, I am afraid that he missed the point altogether. He was talking of massive subsidies. I remind the honourable member that the total amount of extra nitrogenous fertiliser subsidy is between $2m and $2.5m.

SPEECH.PARA: However, he talked about the massive profits that are coming back to some suppliers of our vital food and trade products. He mentioned a 50 tonne limit as a means test, but he did not even mention the type of fertiliser involved-whether it is straight nitrogeneous or another. I am afraid that he lost me once he got away from his set speech. Perhaps he might explain that to me later on.

I am very happy to see that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore), who introduced this Bill, is at the table. I support this legislation because it means a carry over for the next six months. I think that the Minister is making a very fine job of the office he has taken over. I am certain that he will make sure that the investigation by the appropriate tribunal will be a fair one as far as rural industries are concerned. As I mentioned before, the extra cost of the subsidy is estimated at between $2m and $2.5m. The previous speaker did not seem to realise that this is a relatively small amount in comparison with subsidies given to protect other Australian industries, particularly industries such as the motor industry, where we are talking in billions and not millions of dollars. More than anything else I support this measure because of the cost to the Government and to the consumer of protective subsidies and grants. I believe that industries in Australia receive too much protective support which prohibits innovation, initiative, restructuring and the use of modern technology. Might I say that that can apply to only one set of industries. The industries I represent, particularly the rural and mining industries, are innovative, they are prepared to restructure, and they use modern technology.

I spoke on similar legislation on 14 September 1978 and 11 October 1979. On both occasions I referred to a need for a further referral to the Industries Assistance Commission to update the program in terms of the 1980 situation and not that of 1974, when the matter was first raised. If we are to use grants and subsidies I believe they should be meaningful and appropriate. I agree with the previous speaker that they have to have a purpose. This legislation is being extended so that the IAC can complete a fresh inquiry to enable a decision to be made by 30 June 1982.

I mentioned the appropriateness of a subsidy. For instance, the rate per tonne of nitrogenous content has reduced from $78.74 per tonne in 1975 to $60 in 1976, $40 in 1977 and $20 since 1978. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a schedule which shows the increase in prices of fertilisers having a nitrogenous content, on works, Brisbane, since February 1974.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This schedule shows an increase in the basic costs of nitrogenous fertilisers since 1974 of 136 per cent for urea, 107.5 per cent for aqua ammonia, and 106 per cent for ammonia nitrate. This increase has occurred over a period in which the subsidy has decreased by 75 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The increases in the prices of fertiliser reflect the increase in world crude oil prices. Since 1974 prices have gone from $US11.25 a barrel to $US32 at June 1981, an increase of 84 per cent. For these reasons, farm costs-and farms are the great users of fertilisers and fuels-have escalated at figures well above the consumer price index. Farm products are sold on world markets where more competition and changing exchange rates are depressing the market prices for those products. I mentioned before the $3m cost of the subsidy for all of 1981-82. This is insignificant in amount but important in principle, particularly in regard to the changes in other costs.

Could I for a moment refer to the fuel pricing arrangements instituted many years ago. Basically, 1976-77 was the year in which the real impact of the policy took hold. The increase from $US14.53 per barrel in 1979 to $US24 per barrel in 1980 was significant and resulted in severe criticism for many people, particularly from the Opposition. The present price of $32 per barrel shows a decline in that increase and a relative stabilising of the price. The results achieved by this policy, including decreased usage of fuel, a lessening dependency on overseas supplies, greater exploration and development, and a greater use of alternative energy resources, today stand as evidence and testimony to the wisdom and correctness of the crude oil policy.

The sugar industry in Queensland is a major user of fertilisers having a nitrogenous content. The industry uses between 60 per cent and 65 per cent of the State's total tonnage and about 25 per cent of the Australian total. Fertiliser is an essential ingredient to the growth of sugar cane and the industry is concerned not only for the price, but also for the long term availability of the product. I am sure the industry welcomes the retention of the bounty and also the promised investigation, but I would point out that in cash terms the benefit to the sugar industry of the subsidy for 1981-82 will be only about $750,000. I mentioned earlier the escalating costs of farm production which are well in excess of the consumer price index figure taken usually as the inflation rate. Farm inflation, in costs and new machinery is greater than domestic inflation. This brings me to the subject of the domestic sugar pricing arrangement, agreed between the Commonwealth and State Governments. It is relevant because increased costs of fertiliser and fuel are an indexing factor in the pricing formula.

When the five year arrangement was entered into on 1 October 1979 the formula was based on an increase of 70 per cent of the CPI to account for cash costs only. The formula took into account other factors, particularly the world sugar price change. Actually, on the occasion of the automatic increase on 1 July, 1980 and 1981 domestic price increases were substantially less than 70 per cent of the CPI. The point I wish to make is that the formula does not reflect the increase in farm costs so that the yearly price increases are considerably less than they should be. The result is a shrinking domestic price in real terms at a time when the exchange rate is shrinking the world market price in terms of real Australian currency. I suggest to the Government and to the sugar industry that they should not wait for the full run of the five year period to 1984 as this would mean that the review at that time would, or should produce a substantial increase in the domestic price that may not be palatable to the consumer. I believe that the review should be made sooner so that the increases will be regulated and more relevant to changes and not disruptive as they will be after the five years of the agreement. The National Country Party fully endorses this Bill, the six months extension and the IAC review, particularly if undertaken with a view to comparing the assistance given to manufacturing industries and the limited assistance available to rural industries. I support the Minister and the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Bill (on motion by Mr Moore) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Mr N. A. Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House, when debating this Bill, is dealing with a unique presentation. A Bill of this type relating to the Statute Law Revision Acts was presented earlier this year. We have no objection to the Bill making drafting amendments, repealing spent provisions or making technical amendments by omnibus provisions but there are certain provisions in this legislation which go beyond that description and should not be included in the Bill in this fashion. Some of the amendments we support but it makes it very difficult for the Opposition when there are amendments of substance to legislation in a Bill which, in its main section, amends 17 Acts of Parliament and in its Schedule amends 12 Acts and repeals another three. We are dealing with an enormous number of legislative provisions in the one Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Were the Bill to consist solely of the type of amendment contained in the Schedule, which simply seeks to amend drafting errors and to bring up to date drafting language, we would not have any basic objection. But some of the proposed amendments in the various parts of the Bill cannot be described in that fashion. For example, that an amendment such as that proposed to the Australian Capital Territory Evidence (Temporary Provisions) Act should be included in legislation of this kind is wrong. In 1971 the Senate disallowed an evidence ordinance for the Australian Capital Territory. The Act was passed to provide evidence laws in respect of criminal trials for the Territory. I do not believe it to be consistent with what occurred in 1971 for the Act, which gives effect to the ordinance, to be able to be amended or repealed by another ordinance. Of course, ordinances are made by the Governor-General in Council.

At present the matter of evidence in Federal and Territorial matters is being considered by the Law Reform Commission. This legislation will allow the evidence law applicable in the Australian Capital Territory to be changed without any reference to the Parliament. If the Government wishes to give an undertaking that the ordinance to be passed in the future must be approved by the House of Assembly, we will find that acceptable. However, if, as at present, the recommendations of the Assembly are basically to be ignored we will insist on parliamentary approval of a new evidence law for the Australian Capital Territory. The only power that the Houses of Parliament have in relation to ordinances is the power of disallowance, not the power of amendment. If the Parliament were to disallow an ordinance providing for a new law of evidence for the Australian Capital Territory, that would lead us into precisely the same position as we were in in 1971; that is, there would be a vacuum in the law. That is a position in which the Parliament should not be placed.

Probably the major amendment contained in the legislation is that proposed to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. On 7 May the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) announced that in future the Government would treat citizenship as the appropriate basis for voting rights. As the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) pointed out, one must have residency in Australia for three years before one can apply for citizenship. We certainly do not believe that British subject ought to be given special rights. However, some consideration ought to be given to reducing the qualifying period for citizenship to, say, 12 months. As the honourable member for Port Adelaide pointed out also, the term 'British subject' appears in over 70 Acts of Parliament, quite apart from the Commonwealth Electoral Act. If a provison such as this, which we welcome, is to be included in the Statue Law Revision Bill, which we find dubious, the opportunity ought to be taken in this legislation to remove the discrimination which continues to exist in other pieces of Commonwealth legislation.

We have no objection to the transfer of jurisdiction in bankruptcy, to the proposed amendments to the Designs Act or the proposed amendments to the Patents Act. The proposed amendments to the Petroleum Products Pricing Act, which was passed earlier this year, are interesting in that an earlier statutes revision Act has been misnamed, even though that Act was passed only this year. The amendment referred to the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Revision) Act, whereas it should have referred to the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act. It is perhaps a little ironic that statutes revision legislation should have to correct earlier statutes revision legislation. We hope that in future all statutes revision Bills carry the same title as the present Bill and that if more than one such Bill is introduced in a particular year those Bills simply be numbered, as was the case with the tax Bills-for example, tax Bills (Nos 1 to 9). If that is not done the titles of amending Bills will be extremely confusing and it will become very difficult to locate the revising Acts.

The proposed amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act simply recognise the fact that the Council of Australian Government Employee Organisations is no longer in existence, it having merged with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The representation on the National Labour Consultative Council previously given to CAGEO will now be taken up by the ACTU. The Trades and Labour Council representation on the State councils for union training is to be correspondingly increased by one. Another proposed amendment of substance is that to the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976. Whilst that is a piece of legislation passed by the Fraser Government, I should point out that it is a piece of Australian Labor Party legislation which was introduced in the Parliament in 1975 and which would have been passed were it not for the Governor-General's intervention. The proposed amendment will allow the bodies incorporated under the Act to dispose of their assets to non-Aboriginal bodies or individuals. However, ministerial approval is still required. I deem that a little paternalistic.

While the amendments in themselves are welcome in that they improve the present position, ministerial approval is still required. Why Aboriginal councils and associations cannot deal with their own assets in the same way as anybody else I am at a loss to understand. The reason for land tenure being under what is called an inalienable freehold is not because there is distrust of what land councils or land trusts might do with the land but simply because of the relationship between Aboriginals and land which is quite different from the European concept which simply regards land as an asset which is readily transferrable. Provided that an Aboriginal council or association is not acting ultra vires or in some way vexatiously, there is no reason in principle why the disposal of assets or interests should not be dealt with in any way that the council or association thinks fit.

We support the amendments to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act. These amendments will enable judges to make their oaths or affirmations of allegiance before superior court judges, that is, High Court or Federal Court, instead of the necessity for this to be done to the Governor-General. The amendment has a slightly republican tone which we thoroughly support. I do not know whether it will get the ringing support of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) in view of his comments in this place. The amendment to enable reserved judgments to be delivered by any member of the court is quite sensible and we support it. It places the Australian Capital Territory in its proper place as a supreme court. The same considerations apply to clause 16 of the Bill which enable the Attorney-General rather than the appointee of the Governor-General to bring indictments for offences. Again there is a republican tone in this amendment. The other amendment to be made to the Australian Capital Supreme Court Act relates to the question of interest being payable on judgments for money. We support this amendment which is necessary particularly at this time of inflation.

The Opposition does not support the amendments to the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act. We find it difficult to understand why this legislation is being introduced in this fashion. The Government must be under the mistaken belief that the Corporation, established in 1978, is achieving some effective work. We cannot see that it has been able to do anything because of the strictures placed on it in the original Act. The Corporation cannot buy or sell goods either as a principle or an agent and it cannot compete with private enterprise. The Government continues to have a hang-up about the overseas trading corporation legislation which it rejected in the Senate when in Opposition. The question of an overseas trading corporation has nothing to do with communism or socialism. It is simply a fact of life that there is a need for trading contracts to be established on a government-to-government basis. It is in the interests of private enterprise as a whole for this to be done.

However, the Government seems intent on protecting some sectional interests. The amendment states that the Corporation is not to take any actions which would result in a project being carried out where there is any government involvement. This is a ludicrous provision which will result in the loss of trading contracts. The Government seems to be unaware that we live in a mixed economy where the private and public sectors are intertwined. The building industry is in a slump due very largely to government cut-backs. Public sector involvement is vital to the Australian private industry particularly in the area of trade. While some individual private concerns may benefit from the amendments being moved Australian industry as a whole will not, and the Australian public certainly will not.

Subject to the reservations that I have stated we are prepared to support the Bill other than provisions of Part VII which we would ask the Government to delete. Those provisions relate to amendments to the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation. I make the point again that the original Bill really bound that project corporation hand and foot from the ability to operate in any competitive fashion. It could neither operate as a principal nor as an agent. If one looks at the profit and loss statement contained in the annual report for 1979-80, is it any wonder that we get into the position that all the report can show is a loss? We have a situation now where the accumulated losses to date are over $250,000. If one compares the Corporation's balance sheet with that of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority one will find the Snowy Mountains Authority operating at a profit. Why is this so? It is so because it can get out and compete both as a principal and agent. One has the ridiculous situation here that taxpayers' money is being given to an overseas projects corporation which is heavily in the red after two years and is unable to get out of it. How can it possibly start to earn money when it is not able to act either as principal or agent? If we look at the amendments now proposed it is prevented from even getting involved in any area where there is deemed to be an Australian authority. There is a specific prohibition in Part VII preventing the Corporation from getting involved in any public consortium or competing against any Australian private organisation or consortium. Proposed new section 8A provides that where the Corporation is aware that an Australian private organisation or an Australian private consortium is able and willing to carry out an overseas development project the Corporation is unable to take part in the project. But there has to be some logic in what we are about. It is ridiculous to think that this Bill provides that if a department of the Australian Public Service or a department of a State Public Service is involved the Corporation cannot assist. I think that is where we of the Opposition find this provision to be ridiculous.

I make the point again that the Corporation is operating at a loss. We want to see the Corporation get into the act of making a profit. In so doing it will readily accelerate the opportunity for the private sector to do the work. Surely the task of the Corporation is to assist with and to find the work. But to have it in a situation in which it cannot ever be a principal or an agent for another organisation and it has to drop out because some organisation allegedly is in the private sector or comes within the definition of an Australian authority which virtually bars the Corporation by statute is quite counter-productive. I know the House wants to complete this Bill this evening and the Opposition will co-operate in that regard but we will need to go into Committee just to deal with Part VII of this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to Part VII of the legislation which deals with amendments to the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act 1978. It can be seen from this Part that the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation cannot go near any organisation coming within the definition of 'Australian authority' in terms of being involved in development. The definition of 'Australian authority' also includes a department of the Australian Public Service and a department of the Public Service of a State, but does not include the Corporation. Clause 24 seeks to insert proposed new section 8A, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Where the Corporation is aware that an Australian private organisation or an Australian private consortium is able and willing to carry out an overseas development project or a part of an overseas development project, the Corporation shall not take any action that would result in that project or that part of the project being carried out, in whole or in part, by an Australian authority or by an Australian public consortium.

There is a similar provision set out in proposed new section 8A (2). We of the Opposition find it quite ridiculous to think that the Corporation is so hamstrung. I have already made the point in my speech on the second reading that we do not think the Corporation is doing as well as it should be doing. The taxpayers' money will not be wisely expended if the Corporation is to be hindered by legislative strictures. Accordingly, we oppose this amendment; that is, the whole of Part VII. We do not intend to press it to a division because of the lateness of the hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity to respond briefly to the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen) who has argued the opposition to Part VII of this Bill. I think the role which the Government has set for the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation will be seen quite clearly in the explanation I am about to give. I think the public will understand that it is a proper role which carves out for the Corporation an ability to assist Australian organisations to compete for contracts for development projects overseas. The Government has deliberately limited the powers of the Corporation so that existing Australian commercial organisations cannot be displaced by the Corporation in their normal activities. The actual execution of projects is a function of the private sector and the supply of goods needed to fulfil a particular project would be the responsibility of the Australian firms associated with the project.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, then, that the Committee will see that the role of the Corporation is complementary to that of private enterprise and existing Australian commercial organisations. It is intended that the Corporation assist those organisations without intruding into their normal commercial activities and without seeking, as I have said, to displace existing Australian corporations in their normal activities.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Stock Exchange Markets-Computerised Legal Information Retrieval Systems

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Viner) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 10 days before last year's general election, share market gamblers enjoyed a picnic in Australia. They manipulated the prices of Australian shares for no sound reason except to line their pockets with unearned, speculative profits. Further, they spread gossip, rumour and lies to try to mislead the public about their activities. Just as seriously, they were supported, even encouraged, by brokers, by newspaper financial reporters and editorialists and by Fraser Government spokesmen. But now, the truth about those 10 days can be better understood. The subsequent performance of share prices has revealed the cynicism of these financial, media and political manipulators.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me begin by reminding the House of the facts. After a period of increasing share prices, by around 44 points over the preceding five weeks, on Tuesday, 7 October and Wednesday, 8 October last year, the Sydney Stock Exchange all ordinaries index fell 35 points from 692 to 657. The index rose again to 678 two days later, then fell to 662 on Wednesday, 15 October before rising to 675 on Friday, 17 October. The conservative forces had no doubt why these share price fluctuations took place. The Daily Telegraph-Murdoch for the masses-headed its report on 8 October with 'Opinion poll rumours rock stock exchange. Panic as ALP Surges Ahead'. The story began:
Shares crashed as rumours swept Sydney Stock Exchange yesterday of a new opinion poll believed to show that the ALP has surged further ahead of the government parties.
On the same day, the business community heard the same news from the Australian Financial Review which stated:

Share prices suffered a pounding on national share markets yesterday as investors became increasingly nervous of the possibility of the ALP winning at the forthcoming Federal election. The collapse of prices was one of the biggest single day falls ever seen on Australian share markets.
Eight days later, on 16 October, the Australian Financial Review repeated this line when prices fell again. It stated:
The Sydney Morning Herald-Age and Bulletin polls, giving Labor a comfortable lead, saw one of the market's biggest plunges in the first hour.

Stock Exchange representatives took the same line. Unnamed brokers quoted in the Age of 8 October talked about the blackest day they had seen in six months and said that 'the bottom's fallen out of the market', at the prospect of a Labor election victory. On 10 October, Mr Denis Tricks, Chairman of the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges, was quoted as threatening further falls if Labor were returned to government-

TALK.START.PARA: —Tricks?

—Yes, well named, as the honourable member for Fremantle has implied. Mr Brent Potts, partner in the broking firm Rivkin and Co., predicted a stock market crash if Labor won. The Fraser Government encouraged this attempt to generate an irrational anti-Labor hysteria. On October 9, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) whipped up a Press conference to claim:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what happened on the stock markets yesterday and today shows quite clearly how business and hundreds of thousands of Australian investors view the prospect of a Labor Government.
The Prime Minister's business consultant and a renowned speculator himself, the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) said:
What we are seeing is simply a foretaste of the way investment would dry up if Labor wins the coming election.

That was October 1980. Let me now challenge these high priests and prophets of conservatism. Do they still stand by those explanations? Is a drop of 36 points in the all ordinaries index still a 'panic', a 'black day', a 'collapse in a heap'? Does it still indicate that Australian business and the public have no confidence in the Government? If so, the Fraser Government has caused not simply a momentary decline but a momentous crash in investor confidence.

I table a graph, prepared by the Parliamentary Library Statistical Service, which shows the Sydney Stock Exchange indices for all ordinaries and for 50 market leaders between September 1980 and October 1981. Quite clearly, on at least eight different occasions since the Fraser Government was returned at the last general election, the index fell as far and as fast as it did on 7 to 8 October 1980. Worse still, the market fell in a long term trend from about 730 points in mid-April to about 560 points at the end of September this year-a fall of 170 points in less than five months. I suggest the investors and brokers examine these figures closely. I suggest the public-the target of their hysteria a year ago-also examine these figures. If last year's stories were honest, why are we not now seeing, daily, similar headlines and reports? If last year's explanation was correct, why are we not now hearing, daily, acknowledgments from the Prime Minister that his Government has been a disaster for business and the Australian community? Or do we conclude that this collection of share price manipulators and political cynics were simply spreading gossip, rumour and lies to try and con the public in the 10 days before 18 October 1980? If so, I trust we will be wise enough to reject these tactics next time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General meets in Perth on Friday I want to draw the House's attention to the unsatisfactory position in which private enterprises wishing to establish computerised legal information retrieval systems still find themselves. Honourable members will recall recent discussion in the media on the subject of difficulties public libraries and universities are having in complying with the amendments to the Copyright Act and in particular in relation to the copying of statutes, regulations and court judgments. No doubt honourable members have received numerous representations on the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: Less well publicised but equally important is government failure so far to allow electronic dissemination of primary legal source materials-statutes, regulations and cases. It is this which is seriously impeding the establishment in Australia of the computerised legal information retrieval systems that I have referred to, whether it be by Computer Law Services Pty Ltd, Butterworths Pty Ltd or others. At the heart of both these problems is the Crown's copyright claim in respect of these legal source materials-cases, statutes and regulations.

Every person is presumed to know the law and this is indeed his duty. Such an onerous duty must surely carry with it the right of unimpeded access to primary sources of the laws. Governments should not have, or even claim, the right to impede the free dissemination of primary legal source materials, especially given their well known unsatisfactory record in providing up to date consolidated statutes and regulations. If private enterprise can produce a better access to the law then it must be in the public interest that it be able to do so in whatever media-electronic or otherwise-it finds most convenient. It is for this reason that the Committee on Copyright and Law in the United Kingdom-the Whitford Committee-observed:
The statutes and Judgments, embodying as they do the law, should, on the face of it, be free of any possible copyright restrictions.

The House is no doubt aware that in this respect Australia is out of step with every other major common law countries. In the United States all statutes, regulations and judgments have, since the case of Wheedon v. Peters in 1832, been in the public domain and may be disseminated without government interference. In the United Kingdom the Crown, which has rights in relation to legislative materials but not judgments, does not assert those rights save in exceptional circumstances. In Australia the report of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions has recommended a relaxation of copyright; yet to date there has been no indication of any relaxation of copyright with respect to computerised electronic media. The reasons for this are not clear. The responses to questions before the Estimates Committee C inquiry into the Attorney-General's Department's estimates for 1981-82 were not entirely satisfactory and indicated that discussions between the States and the Commonwealth with respect to the establishment of computerised legal data retrieval systems were far from resolved, particularly as far as the Commonwealth's position is concerned. Furthermore, details of discussions of and reports to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General have been given very little public airing.

I believe that this position cannot be justified either on the basis of the Government's commitment to private enterprise or on the basis of my earlier comments with respect to the important right of unimpeded public access to the law. We need to facilitate that access. With the increasing importance of computerised electronic media as a means of rapid dissemination of the law in the major common law countries, it is in Australia's national interests for the Government to forgo what could now be claimed to be a monopoly and to allow capable organisations which wish to disseminate information through computerised electronic media to do so. Again, noting that the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General is to meet in Perth on Friday, I urge that steps in that direction be taken forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Hodges) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 11.36 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many young persons does the Government anticipate assisting under each of the 5 new initiatives of the Commitment to Youth Program announced by him on 1 October 1980.
(2) How many young persons have been assisted under each of these new initiatives as at 30 March 1981.

(3) How many extra Commonwealth Employment Service staff have been allocated nationally to cope with the increased workload involved in implementing these new initiatives and how have these staff been distributed in each State.
(4) What was the basis on which this staffing figure was calculated.
(5) Were relevant staff associations involved in the calculations of extra staff requirements; if not, why not.
(6) Were these staff associations satisfied with the number of extra staff allocated to cope with the new initiatives; if not, what was the basis for their dissatisfaction.

(7) What is the current situation concerning the Review to seek improved opportunities for youth jointly announced with the Minister for Education on 16 January 1981 and, in particular, the consideration of ceasing the availability of unemployment benefits for persons under 18 years of age.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Two of the five initiatives relate to the payment of a Transition Allowance. The allowance, equivalent to Unemployment Benefit plus $6 per week, is payable to young people aged 15-19 years who have been unemployed and away from full-time education for at least four months in the last twelve months and who take part in approved full-time Commonwealth funded School-to-Work Transition Program courses in TAFE. The same allowance is payable to all young people under the age of 25 years, unemployed and away from full-time education for eight months out of the last twelve months and who participate in an approved full-time TAFE course of up to twelve months' duration which is likely to lead to employment.

The Government anticipated that, in a full year, up to 10,000 young people would be paid a Transition Allowance. The initiative came into effect on 1 February 1981 and by the end of March 1981, payment of an allowance had been approved to 2,722 young people.

A third initiative was the introduction of higher subsidies under the Special Youth Employment Training Program (SYETP). The new subsidies, set at $80 per week for the first 17 weeks and $55 per week for the remaining 17 weeks, are payable to employers who agree to take on and train young people aged 18-24 years who have been unemployed and away from full-time education for eight months out of the last twelve months.

The Government expected that up to 10,000 young people would receive subsidised on-the-job training under this initiative in a full year. The new subsidies were also effective from 1 February 1981 and by the end of March 1981, payment had been approved in respect of 2,686 trainees.

A fourth initiative involved a variation to the eligibility criteria for training under standard SYETP conditions. Eligibility to such training has been extended to all young people who have completed a full-time course in TAFE under the Commonwealth funded School-to-Work Transition Program and who are in need of further on-the-job training.
This variation in SYETP eligibility became effective at the end of November 1980 and to the end of March 1981, 63 young people had benefitted.

The final initiative was the introduction of a special counselling and advice service within the CES. The Government intends that every young person under 25 years of age who has been continuously registered as unemployed for eight months will benefit from this initiative. ACOA bans on the collection of statistics in some States prevented the compilation of an accurate statistic for Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding information in respect of Part (1) the attached table sets out details of (a) number of workers involved (b) number of working days lost and (c) estimated loss in wages as a result of industrial disputes in each State, the Northern Territory, the Australian Capital Territory and Australia as a whole, for each of the last 10 years.

These statistics refer only to working days lost by workers directly involved in stoppages, and those indirectly involved at establishments where the stoppages occurred. They do not include time lost by workers indirectly affected at other establishments, nor the effects of bans and limitations.

Regarding information in respect of Part (2), (a), (b) and (c), uniform and comprehensive statistics of industrial accidents, injuries and occupational diseases for the past 10 years are not available. However, the Australian Bureau of Statistics is proceeding with initiatives to extend statistical coverage to include the Territories and Commonwealth Government employees and to standardise the existing statistics for the States. It is hoped then that reliable State, Territory and national statistics can be produced.

Calculations prepared for the Departments of Labour Advisory Committee on Industrial Accidents indicate that each year, there are at least 300 fatalities, and 300,000 disabling injuries (causing time off work of one day or more) and 1,000,000 weeks lost from work. These estimates do not include cases of occupational disease, or journey to or from work.
Complete information in respect of Part (2) (d) is not available.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Care and Use of Animals in Research

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the National Health and Medical Research Council drawn up a Code of Practice in respect to the care and use of animals in research.
(2) If so, does this Code of Practice apply to (a) Government laboratories, (b) industry and (c) educational institutions.
(3) Does his Department carry out inspections of research laboratories to ensure compliance with the code; if so, how often are inspections carried out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) has, in conjunction with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), drawn up a 'Code of practice for the care and use of animals in research in Australia'. It is an extensive document, covering aspects in relation to the manner in which experiments are conducted, the care and maintenance of animals and the training of laboratory personnel in the care of animals.

(2) The code of practice is a voluntary code and therefore, it is at the discretion of individual laboratories as to whether it is followed. However, it is a requirement that NHMRC grantees comply with the Code and compliance is generally monitored by the relevant Ethics Committee of the institution where the research is being conducted. In those institutions where there is no appropriate Ethics Committee, the grantee is required to abide by the Code of Practice, as a condition of the grant. Government laboratories such as the Commonwealth Serum Laboratory comply with the code which is administered through an Animal Experimentation Ethics Review Committee.

(3) My Department does not inspect research laboratories to monitor compliance with the code. It is the responsibility of State and Territory Departmental authorities to ensure the legislation is appropriately administered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is (a) cabinet-making excluded from the building category for which $1,000 rebates are made available and (b) panel beating excluded from the metal trades category for which $1,000 rebates are made available under his Department's job training programs; if so, why.
(2) Has his Department received complaints concerning these exclusions.
(3) Will he consider amending the conditions of the training programs to include these trades; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) Yes. As cabinet-making is a furniture trade and panel-beating is a vehicle trade, they are outside the metal, electrical and building trades to which the CRAFT $1,000 rebate applied in the period 1 December 1980-30 June 1981.
(2) Yes.

(3) No. The metal, electrical and building trades were identified and agreed by Commonwealth and State Ministers of Labour as the areas where the greatest shortfall of skilled tradesmen may apply as a result of demands from the major development projects. The Government therefore gave priority to increase the supply of skilled tradesmen in these areas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights: International Labour Organisation Conventions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the International Labour Office list International Labour Organisation Conventions No.135-Workers' Representatives, 1971, No. 141-Rural Workers' Organisations, 1975 and No. 151-Labour Relations (Public Service), 1978 among the 10 conventions which deal with basic human rights.

(2) What have been the dates and form of the periodical consultations with the States which the Australian Government is obliged by Article 19 (7) (b) (ii) of the Constitution of the ILO to arrange with a view to promoting co-ordinated action to give effect to the provisions of such conventions.
(3) What attitude has each State expressed to the ratification of each convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are 11 International Labour Organisation Conventions which the International Labour Office lists as basic human rights Conventions. They are:
Convention No. 11: Right of Association (Agriculture), 1921
Convention No. 87: Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, 1948
Convention No. 98: Right to Organise and Collective Bargaining, 1949
Convention No. 135: Workers' Representatives, 1971
Convention No. 141: Rural Workers' Organisations, 1975
Convention No. 151: Labour Relations (Public Service), 1978
Convention No. 29: Forced Labour, 1930
Convention No. 105: Abolition of Forced Labour, 1957
Convention No. 100: Equal Remuneration, 1951
Convention No. 111: Discrimination (Employment and Occupation), 1958
Convention No. 156: Workers with Family Responsibilities, 1981

(2) Convention No. 135-Workers' Representatives, 1971: Apart from correspondence between the Commonwealth and State Departments of Labour, and a request in January 1972 by my Department for State Department reports on the extent to which law and practice in their respective jurisdictions complied with the Articles of the Convention, Convention No. 135 has been considered at Technical Officers' meetings in November 1973, May 1974, December 1974, July 1975, December 1975, February 1977 and August 1979, Departments of Labour Advisory Committee in August 1973, February 1974, September 1976, September 1978, the Conference of Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers in September 1976 and February 1979.

Convention No. 141-Rural Workers Organisations, 1975: Convention No. 141 applies particularly to developing countries where organisations representing rural workers have not been established or, if they have, are in the formative stages of development only. The approach adopted in the instrument does not lend itself to adaptation to the Australian legal frameworks and institutional arrangements in the labour area and ratification would not be possible without quite fundamental changes to the Australian industrial relations system. Nevertheless this Convention has been discussed at Technical Officers' meeting in 1976 and 1977 and the position will be reviewed from time to time.

Convention No. 151-Labour Relations (Public Service) 1978: In addition to correspondence between the Commonwealth and State Departments of Labour, State Departments of Labour were requested by my Department in 1978 to provide detailed information on the extent to which law and practice in their respective jurisdictions complied with the Articles of this Convention. My Department is still awaiting those detailed responses. Convention No. 151 has also been discussed specifically at Technical Officers' meetings in October 1978, August 1979 and August 1980 and generally at the Departments of Labour Advisory Committee in September 1978 and at the Conference of Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers in February 1979.
(3) No State has agreed to the ratification of either Convention No. 135 or Convention No. 141. Western Australia has agreed to the ratification of Convention No. 151.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sydney International Airport: Immigration Clearance Booths

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that 12 Immigration Clearance Booths at Sydney's International Airport were unattended on 12 July 1981, causing inbound passengers to queue for over 2 hours, and several passengers to miss onward connecting flights.
(2) If so, why have additional staff not been assigned to Clearance Booths to spare travellers and tourists from protracted delays.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) On 12 July 1981 eighteen primary officers were rostered for duty to cover arriving as well as departing passengers. To spare travellers and tourists from protracted delays a further eight officers were rostered, increasing the primary officer working strength to twenty six. Sixteen officers were deployed to process arriving passengers and crew and ten officers to process departing passengers and crew.

Between 9.30 am and 10.15 am, 1,640 passengers disembarked from 7 aircraft, 5 of which were off-schedule by periods of between 14 and 50 minutes. Passengers from these aircraft did wait for periods ranging up to 115 minutes to be cleared through the Customs/Immigration primary check.

Passenger overloads at the inwards primary line are caused largely by circumstances over which the Department has no control, such as the arrival of off-schedule aircraft which is what occurred on 12 July. I have been assured that all officers on that morning were utilised to the maximum advantage.
I have been advised that the Department has received no reports of passengers missing connecting flights.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. What extra costs will be incurred by secondary schools to expand their libraries to cover the increased demand for books and journals as a result of increasing restrictions on the use of photocopying facilities by secondary teachers requiring sufficient duplicates for class course material.
2. Does the Government intend to provide financial support to those schools lacking the finance to provide the necessary extra books and journals.

3. Have there been any discussions with State Education Ministers or Departments regarding the effects on standards of education resulting from restrictions to photocopying; if so, what was the outcome of the discussions; if not, will there be discussions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. It is not possible at this stage to estimate what extra costs, if any, schools will incur in expanding their libraries to meet any needs arising from the operation of the Copyright Amendment Act 1980. Such costs will depend in part on determinations to be made by the Copyright Tribunal in regard to the rate of royalty payable to copyright owners for multiple copying of their work.

The Act does not require schools to stop photocopying. What it does require is that schools should examine more closely the amount they propose to multiple copy from a particular work. Broadly speaking, a school may multiple copy up to 1 per cent of a work free of payment to the copyright owner. Up to 10 per cent may be multiple copied if the school is prepared to pay a royalty for the pages copied. When multiple copies of more than 10 per cent of a work are required, the school is expected to buy rather than copy, if the work is commercially available as a separate publication.

2. School funding is basically a matter for the State Governments and other bodies which operate schools. If, in due course, such bodies choose to document cost increases arising from the changes to copyright law, in their routine submissions to the Schools Commission, the Government will be in a position to decide whether or not those costs should influence the level of funds to be provided for schools by the Commonwealth.

3. Proposed and actual changes to copyright law have been regularly discussed over a period of several years by the Commonwealth and State Ministers for Education, and by officers of their Departments. Some outcomes of the discussions have been:
(a) the establishment, in 1978, of an Australian Educational Council working partly on copyright law;
(b) representations to the Attorney-General's Department to ensure that the needs of education were met as far as possible when the new legislation was being prepared;
(c) co-operation among the Education Departments in the task of preparing teachers and administrators for the new legislation; and

(d) continuing discussions with the Attorney-General's Department on the needs of schools in regard to their use of audio visual materials, which in an area where further amendments to copyright law are envisaged.
A report on the current situation will be presented to the next meeting of the Australian Education Council which is to be held from 19 to 23 October.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his Department obtained a legal opinion on whether arrangements for the export of Australian tobacco leaf by firms which import manufactured tobacco breach the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade provisions on export subsidies.
(2) Has the United States of America or any other country protested about those arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 26 March 1981 the Government announced its decision to provide a duty concession of 10 per cent ad valorem on one kilogram of manufactured tobacco imported for each kilogram (greenweight) of Australian leaf purchased. The concession is available contingent upon importers making specified purchases of Australian leaf.

The Department of Trade and Resources, under the direction of the Minister for Trade and Resources, has primary responsibility for Australia's participation in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). This includes the negotiation of any agreements or understandings in the GATT, the handling of any representations by other GATT contracting parties on any Australian measures or practice which affects their rights under the GATT or under any agreement administered under the auspices of the GATT, and advice to the Government on the GATT implications of proposed courses of action.

Normally, any GATT contracting party, judging a practice of another contracting party to be harmful to its interests and not in conformity with the GATT, raises the matter under formal GATT procedures. In the case of tobacco, no such action has been initiated by any contracting party.

The only grounds for questioning Australia's action would be in terms of the GATT export subsidy provisions which, as far as agricultural products are concerned and as Australia itself is well aware, are not especially onerous. It is, in any case, widely accepted within GATT that concessional import duties, whether or not applied to agricultural products, are not regarded as subsidies. Accordingly, it is not surprising that Australia's actions on tobacco have not been questioned in GATT.

In terms of GATT practice, it was neither appropriate nor necessary for the Department of Trade and Resources to seek a further opinion concerning the consistency of the concession on manufactured tobacco with GATT provisions on export subsidies.

(2) Bilateral representations were, in fact, received from the United States concerning Australia's actions on tobacco shortly after they were announced. However, these representations were postulated with insufficient precision to permit a specific response. Since going back to the United States they have not pursued the matter further.
No other country has raised the matter.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Capital Territory Health Commission Grant to Calvary Hospital

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How was the 1979-80 grant of $6,439,339 by the Capital Territory Health Commission to the Calvary Hospital determined.
(2) In 1979-80 how many patients of each classification were admitted to Calvary Hospital and what was their average stay in the hospital.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1979-80 grant to Calvary Hospital Australian Capital Territory incorporated was determined according to an agreement between the Corporation of the Little Company of Mary, the Commonwealth of Australia, Calvary Hospital Australian Capital Territory Incorporated and the Capital Territory Health Commission. The agreement provides for the Commission to pay to Calvary Hospital a grant for operating expenses equal to the difference between income and expenditure for the financial year concerned based on a submission to the Commission of estimates of income and expenditure for the coming year. Calvary Hospital is also required to provide information and statistics relating to their estimates as required by the Commission. Calvary Hospital is entitled to participate in discussions on the funding and budget estimates for all public hospitals in the Australian Capital Territory. The Commission has the right to vary, after consultation with the hospital, the approved budget at any time during the year.

(2) In 1979-80, 2507 patients were admitted to acute beds in Calvary Hospital. These admissions represented 849 hospital service patients with an average length of stay of 8.0 days and 1,658 private and compensation patients with an average length of stay of 8.3 days.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to the site reclamation procedures of hydraulically pumping sand from Moreton Bay to accommodate the 02/20 runway in conjunction with the re-development of Brisbane's International Airport; if so, have any investigations been carried out into (a) possible adverse ecological consequences to micro-organisms in Moreton Bay fishing grounds which may produce ciguatoxin and hence contaminate locally caught fish and (b) the effects of dredging on adjacent beaches.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, my attention has been drawn to the reclamation procedures.
With regard to investigations, my Department has been advised by the Department of Housing and Construction as follows:

(a) Expert advice provided since 1972 has never identified ciguatoxin. as a potential problem and consequently detailed investigations have not been undertaken. Ciguatoxin is associated with the destruction of coral substrate and is generally restricted to tropical waters. Dredging in Moreton Bay for the re-development of Brisbane International Airport is being conducted at Middle Banks, which is an area devoid of coral and not within tropical waters. Thus ciguatoxin is not likely to result from Middle Banks dredging.

(b) Yes. Investigations of the effect of dredging at Middle Banks on the beaches of Moreton Island by specialist advisers concluded that the effects will be be negligible, on the currently unstable Moreton Island beaches. Records existing since the mid ninteenth century confirm the unstable nature of these beaches. Direct monitoring of the western Moreton Island beaches commenced prior to dredging to identify any changes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 1 September 1981 there were 7,310 applications awaiting decisions by the Repatriation Review Tribunal. Of this total 1,116 were lodged before 1 September 1979 and 6,194 were lodged on, or after, 1 September 1979.
(2) Approximately 50 formal representations have been received during the last 10 months expressing concern about delays in the Repatriation determining system.

(3) The Government is fully aware of the problems being encountered with delays in the repatriation determining system and changes have been made to improve the position. Three additional Repatriation Boards have been established with the object of lessening the backlog in cases awaiting determination. The number of Repatriation Commission delegates has been increased and approval has been sought for further delegates to be appointed. In addition, the Repatriation Act 1920 has been amended to provide the Repatriation Review Tribunal with a discretion whether or not to refer to the Repatriation Commission cases where additional evidence is presented.
While the above, and other, measures have assisted in reducing the average time taken to process claims and appeals, the delays in the system need to be reduced further.

The Government is concerned that some veterans are experiencing lengthy delays in establishing entitlement to Repatriation benefits and preliminary discussions on the problems have already been held with veterans' organisations to seek their views on further measures to streamline the determining system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.
