QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Commonwealth medical benefits schedule include an item for specialist consultations.
(2) Is it a fact that no item in the Commonwealth medical benefits schedule explicitly covers the fitting of contact lenses by specialists.
(3) Does the fitting of contact lenses require a full consultation with a specialist.
(4) Is it normal practice for the cost of fitting contact lenses to be the same as that of a specialist consultation.
(5) Does the Commonwealth medical benefits schedule also include an item covering follow-up specialist consultations.
(6) Is the cover afforded for this item half that provided under the item for specialist consultations.
(7) Does Medibank cover the fitting of contact lenses under the item for follow-up specialist consultations.

(8) If specialists regard the fitting of contact lenses as a full consultation and not a follow-up consultation, for what reason is the fitting of contact lenses covered under the follow-up specialist consultation item.
(9) Will he act to correct this apparent anomaly; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) No. As from 1 September 1981, a new item was included in the Medical Benefits Schedule with a fee in all States of $49.00 for-

'Attendance by a medical practitioner for the investigation and evaluation of a patient for the fitting of contact lenses, with keratometry and testing with trial lenses and the issue of a prescription-one attendance in any period of 36 consecutive months'.
Benefits are not attracted under this item unless the lenses are prescribed at this attendance. Evaluation and fitting without the issue of a prescription do not qualify under the item.
Benefits are payable for an initial referred consultation rendered in association with the fitting and prescribing of the lenses.
Subsequent follow-up attendances attract benefits on a consultation basis.

In addition, Commonwealth medical benefits are payable for the prescribing and fitting of contact lenses by optometrists who have undertaken to participate in the Government's Optometrical Benefits Scheme.

Unlike the new item covering the evaluation of a patient for fitting of contact lenses by a medical practitioner, the item covering the prescribing and fitting of contact lenses by an optometrist covers all attendances subsequent to the initial consultation in a single course of attention. This bulk item attracts a Schedule fee of $108.
(9) There is no anomaly.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans: Female Members of Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to statements by former members of the Australian Women's Army Service who served during the Second World War, that they were enlisted for active service outside Australia because they were members of Military Forces engaged in operations against an enemy and any of them could have been sent at any time to war zones outside of Australia.
(2) Is there any discrimination with respect to recognition of war service of female members of the Services when determining eligibility for Defence Service Home Loans.
(3) Under what circumstances are female members of the Defence Forces eligible to receive Defence Service Home Loans.
(4) Does nursing qualify as operations against the enemy when nurses served in forward areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Consistent with the basic principle adopted when the Defence Service Homes Scheme was introduced in 1919, benefits under the Scheme in respect of service in World War II have been available, in general, only to men and women who were enlisted in, or appointed to, Forces raised for service outside Australia or who actually served outside Australia.

Accordingly, service in the wartime Citizen Military Forces and Women's Services, which were not raised for service outside Australia, is not qualifying service for Defence Service Homes benefits unless the member, man or woman, served outside Australia.
(3) Female members of the Defence Force are eligible for a Defence Service Homes loan on exactly the same basis as are male members.
Eligibility for a loan was extended in 1973 to members of the Defence Force who were serving on or after 7 December 1972 and who complete 3 years' effective full-time service.

In 1978 a separate eligibility test was introduced to apply to members whose service commenced on or after 17 August 1977. Those members are required to complete a period of 6 years' effective full-time service and to enter into a commitment to render further full-time service before becoming eligible for a loan.
A member of the Defence Force who served after World War II and whose service terminated before 7 December 1972 is eligible for a loan if he or she:

(a) was allotted for duty in connection with the warlike operations in Korea between 27 June 1950 and 31 August 1957 (inclusive) or in Malaya between 29 June 1950 and 31 August 1957 (inclusive) and left the last port of call in Australia or other part of the Queen's dominions before 1 September 1957 to serve in connection with those operations;
(b) served on land betwen 1 September 1957 and 27 May 1963 (inclusive) in the area of Malaya or in the area of the Island of Singapore and its then dependencies other than Christmas Island; or
(c) served on 'special service' as defined in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act in a prescribed 'special area'.
(4) This is not a consideration in determining eligibility under the Defence Service Homes Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the reasons for Australia being excluded from the proposed 22 Nation Summit Conference to be held in Mexico in October 1981 to discuss North-South problems, following publication of the Brandt Report on International Development Issues.
(2) Were efforts made to secure an invitation; if so, what.
(3) Did he receive the support of the Administration of the United States of America or the Government of the United Kingdom in his efforts to secure an invitation.
(4) What reasons were given for Australia's rejection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: For reasons which are well understood, the number of Heads of Government to attend the Conference at Cancun in Mexico in October 1981 was limited. Australia did not attend, but the Australian Government had long been concerned to do what it could to contribute to a successful outcome from the Cancun proceedings. North/South matters were prominent in discussions at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne, as Australia had hoped, and both CHOGM and the Cancun meeting were notable for their constructive spirit. Because of the great importance of these issues and my Chairmanship of the Commonwealth meeting, I had discussions earlier this year both with Commonwealth leaders and with other world leaders who would be attending the Cancun Summit, including both co-chairmen. These discussions proved extremely useful in registering Australia's views on North/South matters and as a preparation for the Melbourne Commonwealth meeting. The Melbourne meeting achieved a substantial consensus on North/South matters and, in the Government's view, made a significant contribution to the deliberations at Cancun.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current condition of Mawson's Hut, Commonwealth Bay, Antarctica.
(2) What work has been done by (a) Australia and (b) other nations on the hut during the last 10 years.
(3) What are the current plans in relation to the preservation, maintenance and location of the hut.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In January/February 1978 a party from the Antarctic Division visited Commonwealth Bay to inspect Mawson's Hut, to assess the feasibility of returning it to Australia and to do some restoration work. The party found that the condition of the hut reflected the severe weather conditions it has had to withstand. They reported that the outer timbers had been reduced to half their original thickness and had shrunk leaving gaps between the boards. The inner and main timbers were generally in good condition; however, some repairs and replacement would be necessary.
The party recommended that because of the condition of the hut and the variable weather conditions no attempt should be made to return it to Australia and that it should be restored on site.

(2) Only Australia has worked on the restoration of Mawson's Hut. Restoration commenced in the 1975-76 austral summer when roof hatches were repaired, but the main work was carried out in January 1978 when four expeditioners spent over a month at the site.
A number of tasks were undertaken by the 1978 party and they include:
temporary weather sealing of roof and outer timber lining of the hut;
excavation of workshop hut;
approximately 120 cubic metres of ice removed from the inside of the hut;
hut photographed inside and out and a film of restoration work made;
all items of historical importance catalogued and photographed.
In addition, meteorological data was collected to compare with that collected by Mawson's expedition.

(3) The Government has decided that Mawson's Hut should be restored on its present site. This decision has been endorsed by the Australian Heritage Commission which fully supports the arguments which led to this decision (these arguments are summarised on page 1124 of Senate Hansard 2 April 1981).

The next step is weatherproofing of the outer timber lining so that the hut can be cleared of ice and snow. Under present arrangements, restoration work will not recommence for several years. This is because of the present heavy commitment to the rebuilding of our Antarctic stations.

My Department has reviewed its program to see if restoration work can be brought forward. I have been advised that the demand on logistics for the rebuilding program will continue for several years. As the rebuilding program passes its peak, it will be possible to send vessels to Commonwealth Bay to continue the restoration work.
Mawson's Hut is a monument of great importance to Australia and it is my intention that restoration work will continue at the earliest possible date.

(c) the largest 100 companies ranked by capitalised market value.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The number of income tax returns that were lodged by companies in each financial year from 1970-71 to 1979-80 were as follows:
NO. OF RETURNS LODGED

(2) The total value of profits attributable to these companies is not available from taxation statistics. Australian Bureau of Statistics data are available on income of 'corporate trading enterprises' and 'financial enterprises'. The income before tax of these companies from 1970-71 to 1979-80 was as follows:
Trading Financial
Enterprises Enterprises Total

(3)(a) The ABS does not provide a breakdown of the data on income of trading and financial enterprises into the income attributable to foreign-controlled enterprises and to Australian-Controlled enterprises. There are available data on profits and dividends payable abroad; these data enable a measure to be derived of the proportion of company income, after payment of tax, that is payable abroad. For the period 1970-71 to 1979-80, this proportion was as follows:
ADJUSTED INCOME PAYABLE OVERSEAS AS A PERCENTAGE OF TOTAL COMPANY INCOME AFTER TAX
Source: Derived from ABS data.

My press release no. 35 of 31 March 1980 provided details of the method of calculating this proportion and outlined some qualifications about its use. In particular, the proportion is subject to a good deal of short-term fluctuation, as evidenced by the fall in the proportion in 1978-79 and the subsequent increase in 1979-80 (after preliminary data had indicated that the proportion had stabilised). These include a tendency for the profitability of foreign-controlled enterprises to differ from the Australian-controlled enterprises, and for the profitability and taxation payments of sectors in which foreign ownership is relatively high to vary relative to other sectors. For these reasons considerable care must be excercised in drawing any conclusions relating to foreign participation from the proportion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say in which countries tax deductions are permitted for maintenance payments by divorced persons.
(2) If so, what amount is deductible in each case.
(3) Has the Australian Government considered a similar course.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am not able to list all of the countries in which tax deductions are permitted for maintenance payments by divorced persons, or the amount deductible in each case, and it would be misleading to give an incomplete list since the many countries that would not be included might or might not allow such deductions. It is, of course, known that a good many countries do allow deductions and while I am unable to speak with authority on the taxation laws of other countries, I can say that in some cases a deduction is allowed for the whole of the maintenance paid while in other cases there is a limit on the amount that may be deducted. In many cases allowance of a deduction is subject to various conditions being satisfied. The maintenance payments are often taxable in the hands of the recipient, at least up to the amount allowable as a deduction to the payer.

(3) The Government has, from time to time, considered representations received from persons proposing that tax deductions be allowed for alimony or maintenance payments by divorced persons to their former marital partners. However, to amend the law as has been proposed would be contrary to the basic principle of the income tax law that a deduction is only allowable for expenditure incurred in gaining or producing assessable income. Expenditure of a private nature is precluded from deduction. Furthermore, such a proposal would place divorced persons who pay alimony or maintenance to their former partners in a more advantageous position than a married taxpayer who contributes to the maintenance of his or her spouse during a year and who is limited to a maximum concessional rebate of $830 in respect of that maintenance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article entitled 'the dove in the classroom' in The Guardian, London, 21 April 1981, and circulars from Parents and Teachers Against Violence in Education.

(2) What moves has the Minister's Department made towards planning and/or supporting a widening of peace studies in schools and colleges, including military training establishments, in the public service and elsewhere, in accordance with UNESCO principles and other international conventions and commitments.
(3) How do these moves compare with those of other countries and non-government school systems, including Quakers' schools, in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) As a Member State of UNESCO, Australia shares a concern that mutual understanding between peoples, respect for human rights and access to education and information are important among the foundations upon which a lasting peace may be built. The Australian National Commission for UNESCO has in recent years sponsored two seminars on the topics of 'Teacher Education for International Understanding' (1977) and 'Teaching of Human Rights' (at the tertiary and adult education levels) (1980). These seminars drew participants from a wide range of educational interests, and were influential in promoting consideration and study of the teaching issues involved.

In keeping with the obligations of its membership of the United Nations, Australia supports the inclusion in the whole school curriculum of studies, which will contribute to the promotion of peace and international understanding. The Commonwealth's national role in curriculum development has been carried out by the Curriculum Development Centre (CDC). In June 1980, the CDC published a discussion paper entitled 'Core Curriculum for Australian Schools'. Two of the eight areas of knowledge and experience nominated were 'social, cultural and civic studies', and 'moral reasoning and action, value and belief systems'. Studies related to peace and international understanding could be encompassed within these areas. The CDC paper has been considered by State and non-government education authorities, which are primarily responsible for the determination of curriculum matters.
(3) There is insufficient information available to enable valid comparisons to be made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does a family with 2 wages have 2 tax-free thresholds and thereby save $2648 in tax.
(2) Does a family with one wage have one tax-free threshold plus an $830 spouse rebate thereby saving only $2172 in tax.
(3) If so, do families with one pay packet therefore pay nearly $10 a week more pro rata than a 2 income family on the same combined income.
(4) Would an increase in spouse rebate from $830 to $1342 redress this anomaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) If each wage was $4195 or more for 1981-82 the tax-free threshold of $4195 would apply in each case.
(2) The tax-free threshold is available to all individual taxpayers. Where a taxpayer wholly maintains his or her spouse a rebate of $830 is also available.
(3) The difference in tax in the two situations would depend on the level of the combined income and the proportions in which it was shared.

(4) The effects of increasing the spouse rebate to $1342 would also depend on the level of the combined income and the proportions in which it was shared. One effect would be that, under existing arrangements for shading-out entitlement to the spouse rebate by reference to the spouse's separate net income, a taxpayer whose spouse had a separate net income equal to the $4195 tax-free threshold would be entitled to a spouse rebate of $364.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have work projects undertaken in respect of the development of Brisbane Airport involved the extensive use by heavy vehicles of Kingsford Smith Drive; if so, during which hours and on what days do the trucks use Kingsford Smith Drive.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that an increase in the volume of traffic along Kingsford Smith Drive due to the development of Brisbane Airport, has been a source of annoyance and concern to residents living next to the road.

(3) In connection with which projects involved in the Brisbane Airport development will trucks be using extensively (a) Kingsford Smith Drive (b) Sandgate Road (c) Gympie Road and (d) Nudgee Road from January 1981 to January 1982.

(4) In those cases where tenants residing in flats adjacent to roads which experience a significantly increased volume of traffic due to the airport development, vacate those flats because of an increase in noise, will any form of compensation be made to the owners of those flats.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Work projects undertaken as part of the redevelopment of Brisbane International Airport have involved delivery of gravel and fill material by truck to the site both along Kingsford Smith Drive and via the Sir James Holt vehicular ferry. Trucks using the ferry would account for about 10-15 per cent of the total operations. These operations commenced in mid October 1980 with the delivery of about 500 truck loads over 10 days.
Subsequent hauling operations in November and December 1980 of filling material for construction of bunds for the rehandling basin peaked at about 200-250 truck loads per day.

Except for the trucking of approximately 2,000 cubic metres of gravel during February and March 1981, haulage operations did not resume again until May 1981. These operations have continued to the present with a maximum hauling rate of about 120 truck loads per day.

Some works at the existing Eagle Farm Airport have also involved trucking operations with approximately 50 concrete trucks and 1,000 gravel trucks proceeding to the existing Airport via Kingsford Smith Drive and approximately 550 trucks via Nudgee Road during the period from 30 June 1981 to 30 September 1981.

Trucking operations have been confined to daylight hours on six days per week, generally not earlier than 7.00 a.m. and not later than 6.00 p.m. on weekdays and 2.00 p.m. on Saturdays. These operations have been in accordance with Brisbane City Council and State Government regulations.

(2) I understand the Member for Lilley's office sought information from the Department of Housing and Construction on 24 November 1980 following complaints from Kingsford Smith Drive residents. It was advised that two airport projects involving improvements to Sugarmill Road, and the construction of a bund for the rehandling of spoil had generated some truck traffic along Kingsford Smith Drive.

Further information was sought by your office on 21 May 1981 as to the trucking traffic. The Department advised that contractor's trucks were restricted to daylight hours and to legal load limits. I have been advised that at the time of this enquiry, a considerable number of trucks were also using Kingsford Smith Drive for trucking coal for export.

(3) Further projects on the airport redevelopment will involve the haulage of construction materials to the site. At this stage it is not possible to predict the traffic distribution between Kingsford Smith Drive, Sandgate Road, Gympie Road, Nudgee Road and the vehicular ferry as the routes to be trafficked will depend on the location of source material and other factors determined by contract bidding at the time.

(4) The various non-airport developments taking place in the lower reaches of the Brisbane River and in the north/north eastern suburbs of the city are generating a steadily increasing volume of traffic on Kingsford Smith Drive.

The current traffic volume along Kingsford Smith Drive during daylight hours is understood to be about 11,000 to 14,000 vehicles in each direction including 2,600 to 2,800 heavy vehicles. Undoubtedly this volume will increase as a result of the widening of the road from three to four lanes by the Brisbane City Council, from grants provided by the Commonwealth for developmental roads.

Despite increased usage with widening and improvements to Kingsford Smith Drive, which will be completed shortly, it is expected that these measures will smooth out the flow of traffic and contribute to a reduction in traffic noise.

The extra truck traffic generated along Kingsford Smith Drive by the Brisbane Airport development represents only a relatively small proportion of the total trucking traffic and it is not considered to have been the specific cause of any deterioration in amenity for local residents.

Even at its heaviest, the airport trucking traffic only represents a small percentage of the total heavy vehicle movements along Kingsford Smith Drive. Furthermore, Kingsford Smith Drive is a public road, along which a high volume of heavy traffic has passed for many years.
Accordingly, I do not consider that compensation by the Commonwealth is appropriate to flat tenants along Kingsford Smith Drive who vacate because of noise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Australian of 24 August 1981 which quotes a report from the United States of America Department of Defence indicating that the Trident submarine would be deployed in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and not the Indian Ocean.
(2) Will he seek assurances from the U.S. Government that Trident submarines will not be introduced into the Indian Ocean, as it would extend the nuclear arms race in that area; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) No. Although the U.S. has stated publicly that it does not routinely deploy its ballistic missile submarines through the Indian Ocean, to constrain those submarines from entering the Indian Ocean would simplify efforts to detect and track them and might thereby make vulnerable the principle element of the U.S. nuclear deterrent force. This would be prejudicial to international security.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Review of Commonwealth Functions: Manpower Reviews

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 27 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which Commonwealth Government Departments have completed their manpower reviews stemming from the recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions.
(2) What staff movements have occurred in these Departments as a result of (a) natural wastage, (b) resignation, (c) redeployment and (d) retrenchment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Over and above the staffing adjustments which will be required in particular departments in implementing specific Government decisions following the Review of Commonwealth Functions the decision to achieve a further 2 per cent reduction in staff ceilings over two years will affect departmental staffing generally. In respect of this latter decision and other decisions requiring progressive implementation over a period of years manpower review will be a continuing process.
(2) (a) Staff separations ('natural wastage') from Commonwealth Departments and other bodies staffed under the Public Service Act for the period 1 May 1981 to 30 August 1981 were as follows:
Permanent staff 4,562; Temporary and exempt staff 3,129; Total staff 7,691.

(2) (b) Comprehensive statistics on resignations for the period 1 May 1981 to 30 August 1981 are not yet available. Statistics on separations from the Australian Public Service during calendar year 1980 published in the Public Service Board's 1980-81 Annual Report indicate that resignations comprise about 76 per cent of separations of permanent staff.

(2) (c) Redeployment most commonly involves the movement of staff within a department from lower to higher priority activities and does not involve the use of the provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. The redeployment of staff in this way occurs on a day to day basis and statistics on such movements are not available.

However, as a result of decisions stemming from the recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions a total of 62 staff have been declared under the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act as being eligible for redeployment because they were surplus to the requirements of their departments. As at 15 October 1981, 18 of the 62 have been redeployed. Action is continuing in relation to all others with a view to effecting their redeployment as soon as possible.

(2) (d) No officers have been compulsorily retrenched; three officers of the Department of Defence and one from the Australian Electoral Office have elected, under the Public Service Arbitrator's Determination No. 509 of 1977, with the Board's approval, to have their employment terminated and have thereby qualified for the benefits associated with retrenchment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 2257 (Hansard, 19 August 1981, page 507) in which the Member for Reid requested information on the number of departments which have access to data regarding exports of bauxite and alumina by country of consignment, why did he mention the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Bureau of Customs, the Reserve Bank and the Department of Trade and Resources but not mention the Australian Taxation Office.

(2) Does the omission of the Taxation Office from his answer mean that the Office does not have access to this information; if so, does this explain the inability of the Office to control transfer pricing practices in the industry

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Departments referred to in my answer were mentioned because they receive this information on a continuing basis for the purpose of their own administration. The Taxation Office does not receive or need this information on that basis.

(2) Although the Australian Taxation Office does not receive bauxite and alumina export data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Commissioner assures me that his ability to deal with unacceptable transfer pricing practices does not depend on his receiving that kind of information and, if it did, there are other available sources from which he could obtain it. I also refer the honourable member to my second reading speech on the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 on 28 May 1981 in which I foreshadowed the Government's intention to bring before the Parliament legislation to permit the Commissioner to deal more effectively with the transfer pricing problem, wherever it might arise.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Export of Dog and Cat Pelts

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether New Zealand has outlawed the export of dog and cat pelts since 1953.
(2) Is it a fact that Australia has no regulations prohibiting the export of dog and cat pelts.
(3) How many (a) dog and (b) cat pelts were exported for each of the years 1976-77 to 1980-81 and to what countries were they exported.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information available to me indicates that New Zealand banned the export of cat skins on 21 August 1969. However, it appears that New Zealand does not prohibit the export of dog pelts.
(2) Australia does not have regulations prohibiting the export of the pelts of cats or dogs. This matter is presently under consideration.

(3) The relevant Australian Bureau of Statistics item for the export of tanned and dressed furskins is Item 613.00.00 which is not species specific but covers furskins derived from all species including kangaroo, wallaby, possum, fox, goat, hare and rabbit skins.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics have advised that from 1 January 1982 specific export sub-items will record the export of dog and cat skins.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Libyan Claim to the Gulf of Sidra

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the Libyan Arab Republic's claim to the Gulf of Sidra is based on international law dealing with historic bays.
(2) Is the Gulf included in papers and memoranda on Historic Bays prepared by the United Nations Secretariat.
(3) Is he also able to say whether (a) Italy, (b) Malta, (c) Egypt, (d) Tunisia, (e) the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics or (f) any Mediterranean littoral countries recognise Libya's claim.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In October 1973, Libya announced that the Gulf of Sidra 'constitutes an integral part of the territory of the Libyan Arab Republic and is under its complete sovereignty'. Libya claimed that 'through history and without any dispute, the Libyan Arab Republic has exercised its sovereignty over the Gulf'.

(2) Neither the United Nations Secretariat's Memorandum of 30 September 1957 entitled 'Historic Bays' nor its study of 9 March 1962 entitled 'Juridical Regime of Historic Waters, including Historic Bays' make any reference to the Gulf of Sidra or to Libyan claims to the Gulf.

(3) We are not aware, on the information available to us, that any of the countries listed, or any of the littoral countries of the Mediterranean, has expressly recognised the Libyan claim to the Gulf of Sidra.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any cases of tenosynovitis been reported to date, in the Department or statutory authorities under the Minister's jurisdiction.

(2) If so, will the Minister state (a) how many cases have been reported, (b) in what types of work the affected persons were engaged, (c) of the cases reported how many were in respect of (i) female and (ii) male employees and (d) what age brackets appear to be most affected, in the Department and each Statutory Authority.
(3) Will the Minister provide similar information in respect of carpal tunnel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Although my department does not maintain comprehensive records by definition of injury/illness, examination of available files relating to officers who have applied for compensation under the provisions of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act indicates the following:

(a) In 9 cases tenosynovitis has been accepted as an injury for the purposes of the Act. An additional 8 cases are currently awaiting determination by a delegate of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation;
(b) With the exception of one officer who was engaged in clerical duties, all cases involve staff performing keyboard related duties;
(c) All cases are in respect of female staff;
(d) On the information available, those staff in the 32-49 years age group appear to be most affected by tenosynovitis; however, the age range for all cases was 19-56 years.
(3) No claims in respect of carpal tunnel have been received to date.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Parliamentary Liaison Officers under the Minister for Education

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: How many Parliamentary Liaison Officer positions have existed in the Minister's Department and each statutory authority under the Minister's jurisdiction in each State, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory for each year from 1970 to 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Since the establishment of the Department of Education in 1966 one position formally nominated as a full time Parliamentary Liaison Officer has been in existence. The position is currently filled, but this has not always been the case.

Both in the Department and statutory authorities within the portfolio, a number of positions primarily concerned with the preparation of replies to Ministerial correspondence also perform some minor parliamentary liaison functions as required.
All positions are located in the A.C.T.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In assessing income tax payable, why are non-employer sponsored superannuation fund contributions deducted from net income (item 37 of form A) while employer sponsored superannuation fund contributions form part of the basic concession of $1,590.
(2) Are the maximum deductions of $300 for rates and $100 for funeral expenses related to average expenditure on these items; if not, how are the figures determined.
(3) Will he take action to raise these maximum deductions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In introducing the income tax concession for personal superannuation contributions by self-employed persons and employees without employer-sponsored superannuation arrangements, the Government sought to match the taxation position of those taxpayers as closely as possible with that of employees who are members of employer-sponsored superannuation funds. The latter are able to benefit both from the fact that an income tax deduction is available to the employer for amounts contributed for the employee's benefit and by their own contributions qualifying as rebatable expenditure under the concessional rebate provisions of the income tax law. The new concession provides broadly comparable deductions for persons who do not have tax-subsidised employer contributions made for them.

(2) No; the maximum amounts of $300 for rates and $100 for funeral expenses are not related to average expenditure of these kinds by taxpayers and are not designed to offset the full cost of such expenditure. They represent the extent to which, with due regard to revenue commitments, it has been found possible to grant tax relief to taxpayers incurring such expenditure. They are expenses of a private or domestic nature and as such have no claim in taxation principle to constitute a deduction in determining taxable income. The concessional allowances made in respect of them is by way of a tax rebate to the extent that all rebatable expenditure exceeds $1,590.
(3) Concessional tax allowances are reviewed in the context of the Budget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) If full indexation of personal income tax based on movements in the CPI and without any discounting had been applied each year, then instead of the tax free threshold being $4,195 in 1981-82 what would it have been using the tax free threshold for (a) 1976-77 and (b) 1977-78 as base.

(2) What is the estimated number of taxpayers in 1981-82 who will have a taxable income of (a) below $4,195 and (b) between $4,195 and the threshold which would have applied had full tax indexation been applied each year since 1976-77.
(3) What is the estimated total tax which will be paid by those taxpayers included in part 2(b).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Effectively the tax-free threshold for resident individuals subject to tax at the general rates for the 1976-77 income year was $2,845, the maximum level of taxable income at which the gross tax payable was exceeded by the general concessional rebate of $610. If this tax-free threshold had been increased in line with the changes in the CPI from the average of the 4 quarters ended March 1976 to the average of the 4 quarters ended March 1981, the threshold would have been $4,662.
(b) The tax-free threshold for the 1981-82 income year based on the 1977-78 income year figure of $3,402, moved up in a similar manner to 1(a) by the full CPI, would have been $4,908.

(2) (a) The relevant income tax statistics of non-taxable individuals relate only to those who have occasion to lodge income tax returns and exclude, for example, dependent wives, children and certain recipients of social security benefits. The estimated number of taxpayers who will lodge returns for the 1981-82 income year, but will not be subject to tax because their taxable incomes will be less than $4,195, is about 1,300,000.
(b) The number of individuals who will have taxable incomes in the range $4,196-4,662 for the 1981-82 income year is estimated to be about 150,000.

(3) The estimated total income tax payable for the 1981-82 income year by taxpayers referred to in part 2(b) is about $10m. However, all other taxable individuals have part of their taxable income within the range $4,196 to $4,662. The total tax payable on all taxable income falling within this range in 1981-82 income year will be about $900m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Year of Disabled Persons: Sport and Recreation Needs of the Disabled

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What considerations were taken into account when the Government decided to set up the Committee on the sport and recreation needs of the disabled.

(2) Is this committee under the chairmanship of Mr Ian Wilson, MP, and is it the only committee that the Government has decided to set up in this International Year of Disabled Persons; if not, what other committees have been established.
(3) What funding will be made available to implement decisions that are made by the Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The National Committee on Sport and Recreation for the Disabled was created as an advisory committee to the Government as part of a new Government policy on recreation and sport for mentally and physically disabled persons. It is indicative of the measure of concern of the Government for IYDP and is intended to extend beyond 1981. The policy of the Government is to assist and encourage physically and mentally disabled persons to participate in sport and recreation.

The objectives of the Committee are to assist the integration of disabled athletes with non-disabled athletes and to enable the best of the disabled athletes to compete at the international level. Its chairman is Dr Jeffrey Miller, Principal of the Cumberland College of health Sciences and a member of the National Advisory Council for the Handicapped.
Other committees the Government has established to co-ordinate planning for IYDP in Australia are:
the Council of Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers for IYDP which co-ordinates Australia's national response to IYDP;
an Officials Committee, chaired by the Director-General of Social Services, which supports the Council and consists of nominated representatives of each Minister on the Council, and

the IYDP National Committee of Non-Government Organisations, established in conjunction with ACROD (Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled), which is responsible for co-ordinating the non-government sector's response to IYDP.

(3) The 1981-82 Budget allocated $200,000 to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment for programs and projects for sport and recreation for disabled people. Applications for funding were solicited through all major daily newspapers in mid-September. The National Committee on Sport and Recreation for the Disabled will be advising the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment of its recommendations for program and project funding in the near future.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Welfare Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a recent circular letter from the Australian Social Welfare Union, Queensland Branch, claiming that recruitment freezes and staffing restrictions have allowed less than half of the Social Security offices in Queensland to fulfil their allocation of 2 welfare staff, even in districts where no other trained or trainee social workers are available, and that the 3 Aboriginal Welfare Officer posts, all in Brisbane, are unfilled.
(2) If so, is it a fact that problems, some with no solution in these circumstances, are constantly being referred in growing numbers to members and senators, and to voluntary and State bodies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) & (2) The circular letter from the Australian Social Welfare Union has been brought to my attention.

The situation is that as a consequence of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government directed that the Public Service Board, in consultation with my department, review the activities of departmental social workers against the background that social work activity is to be confined to that directly related to the delivery of social security benefits, Commonwealth programs and rehabilitation services.

As to the specific references in the honourable member's question about the staffing levels for welfare staff in the offices of my department in Queensland, every attempt is made to ensure that each regional office has the services of at least one social worker.

In fact, with the exception of Bundaberg and Maryborough regional offices where recruitment action is currently underway, all regional offices in Queensland have at least one position of social worker staffed.
All 3 Aboriginal Welfare Officer positions in Brisbane are currently staffed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will luxury car phone units plus rentals, recently introduced by Telecom with costs exceeding several thousand dollars, be allowable tax deductions for vehicle users able to write-off car use, etc., as a business or company cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that mobile telephones may be either purchased or rented from Telecom. Where a taxpayer establishes that a mobile telephone is used in the course of gaining or producing assessable income, an income tax deduction would, where the instrument is purchased, be allowable by way of depreciation based on its cost and, where the instrument is rented, in respect of the rent paid. The deduction would, however, be appropriately reduced if the telephone is also used to an extent for private purposes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are interest payments derived from long-term deposits averaged out to arrive at weekly income when the pension income-test is applied by the Department of Social Security.
(2) If so, is the pension income-test on income derived from long-term deposits applied prospectively or retrospectively.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the provisions of the Social Services Act pensions are payable at an annual rate and that rate is determined by taking into account the annual rate of a person's income, including the annual rate of income from long-term deposits. Pensions are paid in fortnightly instalments, the amount of each instalment being one twenty-sixth of the determined annual rate of pension.

(2) As indicated above, the income test is applied having regard to a person's annual rate of income at the time of assessment. For example, a pensioner with $10,000 invested in long-term deposits at a rate of interest of 10 per cent would be assessed as having an annual rate of income of $1,000.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Social Welfare: Liquidation of Income-producing Assets

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that new provisions under the Social Services Act to guard against deliberate deprivation of income on the part of pensioners sanction the liquidation of income-producing assets for the purchase of (a) a car, (b) a home or (c) holidays.
(2) If so, do these provisions require that these items must be for the immediate use of the pensioner concerned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) As I announced in the Senate on 13 October 1981, there will be some delay in introducing the legislation to strengthen the provisions of the Social Services Act against schemes contrived to circumvent the income test. When the legislation has been introduced further announcements will be made as to its operational aspects. However, as I mentioned in my statement of 18 August 1981, it is not intended that the new provisions will operate to penalise people if they liquidate income-producing assets for reasonable purposes, such as the purchase of a home or a car for their personal use or for a holiday.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sales Tax on Bulk Cartage Grain Vehicles

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the reason that 17.5 per cent sales tax was imposed on bulk cartage grain vehicles in the 1981-82 Budget.
(2) Were there widespread examples of abuse of the previous concession.
(3) Is it a fact that this imposition will be heaviest in areas where there is not a well developed or close location of silos.
(4) Is it also a fact that vehicles used by cartage contractors cost up to $80,000 and that the tax will add severely to wheatgrowers' costs.
(5) Does he expect that contractors and farmers will seek to exceed truck weight limits due to the imposition, thereby causing higher costs for local road maintenance.
(6) Is he concerned that the imposition will tend to discourage the production of grain in newer areas of agricultural activity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The provision under which exemption had been gained for bulk grain vehicles was not intended to cover such goods. It was designed to cover grain storage and handling plant at grain silos and terminals at railway sidings and ports. The wording of the provision was such, however, that bulk grain vehicles were included. This fortuitous exemption was contrary to the general policy in the sales tax law that road vehicles used in the transportation of goods, whether rural products or secondary products, are subject to sales tax. The taxing of bulk grain vehicles is consistent with this general principle.
(2) Yes.
(3) No. In the more developed areas trucks are required to cart the grain from the field to the silo.
(4) The tax is significant but it is no greater than that imposed on other similar transport vehicles which for many years have borne tax.

(6) It is not expected that the sales tax will, in any significant way, discourage the production of grain in newer areas because vehicles used to transport other primary products have always been taxable and there is no evidence that this has discouraged activity in these areas of primary production. Also, it is a fact that many general cartage contractors paid tax on vehicles used to cart grain before the unintended exemption began to be exploited and their cartage rates would have been based on a tax-inclusive purchase price for their vehicles. Similarly, general purpose trucks used to cart grain at harvest time are purchased at a tax inclusive price. Rates fixed by reference to this have not discouraged the opening up of new areas of grain production.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sales Tax on Pet Food: Guide Dogs

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

(2) Will volunteers who undertake care and training (that is, puppy walker) of young dogs prior to final training and placement as guide dogs be exempted from paying sales tax on pet food.
(3) Will greyhound trainers similarly be exempted from paying the sales tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park, South Australia: Operating Theatres

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister recall my repeated questions relating to the urgent need for the replacement of the operating theatres at the Repatriation Hospital, Daw Park, South Australia.

(2) Did the Minister state in reply to question No. 2370 (Hansard, 27 August 1981, pages 960-1) that (a) the Specialist Advisory Committee had expressed concern to the Deputy Commissioner in South Australia about the theatres, (b) the Committee had also expressed concern about the future of the hospital if a decision on replacement of the theatres was not soon made and (c) the Minister was unable to provide any details about the date of commencement of the project.

(3) Did the Treasurer state in the 1981-82 Budget Speech that the Government has had before it a number of proposals for capital expenditure at the repatriation Hospitals, one of which had been considered by the Parliamentary Public Works Committee and it was not possible to announce a decision on any of these proposals, which involve the expenditure of many millions of dollars, but the Government would be giving further consideration to Repatriation hospitals later in 1981.

(4) Were reports and administrative recommendations for the replacement of the operating theatres formulated as long as 4 years ago; if so, did the recommendations support the replacement of the theatres as a matter of urgency.

(5) Are approximately 4000 operations performed annually in these theatres; if so, would it be impossible for these operations to be performed in other hospitals in the Adelaide area during the same period.

(6) In view of the mounting concern of staff, patients and in particular the Returned Services League and the South Australian Consultative Council of Ex-Servicemen's Organisations who have actively supported the need to up-date not just the operating theatres but the Hospital as a whole, and in view of the undertaking contained in the 1981-82 Budget statement, when will the Minister announce his decision appropriating the funds necessary to ensure that these outmoded operating theatres are replaced as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The concern about the facilities at Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park should be allayed by my Press Statement of 1 November 1981 indicating that the Government has decided that plans should be put to the Standing Parliamentary Committee on Public Works for the construction of four new operating theatres and surgical wards and associated facilities at the hospital, estimated to cost about $6.6m. These proposed new facilities would meet almost all the surgical needs of the veteran population in South Australia, both in terms of the number of operations and of the increasing complexity of modern surgical procedures.

The plans for re-developing part of the Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park, were announced simultaneously with the Government decision to reaffirm its commitment to the maintenance of a separate Repatriation hospital system for the treatment of entitled veterans. The Government considers that adequate funds should be provided for capital and operational expenditure at these hospitals.
These announcements should dispel any doubts about their long term future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Minister's reply to my Question No. 2810 (Hansard, 9 September 1981, page 1144) in which it was stated that the Minister would be rather surprised to hear that the Opposition was anxious to announce Government initiatives and would certainly not think it appropriate for them to do so, does the Minister appreciate the difference between Government initiatives such as the Government's decision to end direct funding of women's shelters, and a Government decision to approve continuation of funding for, say, a charity, or a nursing home, within an Opposition Member's electorate.

(2) Would the Minister be surprised to hear that an Opposition backbencher would be interested in communicating to an organisation and to the public the result of an application for Commonwealth Government funding lodged by that organisation and publicly supported by that Opposition backbencher.

(3) In cases where a routine application for funding is received from an organisation within an Opposition Member's electorate and is supported by that Member in representations to the Minister, is it regarded by the Minister or by the Department of Social Security that an announcement on a decision of the application would be inappropriate if it were made by the local, albeit Opposition, Member.
(4) Are all announcements involving routine funding allocations a matter of partisan privilege.

(5) Is the Minister prepared to reconsider the Department's practice of denying to Opposition Members the right to announce decisions on routine funding applications on the grounds that those Members are not Liberal or National Country Party Members; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that not all Government initiatives are likely to receive the enthusiastic support of Opposition members.

(2) to (5) I regard the announcement of Government initiatives within my portfolio, including the approval of funding for local projects, as a matter for me personally or for some appropriate Government spokesman. Since I do not consider Opposition backbenchers as appropriate Government spokesmen, I have no intention of changing my current practice in these matters. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Soviet Union Military Presence in other Countries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say in which countries the Soviet Union maintains a military presence, provides military assistance and military advisers, or in some other way provides tangible defence support.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Soviet Union maintains a military presence in the following countries which are members of the Warsaw Pact: Czechoslovakia, The German Democratic Republic, Hungary and Poland. (Although members of the Warsaw Pact, Romania has no significant Soviet military presence on its territory and Bulgaria has no formed Soviet combat units.) Soviet combat units are also maintained in Afghanistan and Mongolia, and a small Soviet combat brigade is stationed in Cuba. The Soviet Union maintains a naval presence in Ethiopia, the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen and Vietnam.

In addition to the above countries, the principal recipients of Soviet military assistance in the form of equipment and, in some cases, military advisers are as follows: Algeria, Angola, Congo, Guinea, India, Iran, Iraq, the People's Republic of Korea, Libya, Madagascar, Mali, Mozambique, Nicaragua, Nigeria, Peru, Syria, Tanzania, the Arab Republic of Yemen, Yugoslavia and Zambia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current waiting time for applicants for Defence Service Homes Loans.
(2) Is it a fact that the Defence Service Homes Corporation claims it cannot extend loans to servicemen already buying a home; if so, is it because of the limited capital available.
(3) Is it also a fact that in 1980-81, an appropriation of $12m to augment the capital of the Defence Service Homes Corporation, was not drawn; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A waiting time of 10 months applies to loans for the purchase of a home. The waiting period does not apply to loans for the construction of a home.

(2) In accordance with a Ministerial Direction issued in 1973 the corporation may not grant a loan for the discharge of a mortgage entered into without the prior approval of the Corporation unless the terms of the mortgage are considered to be onerous and payment of commitments under this mortgage is causing serious hardship. This Direction varied a previous Direction issued in 1951 by permitting consideration to be given to whether the terms of the mortgage are onerous by current standards. The policy applies not only to serving members of the Defence Force but to all eligible persons.

The cost of relaxation of the policy cannot be estimated with confidence, but it could be expected to be sufficiently high to require a substantial additional Budget allocation or an extension of the waiting period.

(3) At the time the 1980-81 Budget was prepared it was estimated that a capital appropriation of $12m would be required to meet the shortfall between the cost of the estimated demand for loans ($111.5m) and the funds estimated to become available from the Corporation's operations, mainly repayments of existing loans. In the event, expenditure was lower than estimated and funds available for re-lending were higher, principally because of the number of loans prematurely discharged. The estimation process was complicated in 1980-81 by the decisions to increase the maximum Defence Service Homes Loan by $10,000 to $25,000 and to reduce the waiting period from 14 months to 10 months.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1981 (Hansard, page 987) Mr Lloyd asked me, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Treasurer clarify the present confusion, and the charges of discrimination between horses, dogs and cats, in the application of sales tax to manufactured pet food, saddlery and harness? Is a person who earns his living by breeding, training or racing dogs able to purchase food and other goods for those dogs free of sales tax while someone who earns his living from training or racing horses is not exempt from paying sales tax on their food or other goods such as saddlery? Does a breeder of horses, dogs or cats have to earn his total income from this pursuit to be exempt from sales tax on food for those animals? If not, at what percentage of income does the tax apply? Are all breeds of dogs exempt if the other criteria are met or only breeds of working dogs? Finally, is the proprietor of a supermarket or other shop retailing pet food required to remove the sales tax on presentation of an exemption certificate number, or can the proprietor force the purchaser to buy his pet food only from a wholesaler?
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) The tax on pet foods applies only to foods for animals kept as domestic pets. Horses are not regarded as domestic pets but dogs and cats are. Food for horses and for dogs and cats not kept as domestic pets is exempt. All saddlery and harness is now taxable except where it is purchased for use in agricultural industry exclusively, or primarily and principally, in carrying out agricultural operations.

(2) Persons breeding or training racing dogs or training or racing horses are entitled to purchase foods for the dogs or horses free of tax. Equipment for racing dogs, such as muzzles, collars and leads, is taxable as is saddlery and harness for racing horses.

(3) A horse or dog or cat breeder does not have to earn his or her total income from such pursuits for exemption to apply for food for breeding animals. It is a question of fact whether a person operates a breeding business, either full or part-time, as distinct from merely keeping the dogs or cats as domestic pets with any breeding being incidental to their role as domestic pets.
(4) No distinction is drawn between breeds of dogs.

(5) There is no requirement at law to compel a proprietor of a supermarket or other retailer of pet food to remove the sales tax on production of an exemption certificate. Whether or not a certificate is accepted is a matter between the retailer and the customer. This situation is not new; it has existed for many years and applies also in respect of all other taxable goods that are purchased at the retail level for use in exempt circumstances. It may be that in practice a person entitled to exemption will find it more convenient to deal with a pet food supplier than with a supermarket.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 1060) Mr Ian Cameron asked me, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Treasurer ensure that, to save resources and red tape, the Treasury will allow primary producers and manufacturers to use their existing diesel certificate numbers to get an exemption from sales tax on oils and greases? They are different taxes but in the interests of good management they should be grouped on the same certificate.
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

On 9 September 1981 Mr Ian Cameron (Hansard, page 1060) asked me, without notice, whether primary producers could use their existing diesel certificate numbers to obtain exemption from sales tax on oils and greases.

I indicated that this was an administrative matter which I would take up with the Commissioner of Taxation. I have since received further information from the honourable member that dealers and agents involved in marketing oils and greases have expressed concern about the administrative procedures necessary to gain exemption.

The Commissioner has advised that, while a diesel certificate number may assist in establishing the bona fides of a person claiming exemption from sales tax, it would not be practicable from a legal viewpoint to use one certificate for two different taxes. The exemptions are not parallel and there are different responsibilities under the relevant legislation involved. It would not be practicable or desirable to cover the requirements of two different sets of legislation with one certificate.

The Commissioner suggested that any supplier of oils and greases experiencing problems with exemption claims should contact the local taxation office where officers would be available to discuss the matter. The kind of problems likely to arise in this area have arisen previously in other situations and satisfactory solutions found.

I mention also that the Government is at present reviewing the system of exemption certificates under the sales tax law. The information supplied by the honourable member will be taken into account in this review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many reports of landings by foreign fishermen on the north-west coast of Australia and adjacent islands have been received since July 1977.
(2) Were any of these reports substantiated; if so, what are the details.
(3) Did any reports refer to animals accompanying the fishermen; if so, were they substantiated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Accurate records of the kind needed to answer the honourable member's questions have only been kept since July 1978 with the introduction of the Government's upgraded Civil Coastal Surveillance Program. Since then fifty-four reports have been received of foreign vessels being sighted in positions or situations from which it had to be assumed for quarantine purposes that landings on the north-west coast of Australia or adjacent islands had occurred or were about to occur.
(2) On investigation it was possible to verify that landings on Australian soil had occurred on twenty-five of those occasions. Details are as follows:

25.9.79-An Army Nomad aircraft sighted an Indonesian fishing vessel in the vicinity of Adele Island. The Transport vessel M.V. Cape Pillar responded and found that the food and water cache at the Adele Island lighthouse had been stolen and there was Indonesian writing on the lighthouse walls. The fishing vessel could not be relocated.

3.10.79-Littoral surveillance aircraft sighted two Indonesian fishing vessels anchored off Tapers Inlet with canoes heading from the beach to the vessel. A chartered helicopter response was mounted and the landing confirmed but the fishing vessel was not relocated.

18.10.79-Littoral surveillance aircraft sighted one Indonesian fishing vessel at Cartier Islet with two people on the beach tending fish drying racks. The fishing vessel departed on the aircraft's approach.

21.10.79-Aborigines from One Arm Point Mission reported landing of crews from two Indonesian fishing vessels on West Roe Island. An Animal Quarantine Officer, on investigation, confirmed the landings. The vessels could not be relocated.

27.10.79-Chartered aircraft on surveillance response task reported an Indonesian fishing vessel hidden in mangroves at Sir Frederick Island. The surveillance chartered vessel 'Collendina' responded, escorted the fishing vessel to sea and issued warnings.

29.10.79-Littoral surveillance aircraft sighted an Indonesian fishing vessel at Bedford Island with one person on shore and three canoes in the vicinity. The fishing vessel was boarded by officers from the Customs vessel 'Jacana' and then escorted to sea.

25.11.79-Littoral surveillance aircraft sighted an Indonesian fishing vessel moored in mangroves at East Sunday Island. The surveillance chartered vessel 'D.McD' could not relocate the fishing vessel.
27.11.79-The chartered vessel 'D.McD' located and boarded an Indonesian fishing vessel hidden in mangroves at Tide Rip Island. The fishing vessel departed the area overnight.

28.11.79-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported an Indonesian fishing vessel with three people having landed at High Island. The chartered vessel 'D.McD' located two Indonesian vessels high and dry on the beach. The masters of the vessels were warned and then escorted to sea.

7.12.79-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported an Indonesian fishing vessel hidden in mangroves at Bedford Island. Health and Fisheries officers from the surveillance chartered vessel 'Collendina' boarded the fishing vessel and escorted it to sea following a warning being given.
11.12.79-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported an Indonesian fishing vessel hidden in mangroves at Mermaid Island. Officers from HMAS Adroit boarded the vessel and ordered it to sea.

16.12.79-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported an Indonesian fishing vessel hidden in mangroves at Pascoe Island. Officers from HMAS Ardent confirmed the landing, boarded the vessel and confiscated a quantity of fish and trochus. The following day the vessel was escorted to sea and a warning issued.

17.4.80-Three reports were received and confirmed by littoral surveillance aircraft of Indonesian fishermen having made landings on various islands. Two vessels were seen at Island Reef, 25 miles north west of Cafferelli Island, one vessel on High Island, and another two hidden in mangroves at Sunday Island. In response to these reports the Customs vessel 'Jacana', with two Quarantine Officers and a State Police Officer on board, boarded four Indonesian vessels in King Sound between 17 and 19 April, whilst W.A. Fisheries Inspectors on board HMAS Aware boarded a total of eleven vessels in the vicinity of Scott, Ashmore and Brue Reefs. All vessels were given warnings and departed the area.

20.4.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported two Indonesian fishing vessels at the west island of the Lacepedes group with canoes on the beach. Further investigation failed to relocate the vessels.

8.5.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported one Indonesian fishing vessel at Adele Island with a landing having occurred. Fisheries officers from the surveillance chartered vessel 'Collendina' confirmed the landing, boarded the Indonesian vessel and issued warnings. The fishing vessel departed the area.
13.5.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft sighted one Indonesian fishing vessel hidden in mangroves at Curlew Bay. The vessel could not be relocated on further investigation.
2.6.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft sighted one Indonesian fishing vessel anchored at North Maret Island with people foraging on the reef. Subsequent investigation failed to relocate the vessel.

9.6.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported one Indonesian fishing vessel beached at Adele Island. Officers from the chartered vessel 'Axion' boarded two Indonesian vessels in the area. The masters denied landing at Adele Island and were directed to leave the area.

14.6.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported one Indonesian fishing vessel camouflaged in mangroves at East Roe Island. This vessel was subsequently boarded by officers from HMAS Ardent and escorted to sea.

15.6.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported one Indonesian fishing vessel hidden in mangroves at Sunday Island. Officers from the chartered vessel 'Axion' investigated, towed the vessel clear of the island and HMAS Ardent escorted it to sea.

16.6.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported two Taiwanese fishing vessels aground on Churchill Reef. Fisheries officers on board HMAS Ardent investigated and found two licensed Taiwanese fishing vessels, one of which had accidently run aground. It was refloated at the next high tide.

22.7.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported one Indonesian fishing vessel hidden in mangroves at Gregory Island with the crew gathering trochus shells on reef. Officers on board HMAS Ardent investigated the report, apprehended the vessel and towed it to Koolan Island. Legal proceedings were instituted and the master was subsequently fined for illegal landing and the vessel was confiscated.

23.7.80-Littoral surveillance aircraft reported one Indonesian fishing vessel beached on Bedford Island. This vessel was apprehended by officers on board HMAS Ardent and towed to Koolan Island. Legal proceedings were instituted with similar results as in preceding incident.
(3) No. However, reports from Defence officers include references to birds being found on foreign fishing vessels boarded by them on the high seas off Western Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the 1980 amendment to s. 183 of the Copyright Act removed from all educational institutions the protection afforded by the wording 'for the services of the Commonwealth or State' in relation to audiovisual recording.
(2) Will possible breaches of the amended Act by Members, Senators and users of the Parliamentary Library be overlooked.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 183 of the Copyright Act 1968 provided certain protection from infringement of copyright in respect of acts 'done for the services of the Commonwealth or State'. Section 24 of the Copyright Amendment Act 1980 added a new provision to s. 183 which qualifies this protection in relation to educational institutions 'of, or under the control of, the Commonwealth, a State or the Northern Territory.' The extent of that qualification is a matter of legal opinion. I would add that on 12 July 1981 the Attorney-General announced that his Department would carry out a review of the provisions of the Copyright Act concerning copying by audiovisual means.

(2) Infringement of copyright is, under the Copyright Act, mainly a matter for civil proceedings, and the decision to commence any such proceedings is thus a matter for the owner of a copyright which is alleged to have been infringed.
(3) See answer to (1) above.
