QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the considerable alarm, concern and confusion caused by telephone calls from a spokesman for the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority to several fishing enterprises and business concerns in the Northern Territory and Queensland, in which it was stated that consideration was being given to changing the Fuel Freight Subsidy Scheme by removing existing freight differentials for safe anchorage locations in northern Australia and restricting these differentials to 6 mainland points only.
(2) Is there any sustance in this report; if so, by what authority was this action taken.

(3) Can he assure the House that before the action was taken, his colleague the Minister for Primary Industry was consulted on the matter; if so, what was the reaction of the Minister for Primary Industry.
(4) Was the fishing industry consulted on this matter.
(5) Has he considered the very serious effect the reported action would have on the operations of the northern prawn trawling industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) The Petroleum Products Pricing Authority (PPPA) has a statutory responsibility to determine whether the prices of certain petroleum products, or services associated with their supply, are justified. In this context the PPPA has been examining fuel freight differentials for areas such as safe anchorages in the Gulf of Carpentaria where, over time, anomalies in the differentials have arisen.

The PPPA contacted oil companies and those fishing operators which, as agents of oil companies, have had freight differentials established for them and indicated that it was considering restriction of freight differentials to ports in the Gulf region. The PPPA invited those contacted to put views to it concerning the freight differentials.

As the examination by the PPPA has implications of the rates of subsidy payable on fuel delivered to safe anchorages, the Minister for Primary Industry and other relevant Ministers have been informed of the development. In addition I have met with representatives of the Gulf fishing industry and discussed the operation of the fuel freight subsidy scheme with them.

Currently with the PPPA examination of freight differentials, a number of aspects of the scheme are being reviewed by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. As part of that review, consideration is being given to the effects of the scheme on industries in remote areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

(2) What Commonwealth Government regulations apply to importation of coffee.
(3) Do Commonwealth Government regulations in any way apply to the quality of imported instant coffee.

(4) Has any Australian import company trading with a near east country been prosecuted recently for substituting acorns and other grains in imported instant coffee; if so, under what State or Commonwealth Acts was action taken.
(5) What was the result of prosecution.
(6) What guarantees can he provide concerning the quality of imported instant coffee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Bureau of Statistics advises that separate statistics are not available to enable the percentage to be calculated.

(2) The Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations provide for a control over the importation of coffee in accordance with Australia's obligations as a member country of the International Coffee Organisation.
In addition those Regulations and the Commerce (Imports) Regulations provide for standardised sizes and labelling requirements for pre-packed coffee.
(3) Commonwealth import regulations do not apply to the quality of imported instant coffee. However, the National Health and Medical Research Council has approved a standard for coffee.

The standard covers the composition and quality of coffee in its many forms and specifies, inter alia, that coffee shall be derived from the coffee bean and shall not contain any foreign substance. Approved National Health and Medical Research Council Standards are recommended to the States and Territories for adoption into the food control legislation of the relevant authorities. When incorporated in the food laws of the States and Territories the standards are applicable to imported and local foods.

(4) and (5) I am not aware of any recent prosecution in connection with the quality of imported instant coffee. If a prosecution did take place it would have taken place under the relevant State or Territory food laws.

(c) I am advised the Commission's attention has been drawn to an article in an American journal which discussed faults in the Tandy TRS80 which seemed to be similar to those which had been experienced with the Sharp PC1211. The Commission has recently learnt that there may be little significant difference between the two units. The Commission therefore intends to approach Tandy on the matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1981 (Hansard, page 987) Mr Kent asked me a question, without notice, concerning the quarantine risk of the importation of pollen.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

My Department has undertaken an extensive study on the effects of chalkbrood fungus and the possibility of viable pseudosclerotia being included in consignments of pollen. My Department's investigations do indicate that a tenuous link exists that could create a risk of entry of the disease with importations of bee-collected pollen. For example, discarded containers holding the remnants of any infected pollen may prove attractive to bees and provide a possible means of introducing the disease into bees in the wild in Australia.

I have approved the drafting of legislation to ban the importation of bee-collected pollen. Given the nature of the disease link and the need, where practical, to ensure that industry and others be given time to adjust, I do not consider that it would be appropriate to introduce interim measures to prevent the entry of bee-collected pollen before the proposed legislation becomes effective.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 1155) Mr Robert Brown asked me, as Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning contribution rates of hospital insurance funds.

ANSWER.PARA: The following is the answer to the honourable member's question:

Where a registered health insurance organisation changes its rates of contribution, it is required under the National Health Act (section 78) to notify the Permanent Head of the Department of Health in writing of the change within seven days after the change is made. The change is inoperative and has no legal effect unless and until the Minister's approval of the change has been given. Any change to an organisation's rules which has financial implications, such as a change in contribution rates, is referred to the Registration Committee for examination and report to the Minister. The Committee comprises the Commonwealth Actuary, or a person appointed by the Commonwealth Actuary to act in his stead, and two officers of the Department of Health appointed by the Permanent Head.

However, the prime responsibility for ensuring that contribution rates are viable lies with the organisations themselves. The onus is on an organisation, when notifying a change in rates, to provide sufficient supporting data that will enable the Registration Committee to undertake a proper assessment of the change and then make an appropriate recommendation to the Minister. Factors taken into account by the Committee include the following:

(i) The financial experience of both the hospital and medical benefits funds, by tables of benefit for the latest year ended 30 June. This acquaints the Committee with the surplus or deficit situation and the level of reserves of each fund, thereby providing a basis for consideration of the effects of the proposed change.

(ii) The estimated financial experience of each fund, by tables, for the period between 30 June and the date of effect of the new rates. The financial experience is arrived at after taking into consideration any recent movements in membership, the average level of benefits and per capita claims utilisation as well as general cost movements which might affect the level of management expenses and the likely amount of non-operating income accruing to the fund having regard to the funds' investments at 30 June. Detailed statistics relating to membership benefits and claims utilisation are maintained by the Department of Health from quarterly returns furnished by the health insurance organisations themselves.

(iii) A projected financial experience for each fund, by tables, for a period of twelve months from the date of effect of the new contribution rates. This takes into account similar factors as in (ii) above. However, where the proposed change is the result of a major revision of the health insurance arrangements, particular attention is given to the likely impact on fund experience of new benefits or increases in levels of existing benefits. In this regard, an assessment is made of the effect on claims utilisation of a possible future redistribution of membership between tables. Similarly, the Committee considers to what extent new members might be attracted and the effect this might have on future experience.

(iv) The estimated result for twelve months having regard to the factors set out in (iii) above and level of reserves, expressed in months of contribution income, at the end of the projected period. The Committee recognises that organisations might incorporate components in their proposed contribution rates to build-up reserves to satisfactory levels. The Committee also needs to be satisfied that, as far as it can determine, adequate provision has been made for outstanding claims of contributors.
(v) In the case of a hospital benefits fund, the extent of the distribution of moneys from the Hospital Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund.

(vi) Whether the contribution rates proposed by the organisation generally adhere to the community rating principle. In this context the same contribution rates should be charged for all members of the one table, with the single rate set at half the family rate.
(vii) Any other factors that the Committee considers relevant in the case of a particular fund.

Some of the larger organisations employ the services of an actuary to determine changes in contribution rates and the Committee is sometimes furnished with a copy of the actuary's report for its information.

If, after examining the effect of a change, the Committee considers that the change imposes any unreasonable or inequitable condition affecting the rights of contributors or adversely affects the financial stability of a fund, the Committee is required to state its opinion and the reasons for its opinions in its report to the Minister.

The financial experience of the respective health insurance organisations often varies considerably. Therefore, the Registration Committee necessarily adopts a flexible approach when examining proposals to change contribution rates, having regard to the particular set of circumstances pertaining to each fund.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The commodities listed in Part 1 of the question were included in a list of commodities on which I indicated in my statement on 15 December 1978 that my Department would be consulting with industry and the States on their possible removal from export control.

Following those consultations nickel was included in the list of minerals for which I authorised blanket approvals on 12 June 1979. Copper ores, concentrates, matte and refined copper were added to the list in a joint statement by the Ministers for Industry and Commerce, Business and Consumer Affairs and myself on 22 July 1980. As a consequence, it is no longer necessary for exporters of these commodities to seek export approvals for individual shipments or contracts and exporters are able to seek approvals covering their annual tonnages. This procedures enables the Government to monitor the export of these minerals with a minimum of involvement.
In relation to salt, there is still a requirement for approval of individual shipments or contracts. However, this situation is at present under review.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Use of Adjacent Land

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports which appeared in the Brisbane Courier Mail prior to the 1980 Federal election, in which the former member for Lilley referred to advice provided by independent consultants to his Department on the matter of recreational uses to which land adjacent to the Brisbane Airport might be put.
(2) If so, did these reports refer to specific possible recreational uses, such as boating, horse riding, orienteering, bike riding and shooting.

(3) Can he say whether the former member said in the reports that these activities (a) had been recommended by the advisers and (b) would not impede the efficient running of the airport or add to the hazards of flying.

(4) Is the advice referred to contained in a report commissioned by the Government; if so, (a) who were the independent consultants, (b) when were they commissioned, (c) when and to whom was their report submitted, (d) is the report regarded as confidential, and, if so, what is the reason and (e) was the report made available officially or unofficially to anyone outside his Department and, if so, to whom, and on what basis was it made available.
(5) Can he say how the former member received the information he released to the media and used in election pamphlets.
(6) Did he receive a request from my office for a copy of the consultants' report to be made available to me.
(7) Is it a fact that that request was denied on the basis that the document was confidential.
(8) What recreational facilities does the report recommend as suitable for land adjacent to the airport.
(9) What is his Department's appraisal of the feasibility of each recommendation.
(10) If he will not release the recommendations of the report, what is the reason.
(11) What recreational facilities does the Government regard as suitable for development on land adjacent to the airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention has been drawn to an article which appeared in the Brisbane Courier Mail of 15 September 1980, which reported the former member for Lilley, as saying inter alia: that recreation experts had recommended to the then Minister for Housing and Construction, the Hon. R. J. Groom, that the area of the seven kilometre estuary and floodway associated with the airport could be used for more than 40 different leisure activities.
I am also aware of a similar but more detailed article on the front page of the North Eastern edition of the Express suburban newspaper of 17 September 1980.

(2) The newspaper reports did refer to specific possible recreational uses such as boating, horse riding, orienteering, bike riding and scouting. It is assumed that the reference to shooting in the question is intended to be scouting.

(3) I am not in a position to indicate what any previous member may have said or not said to the media. Both the above press articles included the comment, although it was not reported as being quoted by the former member, that the consultants say the recreational opportunities suggested would in no way impede the efficient running of the airport or add to the hazards associated with flying.

(4) (a) Yes, the above quotation is contained in a report prepared jointly by the Department of Housing and Construction and consultants. The Department of Housing and Construction commissioned a firm of consultants called Recreational Resource Management Pty Ltd to undertake a study of possible recreational uses of the floodway to assist the Department in its advisings to the Department of Transport Australia. This study formed the basis of the report.
(b) The firm was commissioned on 30 May 1980.
(c) Following submission of the consultants' study report to the Department of Housing and Construction it was then jointly modified with the consultants and finalised in September 1980.

(d) It is an internal Departmental report which was, and still is, subject to examination and review by Department of Transport Australia. It was prepared to assist Department of Transport Australia in their on-going considerations on possible land usage. As such, it did not and does not necessarily represent the final outcome as many other issues have still to be taken into account.

(e) The report was of course given to Department of Transport Australia by the Department of Housing and Construction. I am not in a position to comment on whether or not anyone other than Departmental officers gave the report or parts of the report to anyone else.
(5) I am not responsible for any action of any previous member of this Parliament.
(6) Yes.

(7) At my request, my Senior Private Secretary rang your office to advise that I was not prepared to release the report because I consider it premature to generate any public demand for space or facilities which might be incompatible with long term strategy for use, operation and maintenance of the floodway area and surrounds before all aspects and implications have been fully examined.

At the present time, the floodway usage aspects of the report are being taken into account in formulating the conditions under which possible use might be made of the floodway land for consideration by the various levels of Government. This is being done by the Joint Government Co-ordinating Committee (JGCC) on Brisbane Airport Redevelopment which has established a Floodway Usage Advisory Group to advise it. I have not agreed to release the report to anyone outside the respective Departments.

(8) The report does not make recommendations as to the suitability of any particular recreation facilities but rather canvasses a range of options and comments on the advantages and disadvantages of each particular option. Within the options, the sorts of activities which presented themselves are, inter alia:

barbecuing, boating, cycling, eating, fishing, horse-riding, trail bike riding, photography, picnicking, reading, relaxing, sight seeing, canoeing, caravan park, dog training, fossicking, hiking, orienteering, rowing, sailing, swimming.

(9) The Department of Housing and Construction has made no assessment of the feasibility of the various options proposed pending effective stabilisation of the floodway banks, review of the floodway performance, and the outcome of the considerations of the JGCC's Floodway Usage Advisory Group.
(10) See the answer to Part (7) above.

(11) I would expect that the Government would generally regard recreational facilities or activities as being suitable for the land adjacent to the airport if they are compatible with floodway performance, assist in maintaining the floodway, and do not jeopardise floodway stability or increase the problems of bird hazards and hence risk to aircraft operations from the new airport. However, the whole question of eventual floodway usage is the subject of on-going considerations by the Joint Government Co-ordinating Committee and in particular the Department of Transport Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has an assessment been made of public reaction to experimental ethnic television programs which have been shown in Sydney and Melbourne; if so (a) what was the methodological basis of this assessment and (b) what were the findings.
(2) When will multi-cultural television presently operating in these centres, be extended to other capital and provincial cities throughout Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that during the first year of operations the SBS commissioned three television surveys in Melbourne aimed at assessing audience reaction to various aspects of the Channel 0/28 service. These surveys referred to the multicultural television service, which commenced transmission on 24 October 1980, not to the limited series of experimental ethnic television programs presented in late 1979 and early 1980. It should be noted that the surveys were confined to Melbourne because of the reception difficulties experienced with Channel 0/28 in Sydney.

Two audience surveys were undertaken by McNair Anderson Associates Pty Ltd. The first, undertaken between 21 December 1980 and 10 January 1981, measured the viewing patterns of the total audience (i.e. both Australian and non-Australian born). The second, conducted during the period 16 January to 7 February 1981, surveyed nine ethnic communities, i.e. Italians, Greeks, Yugoslavs, Arabians, Germans, Maltese, Spanish, Poles and Vietnamese.
The third survey, undertaken by Inview Market Research between 23 March and 30 April 1981, involved an 'in-depth' survey of four ethnic communities: Italians, Greeks, Poles and Vietnamese.

Aspects upon which viewer reactions were sought included, in all three surveys: quality of reception (Channel 0 and 28); the channel on which the station was viewed; the quality of Channel 0/28 programs in comparison with commercial and ABC channels; Channel 0/28 program presentation style in comparison with commercial and ABC channels; individual programs presented by Channel 0/28; Channel 0/28 subtitles.

It is noteworthy that there was a reasonable consistency in the findings obtained in all three surveys. The results themselves were encouraging because they pointed to a successful introduction of the new service among the non-Australian born audience; over half of Australian born residents had watched Channel 0/28; the great majority of Channel 0/28 viewers regarded its programming and style of presentation as better or equal to that of commercial and ABC channels; there was a high level of acceptance of Channel 0/28's subtitling among the station's viewers; viewers in all language groups watched other language programs as well as their own; and, there was a favourable reaction to Channel 0/28's news, films and sports programs.
(2) The 1981-82 Budget did not allocate any funds for the extension of the multicultural television service beyond Sydney and Melbourne.

The Government is conscious that there is considerable demand for the multicultural television service in other regions. However, before any decision is taken to extend the service to other areas, considerable economic, social and technical planning and research will need to be undertaken. As part of this process the Government will also have to balance the competing claims of a variety of areas for the service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Informed public debate on the Plant Variety Rights (PVR) issue in Australia depends more upon an understanding of the principles involved in the Scheme than the details of the legislation.

Information about the proposed Scheme has been distributed widely. My own Department and several State departments responsible for agriculture have prepared information papers for general distribution. I have issued a number of Press Releases on PVR and answered many hundreds of postal enquiries from interested persons and organisations. The legislation, designed to give effect to proposals for the Scheme, has been available as a public document since it was introduced into Parliament on 7 May 1981.

I have made it clear from the outset that the form the PVR Scheme will finally take will be determined in large part by the wishes of the Australian Agricultural council but as I indicated in my Press Release issued on 3 August 1981, Council has yet to make its final decision on a number of major issues including merit testing and the question of excluding certain species.

(2) Information necessary for informed public debate is available at present. I am issuing an updated information paper which deals with those matters of public concern most frequently raised with me.

(3) No. Agricultural Council discussions are confidential. However, my Press Release concerning the meeting has been available since 3 August 1981 and the Resolutions from the meeting are being tabled in Parliament.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do procedures exist for the distribution of Community Youth Support Scheme assets.

(3) Does the legal onus of responsibility for ensuring that the disposition of CYSS assets is properly carried out rest with the Member of Parliament who represents the area in which the CYSS centre is located or with an individual CYSS administrative committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The Government has decided that the Community Youth Support Scheme will not be terminated. The current CYSS Guidelines and Administrative Arrangements set out procedures to be followed in the event of an individual project closing.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Industrial Relations: Record of Travel Warrants

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his reply to my question No. 1134 (Hansard, 9 September 1981, page 1124) concerning the number of travel warrants issued for air travel for officers of his Department, why did it take 5 months for him to reply that the information which I sought was not available and would not be made available.
(2) Has it been drawn to his attention that other Ministers' Departments do record this information.
(3) Can he say what are the reasons for the different approaches of Ministers and their departments to this matter of public accountability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The delay was caused by the pressure of other work requirements in that area of my Department responsible for the preparation of the reply. Administrative staffing arrangements have been reviewed to ensure that questions on notice are answered promptly.
I did not say that the information was not available, I said that it was not readily available.
(2) I am not aware of the records held by other Ministers' Departments.

(3) I am not aware of the reasons for the different approaches of Ministers and their Departments but again emphasise that the information is not readily available. It would involve the manual examination of over 9,000 movement requisitions and reference to a large volume of associated airline accounts (and their numerous attachments). I am not prepared to authorise the use of the substantial resources that this would require.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the reply to question No. 2791 by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Hansard, 13 October 1981, page 1935), will the Government, in respect of its position on the importation of baby seal products, take into account whether or not the baby seals from which the products are derived were slaughtered in an inhumane manner, and in the event that this is so, will he undertake to have prohibited the importation of products derived from baby seals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware that there is controversy over the methods used to kill harp seals in Canada. The Canadian Government authorities claim that clubbing, using an instrument called a hakapik, is the most humane of a number of alternative killing methods tried under field conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Government been asked by either the United Nations Organisation or the Thai Government to make a financial contribution toward the revival of the Anti-piracy Unit to be administered by the Thai Navy.

(2) Has the Government made any decision as to whether Australia should give support to this cause, following renewed attacks on Vietnamese refugees and even Australians sailing in the Gulf of Thailand or the South China Seas and following the contribution of $2,600,000 by the United States of America.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There has been no direct bilateral approach from the Thai Government to the Australian Government to make a financial contribution towards the Thai Government's anti-piracy activity. The Thai Government has however submitted to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees proposals for additional funds and equipment which it considers necessary in order to resume anti-piracy patrolling in and around Thai territorial waters. These and similar proposals for the resumption of anti-piracy patrolling are presently being informally discussed between international agencies and interested governments, including Australia.

(2) The Australian Government has consistently condemned the cruel and barbaric practice of piracy and will of course give sympathetic consideration to the provision of appropriate assistance, once the present round of consultations is completed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many hours of overtime were worked during the period 1 January to 19 October 1981 by each air traffic controller based at Brisbane Control Tower.
(2) What is the national average number of hours of overtime worked per air traffic controller.
(3) On how many occasions during 1981 has a check-controller had to stand in for an air traffic controller because of unexpected absences of staff at the Brisbane Control Centre.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Each controller averaged 41 hours 22 minutes overtime.
(2) Approximately 70 hours per annum.
(3) This information is not recorded as the check controller is already on duty when a stand in for a duty controller is required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Fisheries Division of his Department, as well as the South Australian Fisheries Department, recommended in late 1980 that the Investigator Strait fishery be closed to prawn trawling for 2 years.

(2) Did he refuse to close the strait to trawling unless the South Australian Fisheries Department consented to absorb the vessels operating in Investigator Strait, under Commonwealth exploratory fishing permits, into South Australian prawn fisheries.
(3) Did he or his Department grant 12 month exploratory permits for Investigator Strait in 1977 against strong protests from the South Australian Government.
(4) Has the adjoining St Vincent Gulf fishery collapsed because of this action and do the permits remain.
(5) If he did not require the arrangement referred to in part (2), what proposal did he put to the South Australian Department of Fisheries or the South Australian Minister on the question.
(6) If he did require the arrangement referred to in part (2), will it lead to over-fishing and eventually the destruction of other South Australian fisheries.

(7) Did he or his Department co-operate with the South Australian Fisheries Department in a management policy for the joint Commonwealth/State prawn fishery on the West Coast of South Australia, off Venus Bay.
(8) Is it a fact that the fishery was reduced within the 3 year period 1976 to 1979 from an average catch of 239 tonnes to 16 tonnes as a result of the failure of the Commonwealth to co-operate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. I am unable to say what the South Australian Department recommended to their Minister. However, my Department, following extensive consultations with industry was clearly of the view that a decision on closure of Investigator Strait should not be made until final comments were received from industry and other interested community groups.

(3) No. On 10 November 1977 the then Minister for Primary Industry approved an interim arrangement whereby the Commonwealth boat licences in respect of 8 authorised operators would be endorsed subject to certain conditions to permit operations for a 3 month period.

It is true that at the time of the Minister's decision the Commonwealth and South Australian Governments had not reached final agreement on the administration and management of the fishery. Consultations continued until 29 June 1978 when Governments agreed to new management measures which were effectively the same as those implemented by the Commonwealth on 10 November 1977.

(4) On information available to my department, it would not appear that the St Vincents Gulf prawn fishery could be said to have collapsed. However, as this fishery is solely a State-based fishery and therefore managed by the State department I make no further comment.

It would appear that only 6 of the 8 operators authorised to operate in the Investigator Strait fishery are in fact so engaged. Inquiries are being made to determine the rights of the remaining 2 fishermen.

(5) On 10 March 1981 I indicated to Mr Rodda that I would be prepared to consider a 2 year closure of Investigator Strait on the condition that fishing would resume when stocks recovered but stressed that no final decision should be taken until all interested parties had been given opportunity for comment. A joint announcement to this effect was made by Mr Rodda and myself on 27 March 1981.
(6) Not applicable.
(7) Yes. In June 1978 the Commonwealth and South Australian Governments announced agreement on management measures for the prawn fishery on the west coast of Eyre Peninsula.

(8) Annual catches from the fishery for the period 1976 to 1979 inclusive were 51.0 tonnes, 22.8 tonnes, 16.4 tonnes and 32.5 tonnes respectively. Following the implementation of a joint Commonwealth/State management regime catches have recovered to pre-1976 levels.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the specific order of priority followed by his Departmental officers in clearing aircraft for landing at Sydney Kingsford-Smith Airport during periods of air traffic congestion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Aeronautical Information Publication issued by my Department currently contains the following instructions on the subject of 'Regulation of Flight-Assessment of Priorities'.
7.1-ATC will regulate operations to minimise the possibility of conflict and provided that safety is in no way jeopardised, will apply priorities in the following order:
(a) an aircraft in an emergency, including being subjected to unlawful interference, will be given priority in all circumstances;
(b) an aircraft which has suffered radio communications failure will be granted priority for landing;
(c) an aircraft which has declared a mercy flight;
(d) an aircraft participating in a Search and Rescue (SAR), Medical (MED), Hospital Aircraft (HOSP), or Fire and Flood Relief (FFR) flight shall be granted priority as necessary;

(e) an aircraft engaged in the personal transport of Heads of State or of Government or other selected dignitaries, on official visits to Australia, or the personal transport of the Governor-General or the Prime Minister;
(f) a landing aircraft will have priority over a departing aircraft if the latter cannot take-off with prescribed separation standards;
(g) an aircraft landing or taking off will be given priority over taxiing aircraft;
(h) an aircraft which is first able to use the landing area or desired airspace, in the normal course of its operation, will be given priority except;
(i) when significant economic benefit would result for a number of other aircraft by deferring this priority;

(ii) that flights desiring to operate in other than the normal pattern for operational reasons, will be given the same priority as other flights unless it involves a short-notice change to a clearance already issued to another aircraft. In this case, permission to operate will be deferred.
7.1.1-Training flights will be given the same priority as other flights except that:
(a) flights operating in the traffic pattern in general use will be given priority over flights desiring to operate in conflicting patterns for training purposes;
(b) when a training instrument approach is approved, priority will be given to that aircraft from the time it commences its final approach until the approach is completed.

7.1.2-Notwithstanding para. 7.1 (h), during periods when all requirements for operation in a capital city primary control zone, or the overlying control area, cannot be accommodated, priority will be given in the following order:
(a) regular public transport, military and charter aircraft;
(b) aircraft engaged in aerial work;
(c) private aircraft proceeding to the primary airport;
(d) other private aircraft.
Except that at Sydney the following order of priorities will apply:

(a) regular public transport aircraft, charter aircraft of DC9 and heavier type (if associated with RPT operations), IFR charter aircraft proceeding to Bankstown and military aircraft (other than training flights);
(b) charter aircraft (other than in (a) above);
(c) aircraft engaged in aerial work and military training aircraft;
(d) private aircraft types unable to use Bankstown or Camden;
(e) other private flights.

Additionally, instructions have been issued to ATC to provide aircraft engaged in personal transport of State Governors and Premiers and the Administrator and Chief Minister of the Northern Territory with the same priority as the other categories of flight mentioned in paragraph 7.1.2 (a), as applied generally and at Sydney.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did 9,000 sheep die on the ship Persia during a recent trip from Australia to Egypt; if not, how many did die.
(2) Were the deaths due to a failure of the ventilation system on the ship after 2 days' travel from Fremantle, W.A.; if not, what were the reasons.
(3) What is the (a) normal and (b) range of the percentage deaths in the sea transport of live sheep.
(4) What steps can he take and does he intend taking to prevent a high level of deaths in future shipments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The number of sheep that died on the Persia during a trip from Australia to Egypt in September 1981 is reported to be 8,764.

(2) The Persia completed loading of 49,500 sheep on 1 September 1981. On 4 September the ventilation system was out of action for 35 minutes and 266 sheep died. On 8 September the ventilation system was out of action for 5 3/4 hours and 1,003 sheep died. Both periods of non ventilation were caused by a breakdown in the electrical switching system.

Following these two ventilation failures the main engines had to be run at reduced capacity due to a crack developing in a cylinder head liner. This resulted in a reduction in production of drinking water. The ship altered course and called at Aden to take on additional water. There were 6,028 deaths attributable to this water shortage.
The other 1,495 deaths were due to other miscellaneous causes.
(3) (a) The average mortality rate on ships carrying sheep from Australia is 2 per cent approximately and is being progressively reduced due to improved methods.

(b) The range of mortality rates is from less than 1 per cent to about 4 per cent. When a major interruption to conditions is experienced, such as that on the Persia, the rate can be higher. The majority of ships have death rates below 3 per cent.
(4) The Australian Bureau of Animal Health has developed a set of Standards for the Preparation and Carriage of Sheep by Sea. I have informed the industry that these Standards are to be met.
My colleague the Minister for Transport is shortly to introduce revised Marine Orders to control vessels engaged in the carriage of live animals.

Steps have been taken to increase research inputs into this industry. State and Commonwealth officers are planning these inputs at the present time. Funds have been made available to enable veterinarians and other scientists to accompany shipments to carry out observations and measurements and to conduct research.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the scientific testing of building materials for fire safety rating and structural soundness at the Experimental Building Station an essential service to the building industry and to the general public as consumers.
(2) Is it a fact that the services of the station are unique in Australia.
(3) Must the service provided by the station, by its nature, be seen to be independent and unconnected with any commercial interest.
(4) How can the integrity of work performed by the station be guaranteed if it is sold to private interest.

(5) Can he provide any guarantee, that if the station is sold, the full range of testing and related services will continue to be provided for councils and members of the public who depend on these services.
(6) Will the Government urgently review its decision to sell the station in view of the clear need for the retention of the services of the station under government control.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(4) The Government's decision was to dispose of the Station on certain conditions. The successor organisation is required to demonstrate that it could maintain impartiality and technical excellence. This condition was included in the public advertisement for expressions of interest which closed on 9 October.

(5) The public advertisement for expressions of interest also stipulated that the Government's aim is for the Experimental Building Station to be taken over as a going concern, and the Government is prepared to continue its role in building systems accreditation and the development of building regulations. Provision has been made in this year's budget.
(6) See the answer to (5) above.
